image.creator: Cooper, Abraham

image.title2: Steel engraving by E.F. Finden of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Finden, Edward Francis
image.description: Depicts Loch Leven Castle, Fife, scene of Mary Stuart's imprisonment. The plot of Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820) revolves around Mary's escape from the castle. The image was presumably engraved by Finden after his own design.

image.title1: Abbot: Roland Graeme Rescued from the Water
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Rolls after H. Howard of a scene from Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Howard, Henry

image.title2: Steel engraving by W. Miller after C. Stanfield of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts fishermen on Loch Leven, Fife, with the Castle, scene of Mary Stuart's imprisonment, in the background. The plot of Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820) revolves around Mary's escape from the castle.

image.title2: Steel engraving by E.F. Finden after C. Fielding of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Fielding, Copley
image.description: Depicts the boat carrying Queen Mary to England after the Battle of Langside (Abbot, ch. 38), with figures waving on the shore.

image.title2: Steel engraving by E.F. Finden after D. Roberts of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Niddry Castle, West Lothian, where Mary Stuart fled following her escape from Loch Leven Castle (Abbot, ch. 35).

image.creator: Corbould, Henry
image.description: Depicts Roland Graeme as a boy hiding behind the Lady of Avenel as she introduces him to Sir Halbert Glendinning (Abbot, ch. 3).

image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Brandard after G. Cattermole of a scene from Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts Loch Leven Castle, Fife, scene of Mary Stuart's imprisonment, with a group of soldiers on the shore. The plot of Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820) revolves around Mary's escape from the castle.

image.description: Depicts Loch Leven Castle, Fife, scene of Mary Stuart's imprisonment, with a group of soldiers on the shore. The plot of Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820) revolves around Mary's escape from the castle.

image.creator: Cattermole, George

image.title1: Solway Frith, Embarkation of Queen Mary = D̩troit de Solway, embarquement de la Reine Marie

image.description: Depicts Mary Queen of Scots and her followers crossing the Solway Firth into England after her defeat at the Battle of Langside (Abbot, ch. 38).

image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts Crookston Castle, Lanarkshire, to which Queen Mary fled after her defeat at Langside (Abbot, ch. 37).

image.title2: Steel engraving by W. Finden after a drawing by C. Stanfield of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts a view of Edinburgh Castle from Holyrood Park (as seen by Roland Graeme in The Abbot, ch. 17).

image.creator: Gastineau, Henry
image.description: Depicts Loch Leven Castle, Fife, scene of Mary Stuart's imprisonment, with washerwomen in the foreground. The plot of Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820) revolves around Mary's escape from the castle.

image.title2: Steel engraving by W. Radclyffe after a painting by T. Stothard relating to Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Stothard, Thomas
image.description: Depicts the High Street in Edinburgh as it was in the sixteenth century (as seen by Roland Graeme in The Abbot, ch. 17). There are several anachronisms in this engraving, notably the presence of the 17th-century Tron Kirk and the absence of the Netherbow Gate which divided the High Street from the Canongate.

image.title1: The Abbot of Unreason = L'Abb̩ de la D̩raison
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank relating to Scott's novel The Abbot

image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Henry Seyton, disguised as his sister Catherine, knocking a jester to the ground (Abbot, ch. 27). The jester has inadvertently offended Henry during a popular entertainment.

image.creator: Shaw, Byam

image.title2: Woodcut engraving by B. Shaw of a scene from Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Shaw, Byam
image.description: Depicts the keys to Loch Leven Castle, Fife, being swapped to effect Queen Mary's escape (Abbot, ch. 35).

image.title2: Woodcut engraving by B. Shaw of a scene from Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Shaw, Byam
image.description: Depicts Lord Lindesay's delegation crossing Loch Leven, Fife, to the castle (Abbot, ch. 20) in order to force Mary Stuart to abdicate.

image.title2: Woodcut engraving by B. Shaw of a scene from Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Shaw, Byam
image.description: Depicts Abbot Ambrosius trying to pacify the crowd of masqueraders at Kennaquhair Abbey (Abbot, ch. 14).

image.title1: Sir Halbert Glendinning Welcomed Home by his Dog Wolf

image.creator: Shaw, Byam
image.description: Depicts Sir Halbert Glendinning being welcomed by his dog Wolf, with his wife Lady Mary Avenel in the background (Abbot, ch. 3).

image.description: Depicts Jonathan Oldbuck and Lovel bargaining for fish with Maggie Mucklebackit (Antiquary, ch. 11).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by J. M. W. Turner of a scene from Scott's novel The Antiquary
image.creator: Turner, Joseph Mallord William (b.1775, d.1851)

image.title1: 'My good friends, "favete linguis".' = 'Mes bons amis, "favete linguis".'
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel The Antiquary

image.description: Depicts Jonathan Oldbuck's glee at the receipt of important papers (Antiquary, ch. 43).

image.title1: Mrs. Heukbane and Mrs. Shortcake = Madame Heukbane and Madame Shortcake

image.creator: Chisholm, Alexander

image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts Queen Mary and her followers arriving at Niddry Castle, West Lothian, following her escape from Loch Leven Castle (Abbot, ch. 35).

image.creator: Cattermole, George

image.title1: [Steel engraving by T. S. Engleheart from a drawing by H. Richter depicting a scene from Scott's novel The Black Dwarf]
image.creator: Richter, Henry James
image.description: Depicts Isabelle Vere seeking the assistance of Sir Edward Mauley (Black Dwarf, ch. 16).

image.creator: Cruikshank, George

image.creator: Wright, John
image.description: Three-quarter portrait of Lucy Ashton. Details of original publication unknown. Reprinted in: Heath's Book of Beauty. London: Longman, Brown, Green and Longmans, 1833.

image.title2: Engraving by Edward Finden after a drawing by Copley Fielding of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Bride of Lammermoor
image.creator: Fielding, Copley

image.creator: Sharpe, Eliza

image.title1: The Revellers = Les amis de la joie
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel The Fair Maid of Perth
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Oliver Proudfute being 'knighted' by the Prince of Revels at carnival time (Fair Maid of Perth, ch. 16).

image.title1: Bertha at the Camp of the Crusaders = Berthe au camp des Crois̩s
image.title2: Steel engraving by F. W. Topham of a scene from Scott's novel Count Robert of Paris
image.creator: Topham, Francis William
image.description: Depicts Bertha asking to be conducted to the pavilion of Godfrey of Bouillon (Count Robert of Paris, ch. 23). The image was both painted and engraved by Francis William Topham.

image.title1: Ordeal of touching the dead Body = Epreuve de l'attouchement du corps mort
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Sands after a painting by J. Franklin of a scene from Scott's novel The Fair Maid of Perth
image.creator: Franklin, John
image.description: Depicts the body of Oliver Proudfute laid out in Perth Cathedral with King Robert, his brother Albany, and other nobles looking on (Fair Maid of Perth, ch. 23).

image.title2: Steel engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by H. Corbould of a scene from Scott's tale The Death of the Laird's Jock
image.creator: Corbould, Henry
image.description: Depicts the Laird's Jock's despair as he sees his son killed in single combat with an English champion, and his daughter attempting to restrain and comfort him. The short story 'Death of the Laird's Jock' was published by Scott in the 1828 issue of The Keepsake.

image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by Edward Finden after a drawing by A. Naysmith of a scene from Scott's novel The Fortunes of Nigel
image.creator: Nasmyth, Alexander (b.1758, d.1840)
image.description: Vignette depiction of Whitehall, London, with Richard Moniplies presenting Nigel Olifaunt's supplication to King James I and VI (Fortunes of Nigel, ch. 3).

image.title1: The Fortunes of Nigel: The Scene with Nigel, Trapbois, and Colepepper
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Mitchell after a drawing by J. M. Wright of a scene from Scott's novel The Fortunes of Nigel
image.creator: Wright, John Massey
image.description: Shows the usurer Trapbois preventing Nigel Olifaunt and Captain Colepepper from coming to blows (Fortunes of Nigel, ch. 23).

image.title1: The Fair Maid of Perth and Carthusian Monk = La Belle de Perth and le moine carthusien
image.title2: Steel engraving by P. Lightfoot after a painting by A. Chisolm of two characters from Scott's novel The Fair Maid of Perth
image.creator: Chisholm, Alexander
image.description: Depicts a Carthusian monk teaching Catharine Glover, the 'Fair Maid of Perth' with a view of the Tay Valley from Kinoull Hill, 'one of the most beautiful prospects in Scotland' (Fair Maid of Perth, ch. 14).

image.title1: The Citizen and the Soldier = Le Bourgeois et le Soldat
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel The Fortunes of Nigel
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Captain Colepepper fleeing after his duel with the Jin Vin, the 'citizen of London' (who is glimpsed disappearing through a gate) (Fortunes of Nigel, ch. 12).

image.title1: The Fortunes of Nigel: Nigel Encountering the Murderers of Trapbois
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Romney from a drawing by T. M. Wright of a scene from Scott's novel The Fortunes of Nigel
image.creator: Wright, Thomas M.
image.description: Depicts Nigel Olifaunt rescuing Martha Trapbois from her father's murderers (Fortunes of Nigel, ch. 24).

image.title1: The Fortunes of Nigel: Camlet Moat
image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by Edward Finden after a drawing by A. Naysmith of a scene from Scott's novel The Fortunes of Nigel
image.creator: Nasmyth, Alexander (b.1758, d.1840)
image.description: Vignette depicting the murder of Lord Dalgarno at Camlet Moat, London (Fortunes of Nigel, ch. 36).

image.title1: King James, Prince Charles, and Nigel = Le Roi Jacques, le Prince Charles, and Nigel
image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Staines from a drawing by A. Chisolm of characters from Scott's novel The Fortunes of Nigel
image.creator: Chisholm, Alexander
image.description: Depicts Nigel Olifaunt parleying with James I and VI and Prince Charles during a deer hunt (Fortunes of Nigel, ch. 12).

image.title2: Steel engraving by H. Adlard after a drawing by J. Franklin of a scene from Scott's novel The Fortunes of Nigel
image.creator: Franklin, John
image.description: Shows Nigel Olifaunt, Lord Glenvarloch, challenging Dalgarno to combat in St. James's Park, London (Fortunes of Nigel, ch. 16).

image.title2: Steel engraving by Lumb Stocks after a drawing by John Faed of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Faed, John
image.description: Depicts Godfrey Bertram seated before Ellangowan Castle, with Lucy Bertram, Charles Hazlewood, and Dominie Sampson (Guy Mannering, ch. 13). The picture illustrates the following words: 'Mr. Bertram, paralytic, and almost incapable of moving, occupiedhis easy-chair [...]. Behind him, with his hands crossed on the cane upon which he rested, stood Dominie Sampson, whom Mannering recognised at once. [...] On one side of the old man was a sylph-like form--a young woman of about seventeen [...] whom the Colonel accounted to be his daughter.'

image.title1: 'He grinned like an ogre, swung his arms like the sails of a wind-mill, shouted "Prodigious", till the roof rung to his raptures.'
image.title2: Steel engraving by A. Duncan after a drawing by C. R. Leslie of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Depicts Dominie Sampson's joy on beholding the Bishop's library which he is to catalogue and organize (Guy Mannering, ch. 20).

image.title1: Guy Mannering: Meg Merrilies Compelling Dominie Sampson to Eat
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Romney after a drawing by C. R. Leslie of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Shows Meg Merrilies forcing Dominie Sampson to eat her broth (Guy Mannering, ch. 46).

image.title1: Dirk Hatteraick pursued by the Sloop of War = Dirk Hatteraick poursuivi par le sloop de guerre
image.title2: Steel engraving by James Bayliss Allen after a drawing by G. Balmer of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Balmer, George
image.description: Depicts the smuggler Dirk Hatteraick's lugger being pursued by a sloop of war (Guy Mannering, ch. 9).

image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts 'village matrons' helping Dominie Sampson out of the slough of Lochend (Guy Mannering, ch. 8).

image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by P. De Wint of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Vignette engraving of the Bertram family castle of Ellangowan, based on Caerlaverock Castle, Dumfriesshire.

image.title1: Coln. Mannering, Hazlewood and the Smugglers = Coln. Mannering, Hazlewood et les contrebandiers
image.title2: Steel engraving after J. M. W. Turner by W. Finden of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Turner, Joseph Mallord William (b.1775, d.1851)
image.description: Depicts Mannering and Hazlewood on horseback routing smugglers who are besieging Woodbourne (Guy Mannering, ch. 30).

image.title1: The Waste of Cumberland = Plaine de Cumberland
image.title2: Steel engraving by Robert Staines after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts Dandie Dinmont and Henry Bertram escaping from Mumps Hall inn, Gilsland, Cumbria (Guy Mannering, ch. 13).

image.title2: Woodcut engraving by C. A. Shepperson of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Shepperson, Claude Allin
image.description: Depicts Meg Merrilies cursing Godfrey Bertram after the eviction of the gypsies from Ellangowan (Guy Mannering, ch. 8).

image.title1: Carlaverock [sic] Castle, the Common of Ellangowan = Ch̢teau de Carlaverock, communes d'Ellangowan
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. H. Kernot after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts Ellangowan Castle (based on Caerlaverock Castle, Dumfriesshire), with Meg Merrilies, Henry Bertram, and Dandie Dinmont in the foreground, and Lucy Bertram and Julie Mannering in the background (Guy Mannering, ch. 53).

image.title2: Woodcut engraving by C. A. Shepperson of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Shepperson, Claude Allin
image.description: Depicts Guy Mannering meeting Dirk Hatteraick along with Meg Merrilies (Guy Mannering, ch. 4).

image.title1: 'Gape, sinner, and swallow!' = 'Ouvre la bouche, pecheur, et avale!'
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Meg Merrilies forcing Dominie Sampson to eat her broth (Guy Mannering, ch. 46).

image.title1: The Grass Market: The Death of Porteous = Le Grass Market: Mort de Porteous
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Tingle after a drawing by T. M. Richardson of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Richardson, Thomas Miles I
image.description: Depicts the lynching of Captain Porteous in the Grassmarket, Edinburgh (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 7).

image.title1: The Heart of Mid-Lothian: The Interview of Jeanie Deans with the Queen
image.title2: Steel engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by C. R. Leslie of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Shows Jeanie Deans begging Queen Caroline to pardon her sister Effie (Heart of Midlothian ch. 37).

image.title2: Woodcut engraving by C. A. Shepperson of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Shepperson, Claude Allin
image.description: Depicts Dirk Hatteraick strangling Glossin (Guy Mannering, ch. 57).

image.title2: Woodcut engraving by C. A. Shepperson of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Shepperson, Claude Allin
image.description: Depicts Dominie Sampson's joy at beholding the Bishop's library which he is to catalogue and organize (Guy Mannering, ch. 20).

image.title1: Julia and Hazlewood meet Brown in the Plantation
image.title2: Woodcut engraving by C. A. Shepperson of a scene from Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Shepperson, Claude Allin
image.description: Depicts Julia Mannering, Charles Hazelwood, Lucy Bertram, and a servant chancing upon Vanbeest Brown in a fir plantation (Guy Mannering, ch. 31).

image.title2: Steel engraving by W. H. Mote after a drawing by C. R. Leslie of a character from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Depicts Jeanie Deans in a tartan head-dress as she is presented to the Duke of Argyle (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 34). Illustrates the text: 'She wore the tartan plaid of her country, adjusted so as partly to cover her head, and partly to fall back over her shoulders. A quantity of fair hair, disposed with great simplicity and neatness, appeared in front of her round and good-humoured face, to which the solemnity of her errand gave an appearance of deep awe.'

image.title2: Steel engraving by T. Johannot of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Johannot, Tony
image.description: Depicts Meg Murdockson and Madge Wildfire apprehending Jeanie Deans on the road to London (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 29). From Trente vignettes pour les oeuvres de Walter Scott d'apr̬s les tableaux de MM. Alfred et Tony Johannot. Paris: Furne, 1832? The Heart of Mid-Lothian was translated into French as La Prison d'Edimbourg (The Prison of Edinburgh).

image.title2: Steel engraving by Charles Rolls after a drawing by H. Richter of a scene from Leitch Ritchie's story The Outlaw's Bride
image.creator: Richter, Henry James
image.description: Depicts a sleeping Jeanie Deans with Meg Murdockson and, in the background, Madge Wildfire (Heart of Mid-Lothian, ch. 31). The print, originally designed to illustrate The Heart of Mid-Lothian is here employed to illustrate a short tale, 'The Outlaw's Bride', by Leitch Ritchie. In its new context it depicts Jeanie Lindsay in Ronald Cameron's hut (The Outlaw's Bride, ch. 3).

image.title2: Steel engraving by W. Finden after a drawing by W. Daniell of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Daniell, William
image.description: Mountain and seascape depiction of the Isle of Arran (described in The Heart of Midlothian, ch. 42).

image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by W. H. Lizars of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Lizars, William Home
image.description: Title page vignette depicting David Deans's cottage in St Leonard's, Edinburgh, with the Salisbury Crags and Arthur's Seat in the background. The image was engraved by Lizars after his own design.

image.title1: The Affecting Scene between Effie Deans and her Sister in the Tolbooth
image.title2: Engraving by C. Rolls after a drawing by C. R. Leslie of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Shows Jeanie and Effie Deans embracing while the jailer stands at the window (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 19).

image.title2: Steel engraving by Edward Finden after a drawing by A. Naysmith of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Nasmyth, Alexander (b.1758, d.1840)
image.description: Depicts the Old Tolbooth or town prison of Edinburgh (commonly known as the 'Heart of Midlothian'), scene of Effie Deans's imprisonment.

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Cousen after a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts the West Bow in Edinburgh, the route by which the condemned Andrew Wilson is escorted to the Grassmarket in Scott's The Heart of Midlothian (ch. 3).

image.title1: The Heart of Mid-Lothian: Breakfast Scene with Captain Knockdunder at Knocktarlitie
image.title2: Steel engraving by John Romney from a drawing by William Allan of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Allan, William
image.description: Depicts Knockdunder, Dolly Dutton, Jeanie Deans, and Reuben Butler at breakfast (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 44).

image.title2: Steel engraving by Edward Finden after a drawing by G. Barret of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Barret, George
image.description: Depicts St. Anthony's Chapel, in Holyrood Park, Edinburgh, scene of Jeanie Deans's meeting with George Staunton (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 15)

image.title1: St. Anthony's Chapel, Salisbury Crags = Chapelle de St. Antoine, Rochers de Salisbury
image.title2: Steel engraving by Robert Staines after a drawing by Henry Melville of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts St. Anthony's Chapel in Holyrood Park, Edinburgh with Jeanie Deans on her way to a meeting with George Staunton (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 15).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by G. E. Robson of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Robson, George Fennel
image.description: Depicts a panoramic view of the city of Durham, through which Jeanie Deans passes in The Heart of Midlothian, ch. 27.

image.title2: Steel engravng by E.F. Finden after a drawing by P. De Wint of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Shows a panoramic view of Newark Castle, Nottinghamshire. Jeanie Deans passes through Newark in The Heart of Midlothian, ch. 29.

image.title2: Steel engraving by Edward Finden after a drawing by D. Roberts of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts Dumbarton (or Dunbarton) Castle, Strathclyde, glimpsed by Jeanie Deans in The Heart of Midlothian, ch. 41.

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Stephenson after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts Jeanie Deans on a boat beneath Dumbarton (or Dunbarton) Castle, Strathclyde (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 41).

image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by G. Adcock from a drawing by A. Chisholm of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Chisholm, Alexander
image.description: Portrait of Effie Deans, known for her beauty as the 'Lily of St. Leonards', as described in The Heart of Midlothian, ch. 9. Illustrates the text: 'Effie Deans had now shot up into a beautiful and blooming girl. Her Grecian-shaped head was profusely rich in waving ringlets of brown hair, which, confined by a black hood of silk, and shading a laughing Hebe countenance, seemed the picture of health, pleasure, and contentment.'

image.title2: Steel engraving by Edward Finden after a design by J. D. Harding of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Skene, James
image.description: Depicts the Holy Loch (Argyll and Bute) on which the fictional town of Knockdunder is situated in Scott's The Heart of Midlothian. The design by J. D. Harding was made after an original sketch by Scott's friend James Skene of Rubislaw.

image.title1: Madge Wildfire and Jeanie Deans = Madge Wildfire et Jeanne Deans
image.title2: Steel engraving by G. Presbury after a painting by J. Linnell of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Linnell, John
image.description: Depicts Madge Wildfire and Jeanie Deans in Willingham churchyard, Cambridgeshire (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 31).

image.title1: 'Jeanie - I say, Jeanie, woman' = 'Jeannette, ̩coute, Jeannette, ma fille'
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Shows Jeanie Deans evading the attentions of the Laird of Dumbiedikes in her father's cottage (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 9).

image.title1: 'A "summat" to eat and drink' = '"Quelque chose" a manger et a boire'
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Shows Mr Stubbs and Tummas dining at a table with Jeanie Deans sitting in a corner (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 32).

image.title1: The Captain of Knockdunder = Le Capitaine de Knockdunder
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Captain Knockdunder smoking during a sermon (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 7).

image.title1: Hamish Bean and his Mother = Hamish Bean and sa m̬re
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. C. Bentley after a drawing by F. W. Topham of a scene from Scott's story The Highland Widow
image.creator: Topham, Francis William
image.description: Depicts Hamish Bean and his mother awaiting soldiers who have come to arrest him on a charge of desertion (Highland Widow, ch. 5).

image.title1: The Heart of Mid-Lothian: St. Anthony's Chapel
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by P. De Wint of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Vignette engraving of St. Anthony's Chapel in Holyrood Park, Edinburgh, scene of Jeanie Deans's meeting with George Staunton (Heart of Midlothian, ch. 15).

image.title1: Heart of Mid-Lothian: Heart of Mid-Lothian
image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by P. De Wint of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Vignette engraving of the Old Tolbooth, Edinburgh's former city gaol (known as the "Heart of Midlothian").

image.title1: Prince John and Rebecca at the Passage of Arms at Ashby = Le prince Jean and Rebecca au passage des armes a Ashby
image.title2: Steel engraving by P. Lightfoot from a drawing by S. A. Hart of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Hart, Solomon Alexander
image.description: Depicts Prince John on horseback espying Rebecca at the tournament at Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire (Ivanhoe, ch. 8).

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Mitchell from a drawing by F. P. Stephanoff of a scene from Scott's tragedy The House of Aspen
image.creator: Stephanoff, Francis Philip
image.description: Depicts Isabella confessing to George Aspen that she has murdered her first husband (House of Aspen, Act 3, Scene 1). The House of Aspen is an adaptation of Leonhard Waechter's Der heilige Vehme

image.title2: Steel engraving by F. Bacon from a drawing by A. E. Chalon of a scene from Scott's tragedyThe House of Aspen
image.creator: Chalon, Alfred Edward
image.description: Depicts Isabella and Gertrude frightened by knocking at the chapel door (House of Aspen, Act 4, Scene 2). The House of Aspen is an adaptation of Leonhard Waechter's Der heilige Vehme.

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Heath from a drawing by R. Westall of a character from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Ivanhoe disguised as a Palmer warning Isaac, the Jew of York, that his life is in danger (Ivanhoe, ch. 6).

image.title1: The Rescue of Ivanhoe = La D̩livrance d'Ivanhoe.
image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Staines after a drawing by T. Allom of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Allom, Thomas
image.description: Depicts the Black Knight (King Richard in disguise) coming to the rescue of Ivanhoe at the tournament at Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire (Ivanhoe, ch. 12).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Rebecca threatening to throw herself from the turret of the Castle of Torquilstone with Brian de Bois Gilbert endeavouring to dissuade her (Ivanhoe, ch. 24).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Rowena being rescued from the burning Castle of Torquilstone by Cedric and Gurth (Ivanhoe, ch. 31).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Rebecca at the stake refusing Brian de Bois Gilbert's plea for her to escape with him (Ivanhoe, ch. 43).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Wamba and Front-de-Boeuf at Rotherwood (Ivanhoe, ch. 4).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Ivanhoe collapsing at Rowena's feet after the tournament at Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire (Ivanhoe, ch. 9).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Ivanhoe disguised as a palmer, kneeling before Rowena and her maids (Ivanhoe, ch. 6).

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Cochran after a drawing by S. A. Hart of a character from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Hart, Solomon Alexander
image.description: Depicts Rebecca at the tournament at Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire (Ivanhoe, ch. 7). Illustrates the following text: 'Her turban of yellow silk suited well with the darkness of her complexion. The brilliancy of her eyes, the superb arch of her eyebrows, her well-formed aquiline nose, her teeth as white as pearl, and the profusion of her sable tresses [...] fell down upon as much of a lovely neck and bosom as a simarre of the richest Persian silk [...] permitted to be visible.'

image.title2: Steel engraving by H. T. Ryall after a drawing by L. Sharpe of a character from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Sharpe, Louisa
image.description: Three-quarter portrait of Rebecca, heroine of Scott's Ivanhoe. This engraving was first published in Heath's Book of Beauty (London: Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown, Green, and Longmans, 1833).

image.title2: Steel engraving by Pelee after a drawing by T. Johannot of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Johannot, Tony
image.description: Depicts Ivanhoe at Rowena's feet after the tournament at Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire (Ivanhoe, ch. 9). From Trente vignettes pour les oeuvres de Walter Scott d'apr̬s les tableaux de MM. Alfred et Tony Johannot (Paris: Furne, 1832)?

image.title2: Steel engraving by A. W. Warren after a painting by T. Stothard of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Stothard, Thomas
image.description: Shows Rebecca being tried by the Grand Master of the Knights Templar with two guards at her side (Ivanhoe, ch. 37).

image.title2: Steel engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by C. R. Leslie of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Depicts Rebecca, heroine of Scott's Ivanhoe, imprisoned in Torquilstone Castle. Illustrates an anonymous poem entitled 'Rebecca' which imagines Rebecca's thoughts when imprisoned in Torquilstone Castle.

image.title2: Steel engraving by S. Freeman after a drawing by F. Stone of a character from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Stone, Frank
image.description: Three-quarter portrait of Rowena, heroine of Scott's novel Ivanhoe. Illustrates the text: 'The Lady Rowena had watched the progress of the day with equal attention, though without [...] betraying the same intense interest.'

image.title2: Steel engraving by Edward Finden after a drawing by Peter de Wint of a scene relating to Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Depicts the landscape of Wharncliffe, Yorkshire, as described in Ivanhoe, ch. 1.

image.title1: The Black Knight and the Clerk of Copmanhurst Carousing
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Romney after a drawing by T. Stothard of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Stothard, Thomas
image.description: Depicts the Black Knight (King Richard in disguise) and Friar Tuck drinking by the light of a single torch (Ivanhoe, ch. 16).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by P. de Wint of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Jervaulx (or Jorvaulx) Abbey, Yorkshire. The Prior of the Abbey appears in Ivanhoe as an ally of Brian de Bois Guilbert

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene relating to Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Skene, James
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Ashby Castle, Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire, scene of the knightly tournament in Ivanhoe, ch. 8. Cattermole's design is based on an original sketch by Scott's friend James Skene of Rubislaw.

image.title1: The Black Knight and the Clerk of Copmanhurst = Le chevalier noir et le Clerc de Copmanhurst.
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Friar Tuck and the Black Knight (King Richard in disguise) carousing in the hermitage (Ivanhoe, ch. 18).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by P. de Wint of a scene relating to Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Depicts Conisbrough Castle, South Yorkshire, portrayed (as Coningsburgh Castle) in Ivanhoe as the home of Athelstane.

image.title1: The Castle of Coningsburgh = Ch̢teau de Coningsburgh
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. C. Bentley after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Shows King Richard, Ivanhoe, Gurth, and Wamba arriving at the Castle of Coningsburgh (modern-day Conisbrough, South Yorkshire) for Athelstane's funeral (Ivanhoe, ch. 41).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by F. Nash of a scene relating to Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Nash, Frederick
image.description: Depicts York Minster, scene of the marriage of Ivanhoe and Rowena (Ivanhoe, ch. 44).

image.title1: 'One foot nearer and I plunge myself from the precipice' = 'Un pied plus pr̬s et je me plonge dans le pr̩cipice'
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Goodyear after a drawing by G. Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Rebecca threatening to throw herself from the parapet of Torquilstone Castle to escape Brian de Bois Gilbert (Ivanhoe, ch. 24).

image.title1: Athelstane's Escape from the Dungeon = Athelstane s'̩vadant du donjon
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Shows Athelstane, who has broken his chains, bursting out of his cell to the terror of the Sacristan and Friar Tuck who believe him to be a ghost (Ivanhoe, ch. 42).

image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by Edward Finden of a scene from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Finden, Edward Francis
image.description: Vignette of Torquilstone Castle, as described in Ivanhoe, ch. 21. The vignette is presumably engraved after Finden's own design.

image.title2: Steel engraving by Charles Heath from a drawing by Richard Westall from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Brian de Bois-Guilbert threatening Gurth and Wamba who have refused to direct him to the home of their master, Cedric the Saxon (Ivanhoe, ch. 2).

image.title1: The Countess in the Withdrawing Room Attended by Janet
image.title2: Steel engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by C. R. Leslie from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Depicts Amy Robsart sitting with her attendant Janet Foster at Cumnor Place, Oxfordshire (Kenilworth, ch. 6?).

image.title1: 'Upstarted of a Sudden Tony Foster himself, with a Cudgel in his Hand.'
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Romney after a drawing by C. R. Leslie from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Depicts Tony Foster threatening Goldthread (Kenilworth, ch. 2).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by P. de Wint of a scene relating to Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Kenilworth Castle, Warwickshire, home of the Earl of Leicester in Scott's novel Kenilworth.

image.title2: Engraving by M. N. Bate after a drawing by W. H. Brooke of a scene from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Brooke, William Henry
image.description: Stylized miniature depicting Leicester seated on a chair of state and Amy on a footstool admiring his chains of honour and garter (Kenilworth, vol. I, ch. VII).

image.title2: Engraving by M. N. Bate after a drawing by W. H. Brookes of a scene from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Brooke, William Henry
image.description: Stylized miniature depicting a male and a female figure (the Earl of Leicester and Amy Robsart?) at a window.

image.title1: Wayland Smith's Cave = Caverne de Wayland Smith
image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Staines after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts Wayland Smith threatening Tressilian at the mouth of his cave while Dick Sludge attempts to intervene (Kenilworth, ch. 9).

image.title2: Engraving by M. N. Bate after a drawing by W. H. Brooke of a scene from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Brooke, William Henry
image.description: Depicts Tressilian on horseback with the mocking figure of Dickie Sludge in the background (Kenilworth, ch. 10).

image.title1: Queen Elizabeth at Greenwich Hospital = La reine Elisabeth a l'h̫pital de Greenwich
image.title2: Steel engraving by H. C. Shenton after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts Sir Walter Raleigh covering a puddle with his cloak as Queen Elizabeth embarks at Greenwich Hospital, London (Kenilworth, ch. 15).

image.title1: Dickie Sludge and the Giant Porter = Dickie Sludge et le grand portier.
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Shows the giant porter holding Dickie Sludge high in the air in front of the entrance to Kenilworth Castle, Warwickshire (Kenilworth, ch. 26).

image.title2: Steel engraving by W. Floyd from a drawing by T. Allom of a scene from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Allom, Thomas
image.description: Depicts Queen Elizabeth's arrival at Kenilworth Castle, Warwickshire (Kenilworth, ch. 30).

image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Dickie Sludge ("Flibbertigibbet") taking leave of Tressilian and Wayland Smith (Kenilworth, ch. 11).

image.title1: Kenilworth: The Countess Admiring the Decorations of the Earl
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by H. Howard of a scene from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Howard, Henry
image.description: Depicts Leicester seated on a chair of state with Amy Robsart on a footstool admiring his chain of honour (Kenilworth, ch. 7).

image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by E. Finden of a scene relating to Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Finden, Edward Francis
image.description: Vignette depiction of Warwick Castle, Warwickshire, in which Queen Elizabeth stays en route to Kenilworth Castle (Kenilworth, ch. 25). The vignette is presumably engraved after Finden's own design.

image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by Edward Finden of a scene relating to Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Finden, Edward Francis
image.description: Vignette engraving of the ruined gateway of Kenilworth Castle, Warwickshire, as described in Kenilworth, ch. 25. The vignette is presumably engraved after Finden's own design.

image.title1: The Guard Room in Stirling Castle
image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Brandard after a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene from Scott's poem The Lady of the Lake
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts Ellen Douglas, the Lady of the Lake, entering the guard room accompanied by Allan the harper (Lady of the Lake, canto VI, stanza VII).

image.title1: The Mock Battle = La petite guerre
image.title2: Steel engraving by T. A. Prior after a drawing by T. Allom of a scene from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Allom, Thomas
image.description: Depicts a mock battle between the English and Danes held at Kenilworth Castle, Warwickshire, for Queen Elizabeth's amusement (Kenilworth, ch. 37).

image.title1: 'While thus he poured the lengthened tale, the Minstrel's voice began to fail.'
image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by H. Adlard after a drawing by C. Landseer of a scene from Scott's poem The Lay of the Last Minstrel
image.creator: Landseer, Charles (b.1799, d.1879)
image.description: Depicts the Minstrel's recital at Newark Castle, Scottish Borders (Lay of the last Minstrel, canto II, stanza XXXV).

image.title1: 'Full fast the urchin ran and laughed. But faster still a cloth-yard shaft whistled from startled Tinlinn's yew.' Canto IV Stanza XII
image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by H. Adlard after a drawing by J. M. Wright of a scene from Scott's poem The Lay of the Last Minstrel
image.creator: Wright, John Massey
image.description: Depicts Tinlinn firing an arrow at Cranstoun's goblin page who has assumed the shape of Lady Branksome's infant son (Lay of the last Minstrel, canto IV, stanza XII).

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Mitchell after a painting by C. R. Leslie of a scene from Scott's poem The Lay of the Last Mistrel
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Depicts a child playing at soldiers and an armoured guard. John Banim (1798-1842) and his brother Michael Banim (1796-1874) wrote national tales and novels, using the pseudonyms Barnes and Abel O'Hara, with the aim of doing for Ireland what Scott had done for Scotland. This engraving may originally have been intended as an illustration for Scott's The Lay of the Last Minstrel, possibly portraying Lady Branksome's infant son.

image.title2: Steel engraving by Revel from a drawing by Tony Johannot of a scene from Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Johannot, Tony
image.description: Depicts Captain Dalgetty being knighted by the Marquis of Montrose (Legend of Montrose, ch. 19). From Trente vignettes pour les oeuvres de Walter Scott d'apr̬s les tableaux de MM. Alfred et Tony Johannot (Paris: Furne, 1832)? A Legend of Montrose was translated into French as L'Officier de fortune (The Mercenary).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden from a drawing by G. F. Robson of a scene relating to Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Robson, George Fennel
image.description: Depicts Dunstaffnage Castle, Argyll, the model for Ardenvohr Castle in The Legend of Montrose, ch. 10.

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by W. Daniell of a scene relating to Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Daniell, William
image.description: Depicts the busy pier at Inveraray (formerly Inverary), Argyll and Bute, as described in A Legend of Montrose, ch. 11.

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Cochran after a drawing by R. Edmonston of a character from Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Edmonstone, Robert
image.description: Portrait of Annot Lyle, heroine of Scott's A Legend of Montrose. Illustrates the following lines: 'Yet Annot's garments were not only becoming, but even rich. Her open jacket, with a high collar, was composed of blue cloth, richly embroidered, and had silver clasps to fasten, when it pleased the wearer.'

image.title1: A Legend of Montrose: Captain Dalgetty Consigning Gustavus to the Care of the Children of the Mist
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by W. Allan of a scene from Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Allan, William
image.description: Depicts Captain Dalgetty consigning his horse Gustavus to the care of the Children of the Mist (Legend of Montrose, ch. 14).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden from a drawing by J. B. Fraser of a scene relating to Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Fraser, James Baillie
image.description: Depicts the mouth of Loch Awe and Ben Cruachan (Argyll and Bute) as described in The Legend of Montrose, ch. 17.

image.title1: A Legend of Montrose: Dalgetty and Ranald of the Mist Escaping through the Chapel
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by C. R. Leslie of a scene from Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Shows Ranald and Dalgetty escaping from Inverary Castle, Argyll and Bute, via the chapel (Legend of Montrose, ch. 13).

image.title1: Captain Dalgetty at Ardenvohr = Le capitaine Dalgetty a Ardenvohr
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts four kilted Highlanders hurrying Captain Dalgetty towards a meeting with Sir Duncan Campbell (Legend of Montrose, ch. 10).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by G. F. Robson of a scene relating to Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Robson, George Fennel
image.description: Depicts Inverlochy Castle, Invernessshire, and surrounding landscape. The Battle of Inverlochy (1645), portrayed in the Legend of Montrose (ch. 18), saw Montrose's Royalist forces defeat a Covenanting army.

image.title1: The Pass of Leny = Passage du Leny
image.title2: Steel engraving by S. Fisher from a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Portrays the meeting of Lord Monteith and Captain Dalgetty at the Pass of Leny, Perthshire (Legend of Montrose, ch. 2).

image.title1: Castle of Inverlochy = Ch̢teau de Inverlochy
image.title2: Steel engraving by G. Presbury after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts the Battle of Inverlochy (1645), portrayed in A Legend of Montrose, ch. 18, which saw Montrose's Royalist forces defeat a Covenanting army.

image.title1: [Steel vignette engraving by J. Horsburgh from a drawing by W. Allan illustrating Scott's essay 'Henry Mackenzie;]
image.creator: Allan, William
image.description: Depicts Julia de Roubign̩ fainting in the arms of her nurse with Savillon by her side, a scene from Henry Mackenzie's epistolary novel Julia de Roubign̩ (1777).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene from Scott's poem The Maid of Neidpath
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts the Maid of Neidpath on a balcony of Neidpath Castle, Scottish Borders, signalling to her lover (Maid of Neidpath, verses 23-24).

image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by Charles Heath from a drawing by P. de Wint of a setting for Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Vignette engraving showing Inverary Castle, seat of the Dukes of Argyll, on the shores of Loch Fyne (Argyll and Bute). The original building was burnt down by Montrose in 1644.

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts Marmion, in a hall of Crichton Castle, Midlothian, relating his adventure with the phantom knight to Sir David Lindsay (Marmion, canto IV, stanzas XIX-XXI).

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. W. Appleton from a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene relating to Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts picnicking figures with Linlithgow Palace, West Lothian, in the background (Marmion, canto IV, stanza 15).

image.title2: Engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by H. Singleton of a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Singleton, Henry
image.description: Depicts Constance de Beverley consigning papers proving De Wilton's innocence to the Abbess of St. Hilda (Marmion, canto II, stanza XXX).

image.title2: Engraving by Charles Heath from a drawing by H. Singleton of a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Singleton, Henry
image.description: Depicts Marmion hiding his face in despair after hearing Fitz-Eustace's song (canto III, stanza XII).

image.title2: Engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by H. Singleton of a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Singleton, Henry
image.description: Depicts Marmion in full armour greeting the King James IV of Scotland (canto IV, stanza VIII).

image.title2: Engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by H. Singleton of a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Singleton, Henry
image.description: Depicts Marmion waking his servant Fitz-Eustace (canto III, stanza XXVII).

image.title2: Engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by H. Singleton of a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Singleton, Henry
image.description: Depicts Lady Heron playing the harp and singing (Marmion, canto V, stanza XIII).

image.title2: Engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by H. Singleton of a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Singleton, Henry
image.description: Depicts the combat between Marmion and de Wilton (canto IV, stanza XXI).

image.title1: The Duel between Halbert and Sir Piercie Shafton
image.title2: Woodcut engraving by Byam Shaw of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Shaw, Byam
image.description: Depicts the duel between Halbert Glendinning and Sir Piercie Shafton (Monastery, ch. 21).

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. T. Wilmore after a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Landscape depiction of the fictional valley of Glendearg (based on the valley of Allen Water), showing Christie of the Clint Hill riding to overtake the Sub-Prior of Kennaquhair (Monastery, ch. 9).

image.title2: Woodcut engraving by Byam Shaw of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Shaw, Byam
image.description: Depicts Halbert Glendinning delivering a message to the Regent Murray (Monastery, ch. 35).

image.title2: Woodcut engraving by Byam Shaw of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Shaw, Byam
image.description: Depicts Sir Piercie Shafton and Mysie Happer posing as his page (Monastery, ch. 29).

image.title1: Mary Avenel and Mysie in Glendearg Tower
image.title2: Woodcut engraving by Byam Shaw of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Shaw, Byam
image.description: Depicts Mysie Happer at a window watching Sir Piercie Shafton's arrival, with Mary Avenel in the background (Monastery, ch. 14).

image.title1: Edward Glendinning Demanding an Account of his Brother of Sir Piercie Shafton
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Rolls after a drawing by W. Brockedon of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Brockedon, William
image.description: Depicts Edward Glendinning confronting Sir Piercie Shafton who he wrongly believes has killed his brother Halbert (Monastery, ch. 27).

image.title2: Woodcut engraving by Byam Shaw of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Shaw, Byam
image.description: Depicts Stawarth Bolton on horseback with Elspeth Glendinning and her children in front of the gates of Glendearg (Monastery, ch. 2).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Scriven after a drawing by H. Howard of a character from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Howard, Henry
image.description: Frontal portrait of the White Lady, supernatural protectress of the House of Avenel in Scott's novel The Monastery. Inspired by the lines: '"Noon gleams on the Lake | Noon glows on the Fell | Wake thee, O wake, | White Maid of Avenel!" These lines were hardly uttered, when there stood the figure of a female clothed in white, within three steps of Halbert Glendinning.' (The Monastery, ch. 11)

image.title2: Steel engraving by G. H. Adcock from a drawing by E. Prentis of a character from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Prentis, Edward
image.description: Three quarter portrait of Mysie Happer, the miller's daughter in Scott's novel The Monastery. Inspired by the lines: 'The countenance itself was exceedingly comely--the eyes black, large, and roguishly good-humoured--the mouth was small--the lips well formed, though somewhat full--the teeth were pearly white--and the chin had a very seducing dimple in it.' (The Monastery, ch. 13)

image.title2: Steel engraving by H. Cook after a drawing by R. B. Faulkner of a character from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Faulkner, Benjamin Rawlinson
image.description: Portrait of Mary Avenel, heroine of Scott's novel The Monastery. Inspired by the lines: 'Mary Avenel had been taught by the peculiarity of her situation, to regard herself as the Child of Destiny; and the melancholy and reflecting turn of her disposition gave to her sorrows a depth and breadth peculiar to her character.' (The Monastery, ch. 30)

image.title2: Steel engraving by A. Caron after a drawing by A. Johannot of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Johannot, Alfred
image.description: Depicts Sir Piercie Shafton attempting to revive Mary Avenel. Behind him, Edward Glendinning is being prevented from drawing his sword to avenge his brother Halbert whom he wrongly believes Shafton has killed (Monastery, ch. 26). From Trente vignettes pour les oeuvres de Walter Scott d'apr̬s les tableaux de MM. Alfred et Tony Johannot (Paris: Furne, 1832)?

image.title1: 'Knowest thou then this token?' = 'Connais-tu donc ce signe?'
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Halbert Glendinning confronting Sir Piercie Shafton with a token received from the White Lady (Monastery, ch. 19).

image.title1: Abbot Boniface and Father Philip = L'abb̩ Boniface and le p̬re Philippe
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Shows Abbot Boniface confronting a drenched Father Philip after the White Lady has pitched him into the mill-stream (Monastery, ch. 7).

image.title1: Melrose Cross: The Earl of Murray and Abbot of St. Mary's = Croix de Melrose: Le comte de Murray and l'abb̩ de Ste. Marie
image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Staines after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts the Earl of Murray and Abbot of Kennaquhair meeting beneath Melrose Cross, Melrose, Scottish Borders. The Earl is demanding that the Abbot hand over Sir Piercie Shafton (Monastery, ch. 37). As Scott himself acknowledged in the 'Magnum Opus' edition of The Monastery (1830), the fictional town and abbey of Kennaquhair in the novel were based on the Scottish Border town of Melrose.

image.title1: Sir Piercie Shafton and Halbert Glendinning = Le chevalier Piercie Shafton and Halbert Glendinning
image.title2: Steel engraving by W. Floyd after a drawing by G. Arnald of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Arnald, George
image.description: Depicts the duel between Sir Piercie Shafton and Halbert Glendinning (Monastery, ch. 21).

image.title1: Tower of Glendearg = Tour de Glendearg
image.title2: Steel engraving by G. Presbury after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts the Abbot of Kennaqhair with his attendants, accompanied by Sir Piercie Shafton, approaching Glendearg Tower (Monastery, ch. 15). Glendearg Tower is reputedly based on Hillslap Tower, near Galashiels, which is now sometimes known as Glendearg Tower in homage to Scott.

image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Staines after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts Father Eustace approaching the Abbey of Kennaquhair which Scott based on Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders (Monastery, ch. 9).

image.title1: Monastery: Abbey of St. Mary Kirkaldy
image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by Edward Finden of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Finden, Edward Francis
image.description: Depicts the Abbey of Kennaquhair (based on Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders) with the gates thrown open in preparation for a procession (Monastery, ch. 37). Despite the caption, the engraving is an artist's impression of Melrose Abbey prior to its ruin. It was presumably engraved by Finden after his own design.

image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by E. Finden of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Finden, Edward Francis
image.description: Vignette depiction of Glendearg Tower, based on Hillslap Tower, near Galashiels, Scottish Borders, as described in The Monastery, ch. 2.

image.title2: Steel engraving by W. Finden after a drawing by D. Roberts of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts Melrose Cross with a crowded marketplace and the ruins of Melrose Abbey in the background. Melrose, Scottish Borders is depicted as Kennaquhair in Scott's novel The Monastery (and its sequel The Abbot).

image.title1: [Steel vignette engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by Richard Westall of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery]
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Shows the White Lady reclaiming her Bible from Father Philip and pitching him into the mill-stream (Monastery, vol. I, ch. VI). Illustrates the lines: ' Landed--landed! the black book hath won. | Else had you seen Berwick with morning sun! | Sain ye, and save ye, and blithe mot ye be, | For seldom they land that go swimming with me.'

image.title1: The Lady of Avenel and her Daughter in the Dwelling of Dame Elspeth
image.title2: Steel engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Lady Avenel with her daughter Mary on her lap and Martin and Tib Tacket in the background (Monastery, ch. 3).

image.title1: Halbert Glendinning's First Invocation of the White Maid of Avenel
image.title2: Steel engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Halbert Glendinning with sword in hand after summoning the ghostly White Lady of Avenel (Monastery, ch. 12).

image.title1: The Spirit of Avenel Appearing to Halbert the Night Previous to his Duel with Sir Piercie Shafton
image.title2: Steel engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts the White Lady, supernatural protectress of the House of Avenel, appearing to a startled Halbert Glendinning (Monastery, ch. 20).

image.title1: Warden Reproving Julian Avenel for his Injustice to Catherine
image.title2: Steel engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Julian Avenel being reproached by the Protestant preacher, Henry Warden, for mistreating his mistress, Catherine (Monastery, ch. 25).

image.title1: Mysie Happer's Visit to Sir Piercie Shafton
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Mysie Happer visiting the imprisoned Sir Piercie Shafton (Monastery, ch. 28).

image.title1: Catherine Discovered by Halbert Lamenting over the Body of Julian Avenel
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Julian Avenel's mistress Catherine with her baby in her arms grieving over Avenel's corpse and Halbert Glendinning looking on (Monastery, ch. 36)

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by W. Westall of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Monastery
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts the ruins of a bridge over the river Tweed, near Melrose, Scottish Borders, featured in The Monastery, ch. 5. The bridge no longer exists. Westall's design is based on an original sketch by James Skene

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by R. R. Reinagle of a scene relating from Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Reinagle, Ramsay Richard
image.description: Depicts Bothwell Castle in Lanarkshire, featured in Old Mortality, ch. 37.

image.title2: Steel engraving by W. Finden after a drawing by D. Roberts of a scene relating to Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts Bothwell Bridge in Lanarkshire, scene of the battle on June 22, 1679, between Covenanters and government forces, portrayed in Old Mortality, ch. 31-32.

image.title2: Steel engraving by H. Cook after a drawing by G. Cattermole of a character from Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Three quarter portrait of Edith Bellenden, heroine of Old Mortality, attending the Festival of the Popinjay (Old Mortality, ch. 2). Illustrates the line: 'Her [i.e. Lady Margaret Bellenden's] grand-daughter, and only earthly care, the fair-haired Edith, [...] appeared beside her aged relative like Spring placed close to Winter.'

image.title1: [Steel engraving by C. Rolls after a drawing by Henry James Richter of a scene from Scott's novel Old Mortality]
image.creator: Richter, Henry James
image.description: Depicts John Balfour of Burley showing Henry Morton the notches on his sword (Old Mortality, ch. 43). Originally commissioned as an illustration to the Waverley Novels, but unpublished, this engraving was subsequently used to illustrate the tale 'The Novice' in W. H. Harrison's Christmas Tales (1833).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by W. Daniell of a scene relating to Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Daniell, William
image.description: Depicts Dunnottar Castle, near Stonehaven, Aberdeenshire, where Covenanter prisoners were held following the battle of Bothwell Bridge (Old Mortality, introd.).

image.title1: [Steel engraving by W. H. Lizars after a drawing by William Allan of a scene from Scott's novel Old Mortality]
image.creator: Allan, William
image.description: Vignette depiction of Old Mortality being greeted by Peter Pattieson as he repairs inscriptions on the tombs of Covenanters (Old Mortality, ch. 1). Illustrates the text: 'He considered himself as fulfilling a sacred duty, while renewing to the eyes of posterity the decaying emblems of the zeal and sufferings of their forefathers.' (Old Mortality, ch. 1)

image.title1: A Gallery in Craignethan Castle: Tillietudlem
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene from Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts Jenny Dennison, Edith Bellenden's maid, bribing the guard Tam Halliday to let her mistress see Henry Morton (Old Mortality, ch. 10). The scene is set in a gallery of Craignethan Castle, Lanarkshire, reputedly portrayed in Old Mortality as Tillietudlem.

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Goodyear after a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene from Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts the great hall of Tillietudlem, with Edith and Lady Bellenden looking on as Major Bellenden asks Claverhouse to spare Morton's life (Old Mortality, ch. 12). The engraving is based on the great hall of Craignethan Castle, the reputed model for Scott's Tillietudlem.

image.title1: Old Mortality: Burley's Concealment in the Hay Loft at Milnwood
image.title2: Steel engraving by F. Engleheart after a drawing by W. Allan of characters from Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Allan, William
image.description: Shows John Balfour of Burley being hidden in the hayloft at Milnwood by Henry Morton (Old Mortality, ch. 5).

image.title1: 'Whiles - at brose-time' = 'Quelquefois - a l'heure des repas'
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Cuddie Headrigg taking leave of Jenny Dennison (Old Mortality, ch. 28).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by P. Dewint of a scene relating from Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Vignette depiction of Craignethan Castle, Lanarkshire, the reputed model for Tillietudlem Castle in Scott's Old Mortality.

image.title1: Old Mortality: King Charles the Second Saluting Lady Bellenden
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Romney after a drawing by C. R. Leslie of a scene from Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Depicts King Charles II kissing Lady Bellenden on the cheek (Old Mortality, ch. 2).

image.title2: Steel engraving by Charles Heath after a drawing by P. de Wint of a scene relating to Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: A vignette depiction of the government and Covenanting armies meeting at the Battle of Bothwell Bridge, June 22, 1679. The battle is depicted in Old Mortality, ch. 31-32

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. B. Allen after a drawing by W. Harvey of a scene relating to Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Harvey, William
image.description: Depicts the government and Covenanting armies meeting at the Battle of Bothwell Bridge, June 22, 1679. The battle is depicted in Old Mortality, ch. 31-32.

image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Wallis after a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene relating to Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts Cuddie Headrigg and companions preparing to assault Tillietudlem Castle, based on Craignethan Castle, Lanarkshire (Old Mortality, ch. 25).

image.title1: Festival of the Popinjay = F̻te du Papegai
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Carter after a drawing by R. B. Davis of a scene from Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Davis, Richard Barrett
image.description: Depicts a crowd watching the Festival of the Popinjay (Old Mortality, ch. 2).

image.title1: Castle of Tillietudlem = Ch̢teau de Tillietudlem
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. H. Kernot after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts Lord Evandale arriving at Tillietudlem Castle (based on Craignethan Castle, Lanarkshire) after the Battle of Loudon Hill (Old Mortality, ch. 24).

image.title2: Steel engraving by H. Robinson after a drawing by L. Sharpe of a character from Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Sharpe, Louisa
image.description: Three quarter portrait of Edith Bellenden, heroine of Scott's Old Mortality, wearing a shawl.

image.title1: Peveril of the Peak: The Meeting of Peveril and Alice Interrupted by Bridgenorth
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Mitchell after a drawing by T. M. Wright of a scene from Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Wright, Thomas M.
image.description: Depicts Major Bridgenorth finding his daughter Alice and Julian Peveril together (Peveril of the Peak, ch. 13).

image.title1: Peveril of the Peak: Sir Geoffrey Peveril Opposing Bridgenorth in his Pursuit of the Countess of Derby
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Rolls after a drawing by A. Cooper of a scene from Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Cooper, Abraham
image.description: Depicts Sir Geoffrey Peveril on a black horse seizing Bridgenorth by the collar (Peveril of the Peak, ch. 7).

image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by A. Naysmith of a scene relating to Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Nasmyth, Alexander (b.1758, d.1840)
image.description: Depicts Holm-Peel or Peel Castle, Isle of Man, as featured in Peveril of the Peak, ch. 15. Peel Castle or Holm-Peel figures prominently in Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak as the residence of the Countess of Derby.

image.title1: The Countess of Derby Quitting Peveril Castle = D̩part de la Comtesse du Ch̢teau de Peveril
image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Staines after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts the Countess of Derby riding away from Peveril Castle, Castleton, Derbyshire, with an armed escort (Peveril of the Peak, ch. 8).

image.title1: Trial of the Peverils: Oates Giving Evidence = Jugement des Peverils: Oates allant rendre t̩moignage
image.title2: Steel engraving by G. Presbury from a drawing by S. A. Hart of a scene from Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Hart, Solomon Alexander
image.description: Depicts Titus Oates giving evidence at the trial of Sir Geoffrey and Julian Peveril (Peveril of the Peak, ch. 41).

image.title1: Peveril and Chiffinch = Peveril et Chiffinch
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Julian Peveril threatening Chiffinch with death unless he returns a stolen package (Peveril of the Peak, ch. 27).

image.title1: Holm Peel Castle: Fenella and Julian Peveril = Ch̢teau de Holm Peel: Fenella et Julian Peveril
image.title2: Steel engraving by F. W. Topham of a scene from Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Topham, Francis William
image.description: Depicts Peel Castle, Isle of Man, with Peveril and Fenella slipping away in a boat (Peveril of the Peak, ch. 19). The image was both painted and engraved by F. W. Topham.

image.title1: The Pirate: The Shipwreck of Cleveland
image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Baker after a drawing by J. M. Wright of a scene from Scott's novel The Pirate
image.creator: Wright, John Massey
image.description: Depicts Clement Cleveland being revived by Mordaunt, Norna of Fitful Head, and Bryce Snailsfoot after being shipwrecked (Pirate, ch. 7).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by A. Naysmith of a scene from Scott's novel The Pirate
image.creator: Nasmyth, Alexander (b.1758, d.1840)
image.description: Vignette depiction of the house at Burgh-Westra, dwelling of Magnus Troil, as described in The Pirate, ch. 12.

image.title2: Steel vignette engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by A. Naysmith of a scene relating to Scott's novel The Pirate
image.creator: Nasmyth, Alexander (b.1758, d.1840)
image.description: Vignette depiction of Sumburgh Head, Shetland, as described in The Pirate, ch. 1.

image.title1: Sumburgh Head from Jarlshof: Shipwreck of Cleveland = Rocher de Sumburgh vu de Jarlshoff: Naufrage de Cleveland
image.title2: Steel engraving by G. Presbury from a drawing by A. Chisolm of a scene from Scott's novel The Pirate
image.creator: Chisholm, Alexander
image.description: Depicts Sumburgh Head, Shetland, with Cleveland being rescued from the sea by Mordaunt and Norna of Fitful Head (The Pirate, ch. 7).

image.title1: 'She demanded the wounded man of me' = 'Elle me demanda le bless̩'
image.title2: Steel engraving by P. Lightfoot after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel The Pirate
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts Norna of Fitful Head demanding that Cleveland hand over the wounded Mordaunt (The Pirate, ch. 31).

image.title1: Norna dispatching the provisions = Norna envoyant les provisions
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel The Pirate
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Norna of Fitful Head throwing Magnus Troil's meal into the ocean (The Pirate, ch. 29).

image.title2: Steel engraving by H. T. Ryall after a drawing by W. Etty of a character from Scott's novel The Pirate
image.creator: Etty, William
image.description: Portrait of Minna Troil contemplating a nocturnal seascape. Illustrates the line: 'The ocean, in all its varied forms of sublimity and terror--the tremendous cliffs that resound to the ceaseless roar of the billows, and the clang of the sea-fowl, had for Minna a charm in almost every state in which the changing seasons exhibited them.' (The Pirate, ch. 3)

image.title1: 'Close in, lads, he is not half so mad now.' = 'Courons dessus, camarades, il n'est pas maintenant si furieux.'
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. C. Bentley after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel The Pirate
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts armed men in boats attempting to kill a beached whale (The Pirate, ch. 17).

image.title1: Louis of France and the Count de Crevecoeur = Louis de France et le Comte de Crevecoeur
image.title2: Steel engraving by G. Presbury after a drawing by T. Allom of a scene from Scott's novel Quentin Durward
image.creator: Allom, Thomas
image.description: Depicts the Duke of Burgundy's envoy, the Count de Crevecoeur, throwing down a gauntlet to challenge King Louis XI of France (Quentin Durward, ch. 8).

image.title1: Quentin Durward: Quentin Presenting to the Countess of Croye the Letter of her Aunt
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Rolls after a drawing by W. Brockedon of a scene from Scott's novel Quentin Durward
image.creator: Brockedon, William
image.description: Depicts Quentin on horseback presenting a letter to Isabelle de Croye at the end of his lance (Quentin Durward, ch. 36).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by A. Naysmith of a scene relating to Scott's novel Quentin Durward
image.creator: Nasmyth, Alexander (b.1758, d.1840)
image.description: Vignette depiction of the castle of Plessis-les-Tours, Touraine, France, as described in Quentin Durward, ch. 3.

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by A. Naysmith of a scene relating to Scott's novel Quentin Durward
image.creator: Nasmyth, Alexander (b.1758, d.1840)
image.description: Vignette depiction of Peronne Castle, Somme, France, as depicted in Quentin Durward, ch. 26.

image.title1: Quentin Durward: Quentin Rescuing Isabelle at the Sack of Schonwaldt
image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Baker after a drawing by T. M. Wright of a scene from Scott's novel Quentin Durward
image.creator: Wright, Thomas M.
image.description: Depicts Quentin Durward helping the kneeling Isabelle de Croye to her feet (Quentin Durward, ch. 21).

image.title1: Cardinal Balue at the Boar Hunt = Le Cardinal Balue a la chasse au sanglier
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Quentin Durward
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Cardinal Balue having lost control of his horse during a boar hunt (Quentin Durward, ch. 9).

image.title1: Murder of the Bishop of Liege = Assassinat de l'̩v̻que de Li̬ge
image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Portbury after a drawing by J. Franklin of a scene from Scott's novel Quentin Durward
image.creator: Franklin, John
image.description: Depicts the murder of the Bishop of Liege at the hands of William De la Marck (Quentin Durward, ch. 22).

image.title1: Prince Charles Edward taking leave of his adherents = Le Prince Charles Edouard prenant cong̩ de ses adh̩rents
image.title2: Steel engraving by G. Presbury after a drawing by F. W. Topham of a scene from Scott's novel Redgauntlet
image.creator: Topham, Francis William
image.description: Depicts Charles Edward ('Bonnie Prince Charlie') taking leave of his followers on the beach of Lochnanach (Redgauntlet, ch. 23).

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Thomson after a drawing by E. T. Parris of a character from Scott's novel Redgauntlet
image.creator: Parris, Edmund Thomas
image.description: Depicts Lilias Redgauntlet in her green mantle, warning Darsie Latimer of danger (Redgauntlet, Letter 12). Illustrates the text: 'When she entered (wonder if thou will) she wore a green mantle such as thou hast described as the garb of thy fair client. There was an alteration on her brow the instant she recognized me.' (Redgauntlet, Letter 12)

image.title1: Dougal Mac Callum and Hutcheon = Dougal Mac Callum and Hutcheon
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Redgauntlet
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts MacCallum and Hutcheon frightened by an apparition on Sir Robert Regauntlet's coffin (Redgauntlet, letter 11). In this illustration to 'Wandering Willie's Tale', Cruickshank interprets the demonic apparition on Sir Robert Redgauntlet's coffin as a trick of the light involving Sir Robert's pet monkey

image.title1: Salmon Hunting = La chasse au saumon
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. C. Bentley after a drawing by J. Franklin of a scene from Scott's novel Redgauntlet
image.creator: Franklin, John
image.description: Shows two figures on horseback fishing with spears in the Solway Firth, a practice described in Redgauntlet, letter 4.

image.title1: Rob Roy: Francis Osbaldistone and Diana Vernon in the Library
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by C. R. Leslie of a scene from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Shows Diana Vernon reading Francis Osbaldistone's translation of Ariosto (Rob Roy, ch. 16).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by P. De Wint of a scene relating to Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Vignette depicting Inversnaid Fort, Stirlingshire, as featured in Rob Roy, ch. 32.

image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Staines after a drawing by W. Harvey of a scene from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Harvey, William
