image.description: Depicts Francis Osbaldistone's first meeting with Diana Vernon during a fox hunt at Osbaldistone Hall (Rob Roy, ch. 5).

image.title1: F. Osbaldistone at Squire Inglewood's = F. Osbaldistone chez l'Ecuyer Inglewood
image.title2: Engraving by G. Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Francis Osbaldistone interrupting Squire Inglewood, his clerk Jobson, and the spy Morris (Rob Roy, ch. 8).

image.title2: Steel engraving by H. T. Ryall after a drawing by W. Boxall of a character from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Boxall, William
image.description: Depicts Diana Vernon speaking to Francis Osbaldistone in the library at Osbaldistone Hall (Rob Roy, ch. 10). Illustrates the text: 'Her finger immediately touched her dimpled chin, with an arch look of prohibition.'

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by J. M. Wright of a scene from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Wright, John Massey
image.description: Depicts Rob Roy interrupting the duel between Francis Osbaldistone and Rashleigh Osbaldistone (Rob Roy, ch. 25).

image.title1: Fray at Jeannie Mac Alpine's = Fray chez Jeanne Mac Alpine
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Francis Osbaldistone and Baillie Nicol Jarvie fighting with Highlanders at Jeannie MacAlpine's inn (Rob Roy, ch. 28).

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Goodyear after a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts a sermon being delivered in the crypt of Glasgow Cathedral with Rob Roy hiding behind a pillar (Rob Roy, ch. 20).

image.title1: The Pass of Aberfoil: 'Stand!' = Le d̩fil̩ d'Aberfoil: 'Arr̻tez!'
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Redaway after a drawing by C. Bentley of a scene from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Bentley, Charles
image.description: Depicts Helen Macgregor's men ambushing a party of redcoats in the Pass of Aberfoyle, Stirling (Rob Roy, ch. 30).

image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Sands after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts Francis Osbaldistone and Baillie Nicol Jarvie crossing Loch Lomond while Rob Roy looks on from a promontory (Rob Roy, ch. 36).

image.title1: Braes of Balquhidder = Coteaux de Balquhidder
image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Sands after a drawing by H. Melville of a scene from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Melville, Henry
image.description: Depicts the single combat between Rob Roy and Alaster Stewart in the Braes of Balquhidder, Stirling (Rob Roy, introd.).

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by G. F. Robson of a scene relating to Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Robson, George Fennel
image.description: Depicts Ben Lomond, Stirlingshire, and surrounding landscape, as described by Francis Osbaldistone in Rob Roy, ch. 36.

image.title2: Steel engraving by E. Finden after a drawing by G. F. Robson of a scene relating to Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Robson, George Fennel
image.description: Depicts Loch Ard, Stirlingshire, as described by Francis Osbaldistone in Rob Roy, ch. 30.

image.title1: Rob Roy: 'She pressed my hand,' andc.
image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by J. M. Wright of a scene from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Wright, John Massey
image.description: Depicts Diana Vernon bidding farewell to Francis Osbaldistone (Rob Roy, ch. 33). Illustrates the text: 'She pressed my hand, while the tear that trembled in her eye found its way to my cheek instead of her own. It was a moment never to be forgotten--inexpressibly bitter, yet mixed with a sensation of pleasure so deeply soothing and affecting, as at once to unlock all the flood-gates of the heart.'

image.title2: Steel engraving by J. Goodyear after a drawing by H. Corbould of a scene from Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Corbould, Henry
image.description: Depicts Baillie Nicol Jarvie being brought before Helen Macgregor (Rob Roy, ch 31).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by G. Cattermole of a scene from Scott's poem Rokeby
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts two characters talking, possibly Oswald Wycliffe and Bertram Risingham.

image.title2: Steel engraving by R. Staines after a drawing by F. W. Topham of a scene from Scott's novel Saint Ronan's Well
image.creator: Topham, Francis William
image.description: Shows Clara Mowbray meeting Francis Tyrrel in the glen of Innerleithen, Scottish Borders (St. Ronan's Well, ch. 9).

image.title1: Death of Miss Mowbray = Mort de Mademoiselle Mowbray
image.title2: Steel engraving by P. Lightfoot after a drawing by J. Franklin of a scene from Scott's novel Saint Ronan's Well
image.creator: Franklin, John
image.description: Depicts Clara Mowbray on her death-bed with Tyrrel kneeling at her side (St. Ronan's Well, ch. 38).

image.title1: Meg Dods and Captain Mac Turk = Meg Dods et le Capitaine Mac Turk
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel Saint Ronan's Well
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Meg Dods attacking Captain Mac Turk with a broom (St. Ronan's Well, ch. 12).

image.title1: [Steel engraving by E. Radclyffe after a drawing by A. Soloman of a scene from Scott's novel Saint Ronan's Well]
image.creator: Solomon, Abraham
image.description: Shows Francis Tyrrel saving Clara Mowbray from the attentions of a drunken countryman (St. Ronan's Well, ch. 25). Illustrates the text: 'They had accomplished their purpose greatly to their satisfaction, and were hying home after sunset, when they were encountered by a country fellow [...] who [...] saw not the nobility of blood through her disguise, and accosted the daughter of a hundred sires as he would have done a ewe-milker. Miss Mowbray remonstrated--her companion screamed--up came cousin Francis with a fowling-piece on his shoulder, and soon put the sylvan to flight.'

image.title1: [Steel engraving by F. F. Walker after a drawing by A. Soloman of a scene from Scott's novel St. Ronan's Well]
image.creator: Solomon, Abraham
image.description: Depicts Clara Mowbray rejecting the advances of Valentine Bulmer (St. Ronan's Well, ch. 24). Illustrates the text: '"No nearer--no nearer," she exclaimed, "if you would have me look upon you and live!" Lord Etherington remained standing, as if uncertain whether to advance or retreat, while with incredible rapidity she poured out her hurried entreaties that he would begone.'

image.title1: [Steel engraving by R. Graves after a design by F. Stone of a scene from Scott's story The Surgeon's Daughter]
image.creator: Stone, Frank
image.description: Depicts Menie Gray stepping into the garden of Madame de Montreville's house (Surgeon's Daughter, ch. 11). Illustrates the text: '"It may be out of it, then, madam," answered Miss Gray [...]. As she spoke this she stepped through a lattice-door into the garden [...].'

image.title1: [Steel engraving by E. Radclyffe after a drawing by W. L. Windus of a scene from Scott's story The Surgeon's Daughter]
image.creator: Windus, William Lindsay
image.description: Depicts Richard Middlemas pleading with his father, and his mother Zilia fainting (Surgeon's Daughter, ch. 9). Illustrates the text: 'Richard Middlemas sunk on one knee [...]. "O, my more than father," he said, "how much greater a debt do I owe to you than to the unnatural parents, who [...] deserted me through their cruelty!" Zilia, as she heard these cutting words, flung back her veil, raising it on both hands till it floated behind her like a mist, and then giving a faint groan, sunk down in a swoon.'

image.title1: Zilia de Mon̤ada and her Father = Z̩lie de Mon̤ade and son p̬re
image.title2: Steel engraving by G. Presbury after a drawing by F. W. Topham of a scene from Scott's story The Surgeon's Daughter
image.creator: Topham, Francis William
image.description: Depicts Matthias de Mon̤ada forcing his daughter Zilia to return home, and Zilia consigning her child Richard to Dr Gideon Gray's care (The Surgeon's Daughter, ch. 1).

image.title1: The Middlemas Wives and Gideon Gray = Les femmes de Middlemas and Gideon Gray
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's story The Surgeon's Daughter
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Depicts Dr Gideon Gray and a group of Middlemas women who are competing for the right to be Zilia de Moncada's nurse (The Surgeon's Daughter, ch. 1).

image.title1: Sir Kenneth and the Baron of Gilsland = Le Chevalier Kenneth et le Baron de Gilsland
image.title2: Steel engraving by F. W. Topham of a scene from Scott's novel The Talisman
image.creator: Topham, Francis William
image.description: Shows Sir Kenneth and De Vaux at King Richard's sickbed with Saladin disguised as a doctor (Talisman, ch. 8). The image was both painted and engraved by F. W. Topham.

image.title1: Sir Kenneth and the Dwarfs of the Chapel = Le Chevalier Kenneth et les Nains de la Chapelle
image.title2: Engraving by George Cruikshank of a scene from Scott's novel The Talisman
image.creator: Cruikshank, George
image.description: Shows Sir Kenneth speaking with the two dwarfs in the chapel interior (Talisman, ch. 5).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by P. De Wint of a scene relating to Scott's novel Waverley
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Vignette depiction of Tully-Veolan Castle, home of the Bradwardines in Waverley (reputedly based on Craighall Castle, Perthshire).

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by P. De Wint of a scene relating to Scott's novel Waverley
image.creator: De Wint, Peter
image.description: Vignette depiction of Holyrood Palace, Edinburgh, scene of Charles Edward Stuart's court in Waverley.

image.title1: [Steel engraving by C. Heath after a drawing by T. Stothard of a scene from Scott's novel Waverley]
image.creator: Stothard, Thomas
image.description: Depicts David Gellatley privately signalling to Waverley that he has a message for him (Waverley, ch. 28).

This picture was originally commissioned as an illustration to Waverley, ch. 37 but was unpublished. Here it is used to illustrate 'The Highland Cottage', a tale in the manner of Scott by John Carne (1789-1844).

image.creator: Chisholm, Alexander

image.title1: King Charles and Sir Henry Lee
image.title2: Steel engraving by G. Presbury after a drawing by J. Franklin of a scene from Scott's novel Woodstock
image.creator: Franklin, John
image.description: Depicts King Charles II kneeling to receive Sir Henry Lee's blessing (Woodstock, ch. 38).

image.title2: Steel engraving by H. Robinson from a drawing by A. E. Chalon of a character from Scott's novel Woodstock
image.creator: Chalon, Alfred Edward
image.description: Depicts Alice Lee reading a prayer book, as glimpsed by Everard in Woodstock, ch. 13. Illustrates the text: 'The beautiful and high-born young lady had now approached as near as possible to the brown stuff dress of an ordinary village maiden; but what she had lost in gaiety of appearance, she had gained, as it seemed, in dignity.'

image.title1: George Hamilton-Gordon, Earl of Aberdeen, K. T.-F. A. S. andc andc.
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of George Hamilton Gordon, Earl of Aberdeen, by T. Woolnoth after a painting by A. Wivell
image.creator: Wivell, Abraham
image.description: Portrait of the British statesman George Hamilton Gordon, Earl of Aberdeen (1784-1860). The Conservative diplomat and statesman George Hamilton-Gordon, 4th Earl of Aberdeen, served successively as British Ambassador to Austria (1813-14), Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster (1828), Foreign Secretary (1828-30 and 1841-46), Secretary of State for War and the Colonies (1834-35), and Prime Minister (1852-55). Scott first met him as a guest of Lord Abercorn in 1807, judging him 'a very accomplishd young man who promises to make a figure' (letter to Lady Scott, 30 March 1807). Lord Aberdeen subsequently secured a diplomatic position for Scott's son Charles (1830) and furnished his son Walter with a letter of introduction to the British Ambassador to France. The original portrait by Wivell was painted in the mid-1820s.

image.title1: Addison: From a Picture Copied by J. Thurston in the Possession of the Publisher
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Joseph Addison by J. Thomson after J. Thurston after G. Kneller.
image.creator: Kneller, Godfrey (b.1646, d.1723)
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English essayist and poet Joseph Addison (1672-1719). In June 1819, the actor Daniel Terry acquired for Scott a collection of antiquarian material for Abbotsford, including a pair of velvet slippers and a wig-case belonging to the English essayist and poet Joseph Addison. Scott replied: 'If Addison's slippers and wig-box will serve you in your professional dress, pray accept them from me, for my curiosity leads chiefly to articles of armour; and Addison, I know not why, is personally no such favourite of mine as Sir Roger de Coverley should make him' (letter of 15 June 1819). (Sir Roger de Coverley was a caricatural old country gentlemen created by Addison in The Spectator.) Despite his expressed distaste for Addison, Scott frequently quoted his works, particularly the tragedy Cato which he saw performed in Edinburgh in 1812, greatly admiring J. P. Kemble in the title role. The original portrait was painted by Sir Godfrey Kneller (1646-1723) between 1703 and 1712. The engraving was taken from a copy by John Thurston (1744-1822) made ca. 1820.

image.title1: Daguesseau: From an Original Picture by Mignard in the Possession of the Countess Segur
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Henri Fran̤ois d'Aguesseau by J. Mollison after a painting by Mignard
image.creator: Mignard, Pierre
image.description: Engraved portrait of the French jurist and statesman H. Fr. d'Aguesseau (1668-1751).

image.description: Reply by Scott to a letter from Maria Edgeworth in which she had thanked him for sending her copies of his recently published works.

image.title1: [Letter of Walter Scott to Adam Ferguson, 20 December 1826]

image.creator: Scott, Walter, Sir

image.title1: [Holograph letter of George Chalmers to David Laing, 4 February 1824]

image.creator: Jobard, Jean-Baptiste-Ambroise-Marcellin
image.description: Depicts figures in the costumes of the Norman knight Maurice de Bracy and of King John of England at a masked ball held in Brussels, 5 February, 1823.

image.description: Depicts the insignia of Roderick Dhu, a character in Scott's poem The Lady of the Lake.

image.title2: Original pencil drawing by James Skene of the Old Tolbooth in Edinburgh
image.creator: Skene, James
image.description: Original pencil drawing by James Skene depicting the Old Tolbooth, the prison known as the "Heart of Midlothian" that stood on Edinburgh's High Street until 1817. This drawing was subsequently etched for Skene's A Series of Sketches of the Existing Localities of the Waverley Novels (Edinburgh: Robert Cadell, 1829).

image.title1: [First page of a transcript by Scott of the ballad Captain Ward and the Rainbow]
image.creator: Scott, Walter, Sir

image.title2: Original coloured pencil drawing by James Skene of the back stairs, Parliament House, Edinburgh
image.creator: Skene, James
image.description: Handcoloured pencil sketch of Parliament House in Edinburgh, seat of the Faculty of Advocates, as featured in Scott's novel Redgauntlet. This drawing was subsequently etched for Skene's A Series of Sketches of the Existing Localities of the Waverley Novels (Edinburgh: Robert Cadell, 1829).

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by J. Horsburgh after a painting by H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott engraved by John Horsburgh after a portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn painted in 1808. Scott sat for the original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn in spring 1808. Commissioned by Archibald Constable, it was completed in the same year. It is now in the possession of the Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry at Bowhill. The engraving by Horsburgh was published in the 2nd edition of J. G. Lockhart's Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. (1839) but previously issued separately in 1837.

image.title1: [Original heraldic watercolour illustrating Scott's poem Rokeby]
image.creator: Willement, Thomas
image.description: Depicts an array of weapons from the English Civil War, the historical backdrop to Scott's poem Rokeby.

image.creator: Edouart, Augustin Amant Constant Fid̬le
image.description: Depicts Scott carrying a walking stick and wearing a top hat.

image.title1: Sir Walter Scott in his Study (Castle Street, Edinburgh)
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by Robert Charles Bell after a painting by J. Watson Gordon
image.creator: Gordon, John Watson, Sir (b.1788, d.1864)
image.description: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott seated at his desk at 39 North Castle Street, Edinburgh, with his cat Hinse of Hinsefeldt and dog Maida. The original portrait of Sir Walter Scott by John Watson Gordon is a posthumous likeness dating from the 1840s or 1850s. There are numerous inaccuracies and anachronisms. Scott's study at 39 North Castle Street (his Edinburgh home from 1801 to 1826) was lined with bookshelves and featured a portrait of John Graham of Claverhouse where Gordon has placed his own portrait of Scott's mother. The painting now belongs to the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. This engraving by Robert Charles Bell was published as the frontispiece to Portrait of Sir Walter Scott and Five Engravings in Illustration of The Pirate (Edinburgh: [Royal Association for the Promotion of the Fine Arts in Scotland, 1871]).

image.title1: [Oil painting of Melrose Abbey after D. Roberts]
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders. The description of a moonlit Melrose Abbey in Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (canto II, stanza 1), and its further depiction in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820), led to it becoming a popular destination for sightseers. The original painting by Roberts was exhibited at the Society of British Artists in 1824. Cf. Guiterman, H. and Llewellyn, B. (eds). David Roberts (Oxford: Phaidon Press, 1986).

image.creator: Allan, William
image.description: Depicts the death of the Hanoverian Colonel Gardiner at the hands of the Jacobites in the Battle of Prestonpans (featured in Waverley, ch. 47). The original painting was exhibited in 1842.

image.title1: [Oil portrait of Walter Scott after H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Depicts Scott at the age of 52 in the typical attire of a country gentleman of his time. A copy of a portrait painted by Sir Henry Raeburn in 1823 which Corson bought at Dowell's, 29 October 1938. It had previously been part of the collection of Dr Alexander Darling.

image.title2: Half-tone reproduction of a photograph by James White of Helen Walker's grave
image.creator: White, James
image.description: Reproduced photograph of the grave of Helen Walker in Irongray, Wigtownshire. Walker was the prototype for Jeanie Deans in Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian.

image.title1: Cathedral and Bishop's Palace of Kirkwall
image.title2: Original pencil drawing by James Skene of Kirkwall Cathedral and the Bishop's Palace
image.creator: Skene, James
image.description: Original pencil drawing of St Magnus Cathedral and the Bishop's Palace in Kirkwall, Orkney, both described in The Pirate, ch. 31. This drawing was subsequently etched for Skene's A Series of Sketches of the Existing Localities of the Waverley Novels (Edinburgh: Robert Cadell, 1829).

image.title2: Lithograph by J. Fergusson after a drawing by J. Dobbin of Dryburgh Abbey
image.creator: Dobbin, John
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey in Berwickshire, burial place of Sir Walter Scott.

image.title2: Original pencil drawing by James Skene of the Guard House, Edinburgh
image.creator: Skene, James
image.description: Original pencil drawing by James Skene depicting the headquarters of the City Guard in Edinburgh's High Street as mentioned in chapter 5 of Scott's novel The Heart of Mid-Lothian. This drawing was subsequently etched for Skene's A Series of Sketches of the Existing Localities of the Waverley Novels (Edinburgh: Robert Cadell, 1829). It also shows the Tron Kirk and a group of buildings, including the Black Turnpike, demolished to permit the building of the South Bridge in 1786.

image.title1: [Autograph manuscript by Walter Scott of an epilogue to a play, enclosed in a letter to David Laing, 22 October 1824]
image.creator: Scott, Walter, Sir
image.description: Epilogue for an unperformed play on the subject of Mary Queen of Scots.

image.title2: Coloured lithograph by W. Simpson after a drawing by D. Roberts of Kelso Abbey
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts the ruined Abbey of Kelso, Scottish Borders, as described in Scott's Essay on Border Antiquities (1814). Scott stayed in Kelso with his Aunt Janet after leaving school in 1783 and again from 1784-1785 when illness forced him to suspend his studies at Edinburgh University.

image.title1: His Majesty King George the IV, Born August 12 1762
image.title2: Engraving of a portrait of King George IV after Thomas Phillips
image.creator: Phillips, Thomas
image.description: Engraved portrait of George IV, King of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland from 1820 to 1830. George IV, both as Prince Regent and King, bestowed a number of favours upon Sir Walter Scott. In 1813 he offered Scott the post of Poet Laureate (which Scott refused in favour of Robert Southey). In 1815 he twice invited Scott to dine with him and granted him free access to the Regent's Library, where Scott consulted papers on the Jacobite Rebellions of 1715 and 1745-46. In 1818 Scott became the first man to be knighted under George IV and the first ever to be knighted in recognition of literary merit. When the new king commissioned Sir Thomas Lawrence to paint the most distinguished men of the age for the great gallery at Windsor Castle, he desired that Scott be foremost amongst the men of science and letters. For his part, Scott played a leading role in organizing the visit of King George IV to Edinburgh in 1822, the first visit of a Hanoverian monarch to Scotland. The 'Magnum Opus' edition of the Waverley Novels is dedicated to the King. This uncredited print is made from a portrait by Thomas Phillips and closely resembles an engraving by Luigi Schiavonetti in the National Portrait Gallery.

image.title2: Coloured photograph of a watercolour by W. Allan of the dining room at Abbotsford
image.creator: Allan, William
image.description: Depicts the dining room of Sir Walter Scott's home of Abbotsford, Scottish Borders, on the day of the writer's death, 21 September 1832. Sir William Allan had been invited by Scott's son-in-law and future biographer J. G. Lockhart to make images of the interior apartments of Abbotsford as occupied by Scott.

image.creator: Scott, Walter, Sir
image.description: This sketch of Hermitage Castle, Scottish Borders, was copied from an original pencil drawing by Sir Walter Scott. The sixteenth-century castle of Hermitage was a favourite of Scott's and is described in his Essay on Border Antiquities (1814). While gathering ballads in Liddesdale Scott, carried out excavations at the Hermitage and made a sketch of the castle. A print derived from Scott's sketch was published in Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-1804), and the backdrop of Sir Henry Raeburn's 1808 portrait of Scott is also based on it.

image.title1: Sir Walter Scott and his Literary Friends at Abbotsford
image.title2: Engraving by J. Faed after T. Faed of Walter Scott and friends at Abbotsford
image.creator: Faed, Thomas
image.description: Depicts the dining room at Scott's home of Abbotsford, Scottish Borders, where the writer, surrounded by friends, is reading from a manuscript. The original painting by Thomas Faed was exhibited in 1850 and enjoyed great success when engraved by his brother James Faed. Portrayed from left to right are: Seated: Thomas Thomson, James Ballantyne, Archibald Constable, Thomas Campbell, Tom Moore, Sir Adam Fergusson, Francis Jeffrey, William Wordsworth, John Gibson Lockhart, George Crabbe, Henry Mackenzie, Scott, and (on footstool) James Hogg. Standing: Sir Humphrey Davy, Sir David Wilkie, Sir William Allan, Prof. John Wilson.

image.title1: Lucia: Quadrille Dedicated to Mrs Chas. Need of Fountain Dale, Notts.
image.title2: Cover illustration, from a sketch by J. Brandard, for a quadrille inspired by Scott's novel The Bride of Lammermoor
image.creator: Brandard, John
image.description: Front cover of a quadrille inspired by Scott's novel The Bride of Lammermoor, depicting Edgar Ravenswood and Lucy Aston in front of a scenic landscape with a well and a castle in the background.

image.title1: The Talisman Waltz: On Melodies in M.W. Balfe's Grand Opera, Arranged by Charles Godfrey
image.title2: Coloured lithograph after a sketch by A. Concanen advertising a musical performance of The Talisman
image.creator: Concanen, Alfred
image.description: Front cover of a musical setting of Scott's novel The Talisman, depicting Sir Kenneth, the Knight of the Leopard, kneeling before a grotto with the Talisman in his hand. The lithograph was executed by Alfred Concanen from his own design. Balfe's unfinished last opera, The Knight of the Leopard, was first performed posthumously in 1874 in an Italian arrangement entitled Il talismano

image.title1: Kenilworth Castle as It Stood in the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, to Illustrate the Romance of Kenilworth, 1575
image.title2: Facsimile plan of Kenilworth Castle
image.creator: Dugdale, William
image.description: Depicts Kenilworth Castle, Warwickshire, home of the Earl of Leicester in Scott's novel Kenilworth. The now ruined castle Kenilworth Castle was established by Geoffrey de Clinton, Chamberlain to Henry I, in about 1122. This facsimile plan is a copy of a drawing made by William Dugdale in 1656 for his Antiquities of Warwickshire.

image.title2: Coloured lithograph after a painting by M. O'Connor of the heroine of Scott's novel The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: O'Connor, M.
image.description: Depicts Jeanie Deans, heroine of Scott's novel The Heart of Mid-Lothian. The lithograph was made by M. O'Connor from his own design.

image.title1: [Engraved frontispiece and title-page of Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, second series, vol. III]
image.creator: Aikman, William (b.1682, d.1731)
image.description: Engraved frontispiece depicting the Scottish statesman Andrew Fletcher of Saltoun (1655-1716), featured in Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, vol. III, second series, ch. 7-8. Also vignette engraving of an Edinburgh scene. The portrait was engraved by Lizars from a painting by William Aikman (probably via an earlier engraving). The vignette was engraved from Lizars's own design.

image.title2: Coloured lithograph after a painting by M. O'Connor of a character in Scott's novel St. Ronan's Well
image.creator: O'Connor, M.
image.description: Depicts Clara Mowbray, heroine of Scott's novel St Ronan's Well. The lithograph was made by M. O'Connor from his own design.

image.title1: Mr Macready as Rob Roy MacGregor
image.title2: Coloured engraving for a dramatisation by J. Fairburn of Scott's novel Rob Roy
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts the actor William C. Macready (1793-1873) as Rob Roy MacGregor in full Highland dress. Engraved Sept. 11, 1848. Published by G. Skelt of St. Helier, Jersey.

image.title2: Engraving by H. Seling of a sketch by C. Phillips of the actor Mr Braham in a dramatisation of Scott's novel Guy Mannering
image.creator: Phillips, C.
image.description: Depicts the operatic tenor John Braham (ca.1774-1856) as Henry Bertram, hero of Guy Mannering, in the act of singing "Scots wha hae". Portrays a scene from a dramatisation of Guy Mannering, performed in the Haymarket Theatre, Edinburgh, Friday, Sept. 22, 1820.

image.title2: Coloured lithograph after a painting by M. O'Connor of a character in Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: O'Connor, M.
image.description: Depicts Alice Bridgenorth trying to persuade her father that she has met her lover Julian by chance (Peveril of the Peak, ch. 13) The lithograph was made by M. O'Connor from his own design.

image.title2: Original watercolour of Market Place, Melrose
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Original watercolour depicting the Market Place in Melrose, Scottish Borders. Artist unknown; dated 12 August 1848. Melrose is set in the heart of the 'Scott Country', and is featured in many of his works, most notably The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) and, under the guise of 'Kennaquhair', in The Monastery (1820). Town and abbey are described in detail in Scott's The Border Antiquities of England and Scotland (1814).

image.title1: [Engraving illustrating a scene from Scott's poem Marmion]
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Moonlit scene depicting Marmion and Ralph de Winton in combat (Marmion, canto IV, stanza 21). Illustrates canto IV, stanza 21, lines 5-6: 'High o'er my head, with threatening hand, | The spectre shook his naked brand'.

image.title1: [Engraving illustrating Scott's poem The Lady of the Lake]
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Roderick Dhu challenging James Fitz-James (Lady of the Lake, canto V, stanza 9). Illustrates canto V, stanza 9, lines 31-32: 'These are Clan-Alpine's warriors true; | And, Saxon,--I am Roderick Dhu!'

image.title2: Coloured lithograph after a drawing by M. O'Connor of the heroine of Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: O'Connor, M.
image.description: Depicts Annot Lyle singing and accompanying herself on the harp (Legend of Montrose, ch. 9). The lithograph was made by M. O'Connor from his own design.

image.title1: Abbotsford. Scale Four Chains to an Inch
image.title2: Facsimile of plan of Abbotsford and adjacent land
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Facsimile of the original 1811 plan for the Abbotsford estate, Scottish Borders, with annotations in Scott's own hand. When Scott bought the 110-acre Cartley Hole Farm in 1811 he renamed it Abbotsford. He bought up neighbouring properties until in 1825 the estate had expanded to ten times its original size. By 1821, the residence that he had built between 1812 and 1818 had become too small for the estate and for the constant stream of visitors that he received. A two-storey manor house (portrayed here) was built in its stead. Scott continued to live in Abbotsford following the financial disaster of 1825-26 as the estate had been settled upon his newly married son Walter. image.title1: The Storm with Mordaunt Rescuing Cleveland
image.title2: Engraving by W. Richardson after a painting by S. Bough depicting a scene from Scott's novel The Pirate
image.creator: Bough, Samuel (b.1822, d.1878)
image.description: Depicts Mordaunt Mertoun rescuing the shipwrecked pirate captain Cleveland (Pirate, ch. 7)

image.title2: Cover illustration for a quadrille inspired by Scott's novel Old Mortality
image.creator: Brandard, John
image.description: Front cover of a book of sheet music, depicting John Graham of Claverhouse, Viscount Dundee ('Bonnie Dundee') on horseback saluting a cheering crowd. The campaign against the Covenanters, conducted by Graham of Claverhouse, is the subject of Walter Scott's Old Mortality (1816). In a footnote to the Magnum Opus edition of the novel (1830), Scott writes: 'This remarkable person united the seemingly inconsistent qualities of courage and cruelty, a disinterested and devoted loyalty to his prince, with a disregard of the rights of his fellow-subjects. He was the unscrupulous agent of the Scottish Privy Council in executing the merciless severities of the government in Scotland during the reigns of Charles II. and James II.; but he redeemed his character by the zeal with which he asserted the cause of the latter monarch after the Revolution, the military skill with which he supported it at the battle of Killiecrankie, and by his own death in the arms of victory.' Scott was fascinated by the figure of Claverhouse, whom he believed had been traduced by Presbyterian historians, and displayed a portrait of him in his study at Castle Street, Edinburgh. Claverhouse is also portrayed in 'Wandering Willie's Tale' (1824) and in the song 'Bonnie Dundee' in Scott's play The Doom of Devorgoil (1830).

image.title1: [Title page of James Hogg's The Brownie of Bodsbeck; and Other Tales]
image.creator: Hogg, James
image.description: James Hogg's novel The Brownie of Bodsbeck is a fictional account of the 17th-century Covenanting movement, written in response to Scott's Old Mortality, and offering a more sympathetic portrayal of the Covenanters. Scott met the poet and novelist James Hogg while researching material for Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-03). Scott remained his lifelong friend and patron. Following Scott's death, Hogg published The Domestic Manners and Private Life of Sir Walter Scott (1834).

image.creator: Herdman, Robert
image.description: Depicts Waverley visiting Flora McIvor, who is sitting at a window with needlework on her lap (Waverley, ch. 68).

image.title2: Engraving by W. Forrest after a painting by P. Graham depicting a scene from Scott's novel Waverley

image.title2: Frontispiece engraving by W. Greatbatch after a drawing by W. Boxall of a scene from Scott's novel Count Robert of Paris
image.creator: Boxall, William
image.description: Depicts Count Robert seated on the throne of Emperor Alexius during the oath-taking ceremony on the eve of the Crusade (Count Robert of Paris, ch. 9). Illustrates the lines: 'Without a moment's hesitation the Frank seated himself in the vacant throne of the Emperor, and extending his half-armed and robust figure on the golden cushions which were destined for Alexius, he indolently began to caress a large wolf-hound.' This engraving was originally made for the Magnum Opus edition of Count Robert of Paris, published by Robert Cadell, Edinburgh, in 1833. The engraver's name is variously spelt 'Greatbatch' or 'Greatbach'. Most reference sources favour the latter spelling.

image.creator: Pitcairn, Robert

He was an original member of the Bannatyne Club founded by Scott in 1823 to print rare works of Scottish interest.

image.title1: The Regalia of Scotland, Edinburgh Castle
image.title2: Albumen print by Alexander Inglis of the Scottish crown jewels
image.creator: Inglis, Alexander
image.description: Albumen print depicting the Regalia of Scotland or Scottish crown jewels. Following the Act of Union between England and Scotland in 1707, the ancient Regalia (or 'Honours') of Scotland were deposited in a locked oak chest in the Crown Room of Edinburgh Castle. Over the following decades, their whereabouts was forgotten, and it was rumoured that, counter to the terms of the Union, they had been carried away to England. Prompted by Sir Walter Scott, the Prince Regent set up a commission to search the Crown Room for the Regalia. On 4 February 1818, the Commissioners, including Scott, discovered the chest and found, wrapped in linen, the fourteenth-century Scottish Crown, the Sceptre of James V, and the Sword of State, a gift from Pope Julius II to James V. The Regalia were subsequently placed on permanent display in the Crown Room. Scott described the discovery in his Description of the Regalia of Scotland (1819).

image.title2: Title page and frontispiece of a dramatization of Scott's novel Rob Roy by I. Pocock

Also title-page of libretto to the opera. Rob Roy Macgregor, or, Auld Lang Syne was adapted from Scott's novel Rob Roy by Isaac Pocock, with music by Sir Henry Bishop (1786-1855) and John Davy (1763-1824). It was first performed at Covent Garden, London, on 12 March 1818 and went on to become one of the most popular and frequently revived dramas of the nineteenth century.

image.title2: Frontispiece illustration by A.H. Payne of a German translation of Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Payne, Albert Henry
image.description: Portrait of Rebecca, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's novel Ivanhoe. This portrait was engraved by the German-based English artist Albert Henry Payne (presumably from his own design) for a German translation of Ivanhoe. It depicts Rebecca as described in chapter 7 of the novel: 'Her form was exquisitely symmetrical, and was shown to advantage by a sort of Eastern dress, which she wore according to the fashion of the females of her nation. Her turban of yellow silk suited well with the darkness of her complexion. The brilliancy of her eyes, the superb arch of her eyebrows, her well-formed aquiline nose, her teeth as white as pearl, and the profusion of her sable tresses, which, each arranged in its own little spiral of twisted curls, fell down upon as much of a lovely neck and bosom as a simarre of the richest Persian silk, exhibiting flowers in their natural colours embossed upon a purple ground, permitted to be visible--all these constituted a combination of loveliness, which yielded not to the most beautiful of the maidens who surrounded her. It is true, that of the golden and pearl-studded clasps, which closed her vest from the throat to the waist, the three uppermost were left unfastened on account of the heat, which something enlarged the prospect to which we allude. A diamond necklace, with pendants of inestimable value, were by this means also made more conspicuous. The feather of an ostrich, fastened in her turban by an agraffe set with brilliants, was another distinction of the beautiful Jewess, scoffed and sneered at by the proud dames who sat above her, but secretly envied by those who affected to deride them.'

image.title1: Peveril del Picco. Volgarizzato da Pietro Costa

image.title1: Goetz of Berlichingen, with the Iron Hand: A Tragedy
image.title2: Title page of Scott's translation of Goethe's drama Goetz of Berlichingen
image.creator: Goethe, Johann Wolfgang von
image.description: Title page of Sir Walter Scott's translation of Goethe's tragedy Goetz of Berlichingen erroneously giving Scott's name as William Scott. Scott began his literary career with a series of translations from contemporary German literature. Of Goethe, the European writer whom Scott most admired, he translated Goetz of Berlichingen (1799), 'The Erl-King' (1799), 'Frederick and Alice' (1800), and 'Lamentation of the Faithful Wife of Asan Aga' (1806). Scott described Goethe as 'a wonderful fellow, the Ariosto at once, and almost the Voltaire of Germany' (Journal, 15 February 1827) and acclaimed him as 'an author born to arouse the slumbering fame of his country' (Introduction to 'Magnum' edition of Anne of Geierstein, 1831). Scott was bitterly disappointed that Goethe's death on 22 March 1832 thwarted a long-cherished plan to visit him at Weimar. Goethe, in his turn, was a great admirer of the Waverley Novels, praising Scott in a letter of 12 January 1827 for his 'wonderful pictures of human life'. Deeply flattered, Scott sent Goethe a copy of his Life of Napoleon Buonaparte and hailed him as 'the father of the German literature' (letter of 9 July 1827).

image.title2: Engraving by C. Rolls of a painting by J.-B. Isabey depicting Napoleon Bonaparte
image.creator: Isabey, Jean-Baptiste
image.description: Portrays Napoleon Bonaparte in the grounds of the Ch̢teau de Malmaison, the country house bought by his wife Jos̩phine de Beauharnais, which was from 1800 to 1802 seat of the French government. This is the frontispiece to the 1834 edition of Scott's Life of Napoleon Bonaparte, which was first published in nine volumes in 1827. In a letter to Lady Abercorn (April 21, 1824), Scott described Napoleon as 'a strange mingled phantom of grandeur and terror and a little meanness withal as ever bestrode the destinies of the world'. The original portrait by Isabey was considered to be one of the closest likenesses of Napoleon.

image.creator: Harvey, William
image.description: Depicts arms, armaments and other objects from Sir Walter Scott's private collection at Abbotsford or associated with the Waverley Novels. Also depicted are some of Scott's dogs and, in the background, Abbotsford House. Title page of Part LVIII of the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels, published June 1844, containing chapters 1-6 of The Pirate. The illustration is identical for each part of the serialized edition, and for each volume of the published set.

image.title1: Der Abt/L'Abb̩: Maria Stuart, Rowland Grame [sic]

image.title2: Hand coloured engraving by F. Sțber after a drawing by P. v. Stubenrauch of figures dressed as characters from Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Stubenrauch, Philipp von
image.description: Depicts the costumes of Lord Douglas and Catherine Seyton (both featured in Scott's The Abbot) as worn at a themed costume ball in Vienna in 1826. These costumes were paraded at a themed costume ball held in Vienna in 1826

image.title2: Hand coloured engraving by F. Sțber after a drawing by P. v. Stubenrauch of figures dressed as characters from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Stubenrauch, Philipp von
image.description: Depicts the costumes of Sir Walter Raleigh and Queen Elizabeth I (from Sir Walter Scott's novel Kenilworth) as worn at a themed costume ball in Vienna in 1826.

image.title2: Hand coloured engraving by F. Sțber after a drawing by P. v. Stubenrauch of figures dressed as characters from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Stubenrauch, Philipp von
image.description: Depicts the costumes of Amy Robsart and Lord Leicester (from Scott's novel Kenilworth) as worn at a themed costume ball in Vienna in 1826.

image.title1: Quintin Durward/Quentin Durward: Quintin Durward, Johanna von Frankreich
image.title2: Hand coloured engraving by F. Sțber after a drawing by P. v. Stubenrauch of figures dressed as characters from Scott's novel Quentin Durward
image.creator: Stubenrauch, Philipp von
image.description: Depicts the costumes of Quentin Durward and Princess Joan of France (from Scott's novel Quentin Durward) as worn at a themed costume ball in Vienna in 1826.

image.creator: Stubenrauch, Philipp von
image.description: Depicts the costumes of Lady Rowena and Ivanhoe (from Scott's eponymous novel) as worn at a themed costume ball in Vienna in 1826.

image.title2: Hand coloured engraving by F. Sțber after a drawing by P. v. Stubenrauch of figures dressed as characters from Scott's novel Ivanhoe
image.creator: Stubenrauch, Philipp von
image.description: Depicts the costumes of Rebecca and Isaac (from Scott's novel Ivanhoe) as worn at a themed costume ball in Vienna in 1826.

image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Archibald Alison by W. H. Lizars after J. G. Lockhart
image.creator: Lockhart, John Gibson
image.description: Vignette engraved portrait of the Scottish philosopher and divine Archibald Alison (1757-1839). Archibald Alison and Sir Walter Scott were fellow members of the Friday Club, a literary club founded in June 1803 which met every Friday evening. Alison, Minister from 1800 of the Episcopalian Chapel in Edinburgh's Cowgate, is best known as the author of Essays on the Nature and Principles of Taste (1790). It has been argued that Alison's extension of Enlightenment theories of association to the realm of aesthetics exerted a profound influence on Scott's depiction of landscape. The artist signature P.M. refers to Peter Morris, the alias adopted by J. G. Lockhart in Peter's Letters to his Kinfolk (1819).

image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of D'Alembert by W. Hopwood after a painting by M.-Q. de La Tour
image.creator: La Tour, Maurice-Quentin de
image.description: Engraved portrait of the French philosopher and mathematician Jean Le Rond d'Alembert (1717-1783). Sir Walter Scott quoted d'Alembert in his 'Memoir of Samuel Richardson', originally printed as the preface to the Ballantyne's Novelists' Library edition of Richardson's works (1824) and reprinted in Lives of the Novelists (1825). Scott is critical of the profusion of detail in Richardson's works: 'This process of miniature painting has, however, its bounds; and many readers will be disposed to acquiesce in the remark of D'Alembert,- "La Nature est bonne a imiter, mais non pas jusqu'�� l'ennui" [It is good to imitate Nature but not ad nauseam].' The original portrait by Maurice-Quentin de La Tour was executed in pastel in 1753.

image.title2: Self-portrait of Sir William Allan steel-engraved by W.H. Lizars
image.creator: Allan, William
image.description: Engraved self-portrait of the Scottish painter Sir William Allan in Circassian costume. Sir Walter Scott was a friend and patron of Allan and a constant advocate of his work. They first met in 1816, and Scott subsequently invited Allan to Abbotsford in 1818 to help arrange the armoury. When Charles Montagu-Scott, 4th Duke of Buccleuch, asked for a portrait of Scott, he recommended Allan, describing him as a 'man of real genius' who had made 'one or two glorious portraits' (letter of 15 April 1819). The Duke opted for Raeburn, but Allan went on to paint a number of portraits of Scott and of his family, notably one of Scott's son, Walter, in his full Hussar uniform (1821). Besides a number of historical paintings inspired by Scott's works, Allan was responsible for Illustrations of the Novels and Tales of the Author of Waverley (Edinburgh: Archibald Constable, 1820). Allan's friendship with Scott lasted until the writer's dying day when Allan was the only non-family member present at Abbotsford. The original self-portrait of Allan in Circassian costume was painted in 1813. It was engraved by Lizars for J. G. Lockhart's Peters Letters to his Kinsfolk (1819).

image.title1: Ariosto: From a Print by Raffaelle Morghen
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Ariosto by R. Hart after R. Morghen after D. Dossi
image.creator: Morghen, Raphael
image.description: Portrait of the Italian poet Lodovico Ariosto (1474-1533). Ariosto's epic Orlando furioso (1516) was a favourite of Sir Walter Scott's from childhood onwards and exerted a lasting influence on his own verse. Over dinner with Captain Edward Cheney in Frascati on 1 May 1832, Scott claimed to read it once a year. At Edinburgh University he outraged his Greek professor by submitting an essay in which he argued that Ariosto was superior to Homer. While a college student, Scott took private Italian lessons to be able to read Ariosto, Tasso, and Boiardo in the original. Scott gave Edward Waverley, hero of his first novel (1814), much of his own love of Italian Romance. Francis Osbaldistone too in Rob Roy (1817) courts Diana Vernon by reading his translation of the first books of the Orlando furioso (ch. 16). Hart's engraving is based on an earlier engraving by Raphael Morghen (1809), which was itself freely derived from a 16th-century portrait by Dosso Dossi.

image.title1: Arkwright: From a Picture by Wright of Derby
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Sir Richard Arkwright by J. Posselwhite after a picture by Wright of Derby
image.creator: Wright, Joseph of Derby
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English engineer and industrialist Sir Richard Arkwright (1732-1792). Frances Crawford Kemble Arkwright set a number of Scott's lyrics to music, including 'Farewell to the Muse' (from The Pirate) and 'The Lay of Poor Louise' (from The Fair Maid of Perth). Scott described her as 'the most beautiful composer and delightful singer I ever heard without exception' (letter to Major Walter Scott, 20 May 1830). Scott was under the impression that she was the daughter-in-law of Sir Richard Arkwright, inventor of the spinning frame. In point of fact, her husband was Sir Richard's grandson Robert. Her father was the actor Stephen Kemble, brother of the better-known Charles Kemble, John Philip Kemble, and Sarah Kemble (later Mrs Siddons). The original portrait of Arkwright was painted in 1789-90 by Joseph Wright of Derby (or, at least, was produced by his studio).

image.title1: Lord Bacon: From a Print by J. Houbraken 1738
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Bacon by J. Posselwhite after a print by J. Houbraken
image.creator: Houbraken, Jacobus
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English philosopher, statesman, and essayist Sir Francis Bacon (1561-1626). Bacon is cited on a number of occasions by Sir Walter Scott, perhaps most notably in the Introduction to the Magnum Opus Edition of The Fortunes of Nigel (1831). Here Scott identifies the reign of James I and VI as a critical moment of transition from the Age of Chivalry to the Age of Reason: 'The hour was already arrived when Bacon was about to teach the world that they were no longer to reason from authority to fact, but to establish truth by advancing from fact to fact, till they fixed an indisputable authority, not from hypothesis, but from experiment.' A further significant citation occurs in 'The Two Drovers' (1827), where the judge at the trial of Robin Oig M'Combich quotes Bacon's view of revenge as 'a kind of wild, untutored justice'. Scott also cites Bacon's views on astrology in Guy Mannering (1815) and Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft (1830). The engraving by Posselwhite is based on an earlier line engraving by Jacobus Houbraken taken from a 17th-century portrait by an unknown artist.

image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Joanna Baillie by H. Robinson after a painting by Masquerier
image.creator: Masquerier, John James
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Scottish poet and dramatist Joanna Baillie (1762-1851). Sir Walter Scott was a great admirer of Joanna Baillie's blank verse Plays of the Passions, considering her 'the best dramatic writer whom Britain has produced since the days of Shakespeare and Massinger' (letter to Sarah Smith, 4 March 1808). He was first introduced to her at her Hampstead home in 1806, and the pair became lifelong friends and devoted correspondents. Scott found her 'the only writing lady with whose manners in society I have been very much delighted' (letter to Lady Abercorn, 18 September 1811). As a Trustee of Edinburgh Theatre, Scott played an active role in organizing a highly successful production of Baillie's The Family Legend and a revival of her De Montfort in 1810. Scott's own drama Halidon Hill began life as a contribution to Joanna Baillie's Collection of Poetical Miscellanies. When it grew too large for the anthology, it was replaced by a shorter dramatic sketch MacDuff's Cross. Baillie had earlier contributed verse to Scott's anthology English Minstrelsy (1810). The original portrait by Masquerier was painted in 1812. Concerning it, Scott wrote to Richard Heber: 'How has your friend Masquerier succeeded in painting Miss Baillie? if tolerably I must manage to get a copy cabinet size but poor M. has a heavey [sic] hand.'

image.title1: Sir J. Banks: From a Picture by T. Phillips in the Possession of the Royal Society
image.title2: Steel engraving of Sir Joseph Banks by C. E. Wagstaff after a painting by T. Phillips
image.creator: Phillips, Thomas
image.description: Engraved portrait of the naturalist and explorer Sir Joseph Banks (1743-1820). In a letter dated 10 February 1816, Scott asked Anna Jane Clephane to send him a humorous ballad that she had written about the Duke of Argyll's Factor. The Factor had reputedly sent the skeleton of a porpoise to Banks in the belief that it was a mermaid. When Banks attempted to disabuse him, the Factor opined that the distinguished naturalist was an 'auld blind doited deevil'. Scott relates a similar anecdote in a note to the Magnum Opus Edition of The Pirate (1831) recalling how a supposed sea-serpent was washed up on the shore of Shetland and sent to Banks for examination. Banks proclaimed it 'a basking shark', yet, Scott adds, 'it would seem that an animal so well known ought to have been immediately distinguished by the northern fishermen'. The original portrait by Thomas Phillips was painted in 1810.

image.title1: Barrow: From the Original Picture by Isaac Whood at Trinity College, Cambridge
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Isaac Barrow by B. Holl after a painting by I. Whood
image.creator: Whood, Isaac
image.description: Engraved portrait of the divine, mathematician, and classicist the Reverend Isaac Barrow (1630-1677). In his much-read treatise Self-Help, Samuel Smiles cited Sir Walter Scott and Isaac Barrow as twin examples of successful men dismissed as dunces at school. Both are praised not only for their perseverance but for their cultivation of physical fitness. In Smiles's wake, the coupling of Scott and Barrow became a staple of self-help manuals.

image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Bentham by J. Posselwhite after a painting by G.F. Watts
image.creator: Watts, George Frederick
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Utilitarian philosopher and political economist Jeremy Bentham (1748-1832). On 17 February 1823, Bentham wrote to Samuel Parr describing an engraving by Robert Bowyer of George Hayter's painting View of the Interior of the House of Lords during the Trial of Queen Caroline, 1820. Among the audience, Hayter had portrayed many public figures of the day, placing Bentham, to his dismay, next to Sir Walter Scott 'the servile poet and novelist'. Scott never mentioned Bentham by name but, both explicitly in his political pamphlets and implicitly in his novels, he attacked his projects for juridical reform which he feared would destroy national characteristics and traditions. When both men died in close proximity in 1832, obituarists presented them as figureheads of the two opposing currents of nineteenth-century thought: Utilitarianism and Romanticism. The original portrait by George Frederick Watts (not 'J. Watts' as indicated in the caption) was taken in 1837 from Bentham's 'Auto-Icon' (now on display at University College London).

image.title1: Bentley: From a Picture by Hudson in Trinity College, Cambridge
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Richard Bentley by J. Posselwhite after a painting by Hudson
image.creator: Hudson, Thomas
image.description: Engraved portrait of the critic and classical scholar Richard Bentley (1662-1742). In Sir Walter Scott's novel Waverley (1814), the protagonist Edward Waverley is portrayed as a conceited, unreceptive scholar: '"I can read and understand a Latin author," said young Edward, with the self-confidence and rash reasoning of fifteen, "and Scaliger or Bentley could not do much more."' (ch. 3) Richard Bentley is perhaps England's greatest classical scholar. In his Memoir of Jonathan Swift (1814), Scott discusses Bentley's role in the controversy sparked by Sir William Temple's Ancient and Modern Learning which Swift satirized in The Battle of the Books (1704).

image.title1: Black: From a Picture by Jas. Heath after a Picture by Raeburn
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Joseph Black by J. Posselwhite after J. Heath after H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Scottish chemist and physicist Joseph Black (1728-1799). Black lived in the same building in College Wynd, Edinburgh, in which Sir Walter Scott was born. He has been credited with saving the infant Scott's life by informing his father that the child's nurse suffered from consumption. In Scott's novel Guy Mannering, Black is among the 'first literary characters of Scotland' to whom Counsellor Pleydell supplies Mannering with letters of introduction (ch. 10). The original portrait by Raeburn was painted ca. 1780 and the engraving by James Heath first published in 1800.

image.title1: Admiral Blake: From the Picture in the Hall of Wadham College, Oxford
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Robert Blake by J. Mollison
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Engraved portrait of Admiral Robert Blake (1599-1657). Robert Blake was appointed General at Sea by Cromwell in 1649 and is often described as the Father of the Royal Navy. In Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823), the Countess of Derby recalls his unsuccessful siege of Peel Castle on the Isle of Man: 'When we had foiled various attempts upon the island by open force -- treason accomplished what Blake and Lawson, with their floating castles, had found too hazardous an enterprise -- a base rebel, whom we had nursed in our own bosoms, betrayed us to the enemy.' (ch. 5) The engraving by Mollison is taken after a 17th-century portrait by an unknown artist.

image.title1: Boccaccio: From a Print by Cornelius Van Dalen
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Boccaccio by W. Hopwood after a print by C. Van Dalen
image.creator: Dalen, Cornelius van I
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Italian writer Giovanni Boccaccio (1313-1375). The Decameron of Giovanni Boccaccio was a lifelong favourite of Sir Walter Scott and is frequently cited in the Waverley Novels. While a college student, Scott took private Italian lessons to be able to read Ariosto, Tasso, Boccaccio, and Boiardo in the original. He gave Edward Waverley, hero of his first novel (1814), much of his own love of Italian literature. The 17th-print by Van Dalen was taken from a portrait in the Royal Collection which is now attributed to Titian. It is now thought that the sitter is not Boccaccio but Jacopo Sannazaro.

image.title1: Bolivar: From an Engraving by M. N. Bate
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Bolivar by W. Holl after a print by M. N. Bate
image.creator: Castro, Jos̩ Gil de
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Latin American soldier and statesman Simon Bolivar (1783-1830), called El Liberador. The original portrait was probably that painted by Jos̩ Gil de Castro in 1825. (It is unclear why the Corson Collection of Walter Scott materials contains a portrait of Bolivar, perhaps because there are statues of both Scott and Bolivar in New York's Central Park?)

image.title1: Bossuet: From the Original Picture by H. Rigaud in the Collection of the Institute of France
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Bossuet by R. Woodman after a painting by H. Rigaud
image.creator: Rigaud, Hyacinthe
image.description: Engraved portrait of the French divine and historian Jacques-B̩nigne Bossuet (1627-1704). In his Life of John Dryden (1808) Scott discusses the role played by the theological writings of Bossuet in Dryden's conversion to Catholicism. In an article on Moli̬re for the Foreign Quarterly Review in 1828, he also defends the playwright against Bossuet's charge of profanity. The original portrait by Hyacinthe Rigaud was painted in 1702.

image.title1: John Bowring: From a Painting by B. E. Duppa
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of John Bowring by W. Holl after a painting by B. E. Duppa
image.creator: Duppa, Bryan Edward
image.description: Engraved portrait of the political economist and linguist Sir John Bowring (1792-1872). Bowring visited Scott at Abbotsford in 1830. Scott thought him a 'clever' and 'very agreeable' man (letter to Robert Cadell, 23 April 1830). A description of the visit and a biographical sketch of Scott are included in Autobiographical Recollections of Sir John Bowring (1877). Bowring was also part of the Committee which organized the celebration of the centenary of Scott's birth in Melrose in 1871. The engraving by William Holl the Younger was first published in 1840; the original portrait was probably completed shortly beforehand.

image.title1: Robert Boyle: From an Original Picture in the Possession of Lord Dover
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Robert Boyle by R. Woodman
image.creator: Kerseboom, Johann
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English natural philosopher and chemist Robert Boyle (1626-1691). In his Life of John Dryden (1808), Sir Walter Scott discussed Dryden's passion for science and his praise of Boyle in 'Epistle to Dr Walter Charleton'. Boyle's belief in second sight is also mentioned in a note to Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810). The original portrait by Johann Kerseboom was painted ca. 1689.

image.title1: Bradley: From the Original Picture by Richardson in the Possession of the Royal Society
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of James Bradley by E. Scriven after a picture by Richardson
image.creator: Richardson, Jonathan
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English divine and astronomer James Bradley (1693?-1762).

image.title1: Bramante: From a Picture by Alessandro D'Este in the Collection of the Capitol, at Rome
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Bramante by J. Posselwhite from a picture by Alessandro D'Este
image.creator: D'Este, Alessandro
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Italian architect and painter Donato Bramante (1444-1514). Bramante is best known as the architect of St Peter's Basilica in Rome. Scott visited St Peter's in April 1832 while travelling on the Continent in an unsuccessful attempt to repair his health. His main interest lay, however, not in Bramante's architecture but in Canova's Cenotaph of the Stuarts erected in St Peter's with financial backing from King George IV. The 19th-century portrait by Alessandro D'Este is based on an unidentified earlier image.

image.title1: Brindley: From a Picture by R. Dunkarton 1773, after a Picture by F. Parsons
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of James Brindley by J. T. Wedgwood after a picture by F. Parsons
image.creator: Parsons, Francis
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English engineer James Brindley (1716-1772). The original portrait by Francis Parsons was painted in 1770. Wedgwood's engraving is taken from a mezzotint by Dunkarton printed in 1773.

image.title1: George Buchanan: From a Picture by Francis Pourbus Senr. in the Possession of the Royal Society
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of George Buchanan by E. Scriven after a picture by F. Pourbus the elder
image.creator: Pourbus, Frans the elder
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Scottish poet, historian and humanist scholar George Buchanan (1506-1582). In both his fictional and historical works, Sir Walter Scott drew extensively on Buchanan's Rerum Scoticarum Historia while treating its earlier chapters with some scepticism. Buchanan's histories and polemical treatises are a particularly important source for The Abbot (1820). Buchanan's role as tutor to King James VI and I is invoked in The Fortunes of Nigel (1822), especially his disapproval of the convention that a whipping boy (here Sir Mungo Malagrowther) suffer all punishments due to the King. There are further references to Buchanan in Waverley (where he is among the Baron of Bradwardine's favourite poets), The Monastery, and The Bride of Lammermoor. Buchanan was reputedly Scott's favourite Latin poet, although he found his Latin hymns less 'solemn and affecting' to his 'Gothic ear' than the Catholic liturgy (letter to Rev. George Crabbe, ca. January 1813).

image.title1: Buffon: From an Original Picture by Drouais in the Collection of the Institute of France
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Buffon by R. Hart after a picture by Drouais
image.creator: Drouais, Fran̤ois Hubert
image.description: Engraved portrait of the French naturalist Georges Louis Leclerc, comte de Buffon (1707-1788). Sir Walter Scott's library at Abbotsford included an edition of Buffon's Histoire naturelle, g̩n̩rale et particuli̬re. Scott drew on it when likening the painter Dick Tinto to a sloth in chapter 1 of The Bride of Lammermoor (1819): 'In short, Dick Tinto's friends feared that he had acted like the animal called the sloth, which, heaving eaten up the last green leaf upon the tree where it has established itself, ends by tumbling down from the top, and dying of inanition.' The original portrait by Fran̤ois Hubert Drouais was painted in 1761.

image.title1: Burke: From a Picture after Sir Joshua Reynolds in the Possession of T. H. Burke, Esq.
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Edmund Burke by C. E. Wagstaff after a painting by J. Reynolds
image.creator: Reynolds, Joshua, Sir (b.1723, d.1792)
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Irish statesman, philosopher and historian Edmund Burke (1729-1797). Burke exerted a great influence on Sir Walter Scott, both through his concept of the 'sublime' (expounded in A Philosophical Enquiry into the Origin of Our Ideas of the Sublime and Beautiful) and through his vision of an 'organic' society' (expounded in Reflections on the Revolution in France). In a letter to Henry Francis Scott, Younger of Harden, M.P. dated 10 January 1831, Scott praised 'the talents, the almost prophetic powers' of Burke: 'About 1792, when I was entering life, the admiration of the godlike system of the French Revolution was so rife, that only a few old-fashioned Jacobites and the like ventured to hint a preference for the land they lived in; or pretended to doubt that the new principles must be infused into our worn-out constitution. Burke appeared, and all the gibberish about the superior legislation of the French dissolved like an enchanted castle when the destined knight blows his horn before it.' The original portrait from the studio of Sir Joshua Reynolds was painted in 1767-69.

image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Burns by H. Robinson after a picture by A. Naysmith
image.creator: Nasmyth, Alexander (b.1758, d.1840)
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Scottish poet Robert Burns (1759-1796). For Sir Walter Scott, Robert Burns and Lord Byron were 'the most genuine poetical geniuses of my time, and half a century before me' (Journal, 9 February 1826). When asked by James Ballantyne how he ranked his own genius next to Burns, Scott replied: 'There is no comparison whatever -- we ought not to be named in the same day.' Scott met Burns only once at the age of fifteen in 1787 at Sciennes Hill House, Edinburgh, an event he frequently recalled. Besides copious quotations from Burns in his published works and letters, Scott included ballads collected by Burns in his Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-1803). He provided his son-in-law J. G. Lockhart with letters and reminiscences for his Life of Burns (1828) and approved of Lockhart's decision to gloss over the poet's perceived moral failings. Scott also helped organize a subscription for a monument to Burns in Dumfries (1814) and personally subscribed to the Burns Monument on Calton Hill, Edinburgh (1817). The original portrait of Burns was painted in 1787.

image.title1: Calvin: From an Original Engraving by C. Dankertz
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Calvin by T. Woolnoth after a print by C. Dankerts
image.creator: Dankerts, Cornelis
image.description: Engraved portrait of the French Protestant theologian John Calvin (1509-1564). Calvin exerted a profound influence on the Reformation in Scotland and on the development of Scottish Presbyterian doctrine. Sir Walter Scott was brought up in a strict Calvinist household but came to reject many of Calvin's creeds, notably predestinarianism, and to gravitate towards the Episcopal Church. There are references to Calvin in a number of the Waverley Novels, including Old Mortality (1816), Woodstock (1826) and, in particular, The Abbot (1820) where Roland Graeme calls his Huguenot grandmother 'as strict as Calvin himself' and Mary Queen of Scots criticizes the intolerance of the 'stern preachers of the Calvinistic heresy' (ch. 31).

image.title2: Silhouette portrait of Robert Campbell with pencilled inscription
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: A silhouette portrait of the Scottish writer Robert Calder Campbell (1798-1857). An MS note on the back of this print tentatively identifies the sitter as Campbell. An accompanying note in typescript (possibly by J. C. Corson) observes that the sitter would appear to be at least a decade older than Campbell in 1817.

image.title1: Canova: From a Picture by Sir Thomas Lawrence in the Possession of the Abate Canova at Rome
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Canova by J. Posselwhite after a painting by T. Lawrence
image.creator: Lawrence, Thomas
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Italian sculptor Antonio Canova (1757-1822). Like most of his contemporaries, Sir Walter Scott considered Canova the foremost sculptor of his age. Visiting Paris in 1815, he admired the three Canovas commissioned by the Empress Josephine for the Malmaison (now in the Hermitage, St Petersburg). His Paul's Letters to his Kinsfolk (1816) records that he was 'particularly struck' by the Dancer with her Hand on her Hip. When in Rome in April 1832, the dying Scott most wished to see Canova's Cenotaph of the Stuarts erected in St Peter's at the expense of George IV. The following month he admired Canova's Venere Italica in the Palazzo Pitti in Florence. He also mentioned Canova's Venus Victrix in his Life of Napoleon Buonaparte (1827-28), commenting that Pauline Bonaparte's 'encouragement of the fine arts was so little limited by the ordinary ideas of decorum' that she permitted the sculptor to use her as the model. There is a single reference to Canova in the Waverly Novels. In chapter 12 of Saint Ronan's Well (1824) Valentine Bulmer declares that Clare Mowbray's pallor renders her more interesting: 'The last time I saw her, I thought she might have rivalled one of Canova's finest statues.' The original portrait by Sir Thomas Lawrence was painted in 1816.

image.title1: Dr. Cartwright: From a Picture in the Possession of Miss Cartwright
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Edmund Cartwright by J. Thomson
image.creator: Fulton, Robert
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English inventor and poet Edmund Cartwright (1743-1823). Edmund Cartwright, now primarily known as the inventor of the power loom, was also highly acclaimed as a poet during his lifetime. In his 'Essay on Imitations of the Ancient Ballad' (1830), Sir Walter Scott praises Cartwright's best-known poem 'Armine and Elvira' which contains 'some excellent poetry, expressed with unusual felicity'. He adds that he recalls meeting Cartwright in 'very early youth' at the house of his grandfather John Rutherford, and that 'he was the first living poet I recollect to have seen'. The original portrait is by fellow inventor Robert Fulton (1765-1815).

image.title1: Catherine: From a Print by C. Watson after a Picture by Rosselin
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Catherine the Great by R. Woodman after a painting by A. Roslin
image.creator: Roslin, Alexander
image.description: Engraved portrait of Catherine the Great, empress of Russia (1729-1796). Catherine's foreign policy is discussed in Sir Walter Scott's The Life of Napoleon Buonaparte (1827-28), particularly with respect to the partition of Poland and the principle of 'armed neutrality'. The original portrait was painted by Alexander Roslin in 1777-78, and the print by Caroline Watson was published in 1788.

image.title1: Cervantes. After the Spanish print engraved by D. F. Selma
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Cervantes by E. Mackenzie after a print by F. Selma
image.creator: Carnicero Mancio, Antonio
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Spanish writer Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra (1547-1616), author of Don Quixote. Over dinner with Captain Edward Cheney in Frascati on 1 May 1832, Scott claimed that it was Cervantes who first inspired in him the desire to excel in fiction. Indeed in the opening section of his first novel Waverley (1814), Scott hails Cervantes as his most significant predecessor while underlining his own innovations on his model: 'From the minuteness with which I have traced Waverley's pursuits,and the bias which these unavoidably communicated to his imagination, the reader may perhaps anticipate, in the following tale, an imitation of the romance of Cervantes. But he will do my prudence injustice in the supposition. My intention is not to follow the steps of that inimitable author, in describing such total perversion of intellect as misconstrues the objects actually presented to the senses, but that more common aberration from sound judgment, which apprehends occurrences indeed in their reality, but communicates to them a tincture of its own romantic tone and colouring.' (ch. 5) While studying at Edinburgh University Scott acquired sufficient Spanish to read Cervantes in the original. His works are saturated with references to Don Quixote and the Novelas ejemplares. The Tales of a Landlord each bear an epitaph from Don Quixote. The 'Introductory Epistle' to The Monastery (1820) cites Don Quixote as an example of the dangers of anonymous authorship, inspiring, like Scott's own novels, sequels from unscrupulous rivals. In the 'Introductory Address' to Count Robert of Paris and Castle Dangerous (1832), Scott's last published works, Scott again cites Cervantes's self-defence against critics who highlighted minor inconsistencies and loose ends in his narrative. The importance of Cervantes is also repeatedly acknowledged in Lives of the Novelists (1821-24) and the 'Essay on Chivalry' (1818). The original engraving by Fernando Selma from a design by Antonio Carnicero Mancio was first published in 1780.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Thomas Chalmers by W. H. Lizars after J. G. Lockhart
image.creator: Lockhart, John Gibson
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Rev. Thomas Chalmers, founding father of the Free Church of Scotland. James Ballantyne records that Sir Walter Scott abandoned his habitual indifference to praise when he heard that his novels had been lauded in public by Chalmers. Scott declared that 'to have produced any effect upon the mind of such a man as Dr. Chalmers is indeed something to be proud of', for Chalmers was 'a man of the truest genius'. Only one encounter between Scott and Chalmers has been recorded. At the Annual Meeting of the School of Arts on 1 June 1824 Chalmers moved the approval of the Annual Report, expressing an essentially paternalistic vision of the relationship between the school and its working-class pupils. Scott seconded the motion, warmly applauding the principles underpinning Chalmers's speech. See William Hanna, Memoirs of the Life and Writings of Thomas Chalmers (New York: Harper, 1857), vol. III, pp. 37-38. The initials P.M. on the plate stand for Peter Morris, the pseudonym that Lockhart adopted when writing Peter's Letters to His Kinsfolk (1819).

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir William Chambers by W. Bromley after F. Cotes
image.creator: Cotes, Francis
image.description: Engraved portrait of the British architect Sir William Chambers (1723-1796). Chambers is best known as the architect of Somerset House, London (1776-96). Reviewing James Boaden's Memoirs of the Life of John Philip Kemble for the Quarterly Review in June 1826, Sir Walter Scott recalled an incident at the Annual Dinner of the Royal Academy in Somerset House, which he had attended with Kemble. At the height of the meal, a massive chandelier had become partially dislodged, and disaster had been narrowly averted: 'If the absolute fall of the chandelier had taken place, it would have tried Chambers's architecture with a vengeance, and beyond a doubt must have penetrated through the floor to the very cellars of the building, carrying with it princes, dukes, painters, poets, musicians, amateurs -- and critics.' The original portrait was painted in 1764 by Francis Cotes.

image.title1: Charles V: From the Original by Holbein in the Private Collection of the King of the French
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Charles V by W. Holl after a painting by Holbein
image.creator: Holbein, Hans the younger
image.description: Engraved portrait of Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor (1500-1558). When, in chapter 6 of Sir Walter Scott's Guy Mannering (1815) Counsellor Pleydell abdicates the role of monarch in the game of High Jinks, he declares: 'Nay, then, sink state and perish sovereignty! for, like a second Charles V, we will abdicate, and seek in the private shades of life those pleasures which are denied to a throne.' In 1556 Charles V abdicated the thrones of the Holy Roman Empire, Spain, Naples, Sicily, the Burgundian Netherlands, and the Spanish colonies in America. Dividing his realms between his son Philip and his brother Ferdinand, he retired to a monastery. According to Scott's The Life of Napoleon Buonaparte (1827-28), the French Emperor also likened his own abdication to that of Charles V.

image.title1: Lord Chatham: From a Print by E. Fisher after a Picture by R. Brompton
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Lord Chatham by W. Holl from a picture by E. Brompton
image.creator: Brompton, Richard
image.description: Engraved portrait of the British statesman William Pitt, 1st Earl of Chatham (1708-1778) ('Pitt the Elder'). Sir Walter Scott records in his Journal that on 24 May 1828 the former Prime Minister Henry Addington, 1st Viscount Sidmouth showed him correspondence between Pitt the Elder and Anthony Addington (the Pitt family's physician and Sidmouth's father). Scott finds that Pitt's 'handwriting is strong and bold, and his expressions short and manly'. He notes many 'intimations of his partiality' for his son William and Pitt's concern for William's mania to copy him in all things. Comparing the correspondence of the two William Pitts, Scott reflects that Pitt the Younger lacked the 'lofty ideas' of his father, as evidenced in his very handwriting. He particularly contrasts Pitt the Elder's vigorous prosecution of war with France with Pitt the Younger's pacific instincts and tendency to underfund the armed forces, a point that Scott has previously made in his Life of Napoleon Buonaparte (1827-28). In 'The Highland Widow' (1827) Chatham is also praised for entrusting the defence of the colonies to Highlanders 'who, until his time, had been the objects of doubt, fear, and suspicion, on the part of each successive administration'. The original portrait by Brompton was painted in 1772 and the print made by Edward Fisher shortly afterwards.

image.title1: Chaucer. From a Limning in Occleve's Poems in the British Museum
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Chaucer by J. Thomson after Occleve
image.creator: Occleve
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English poet Geoffrey Chaucer (d. 1400). 'Of all Chaucer's multifarious powers', wrote Sir Walter Scott in his Life of Dryden (1808), 'none is more wonderful than the humour with which he touched upon natural frailty, and the truth with which he describes the inward feelings of the human heart'. Chaucer is frequently cited throughout Scott's works, particularly as an authoritative source on medieval life and manners. In Peveril of the Peak (ch. 21) and Woodstock (ch. 16), Scott introduces Chaucer enthusiasts who lament the neglect into which the poet has fallen. Chaucer's unpopularity continued into Scott's day, his project of a hundred-volume edition of the British poets foundering upon his insistence that it begin with Chaucer. A correspondent, Anna Seward, even wrote that Dryden, Spencer, and Chaucer seems to her 'overpraised' and that 'not one of them equals yourself or Southey' (29 January 1807).
