Scott replied that 'My admiration of Chaucer Spenser and Dryden does not blind me to their faults for I see the coarsness [sic] of the first the tediousness occasiond [sic] by the continued allegory of the second and the inequalities of the last but my dear Miss Seward "in these days were giants in the land" and we are but dwarfs beside them' (20 February 1807). The engraving by Thomson is taken after an illuminated portrait of Chaucer in a manuscript of Thomas Occleve's Regiment of Princes (1412).

image.title1: Lord Clarendon: From the Picture in the Bodleian Library, Oxford
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Lord Clarendon by C. E. Wagstaff
image.creator: Lely, Peter
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English politician and historian Edward Hyde, Earl of Clarendon. Sir Walter Scott frequently cited Clarendon's History of the Rebellion and Civil Wars in England. It proved an invaluable source for his Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829) and for his novels of 17th-century England, The Fortunes of Nigel (1822), Peveril of the Peak (1823), and Woodstock (1826). In a letter of 21 November 1821, Scott recommended that his son Charles read Clarendon: '[H]is stile [sic] is a little long-winded but on the other hand his Characters may match those of the Ancient historians and one thinks they would know the very men if you were to meet them in society: few English writers have the same precision either in describing the actors in great scenes or the actions which they performed. He was you are aware himself deeply engaged in the scenes which he describes and therefore mentions them with the individual feeling and sometimes doubtless with the partiality of a partizan [sic]. Yet I think he is on the whole a fair writer for though he always endeavours to excuse King Chas. yet he points out his mistakes and errors which certainly were neither few nor of slight consequence.' The engraving by Wagstaff is from an original portrait by Sir Peter Lely.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of John Clerk by J. Stewart
image.creator: Lockhart, John Gibson
image.description: Engraved portraits of Scottish judge John Clerk, Lord Eldin (1757-1832). Clerk was a colleague of Sir Walter Scott at the Scottish Bar and was appointed to the Bench as Lord Eldin in 1823. He was known as a great connoisseur and collector of art. Scott consulted him as to the authenticity of a painting purporting to show the head of Mary Queen of Scots following her execution (see letter to Robert Pitcairn, 18 September 1822). Eldin was also a fellow antiquarian and co-member of the Bannatyne Club. Lord Eldin's father, Sir John Clerk of Eldin, provided some of the inspiration for the antiquarian Jonathan Oldbuck in Scott's The Antiquary (1816) and owned Lasswade Cottage where Scott lived between 1798 and 1803. Lord Eldin's younger brother William, another advocate, was an intimate friend of Scott's. The initials P.M. on the plate stand for Peter Morris, the pseudonym that Lockhart adopted when writing Peter's Letters to His Kinsfolk (1819). In a letter to Lockhart of 23 March 1819 Scott particularly praised his character sketch of Lord Eldin.

image.title1: Coke: From a Picture in the Hall of Sergeant's Inn, Chancery Lane
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Sir Edward Coke by J. Posselwhite
image.creator: Janssen van Ceulen, Cornelius
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English judge and writer on law Sir Edward Coke (1552-1634). One of the most important jurists in English history, Coke is best-known for his Institutes of the Laws of England (1628-44). In chapter 8 of Sir Walter Scott's Rob Roy (1818), Justice Inglewood is reconciled to his office when his clerk, Joseph Jobson, reminds him of Coke's assertion that 'the whole Christian world hath not the like of it, so it be duly executed'. Scott also discusses Coke's unhappy marriage to Lady Elizabeth Hatton and their dispute over their daughter's marriage in a footnote to his edition of Secret History of the Court of James the First (1811). The engraving by Posselwhite is from an original portrait by Cornelius Janssen van Ceulen (1593-1661).

image.title1: Colbert: From the Original by P. Mignard in the Collection of the Institute at Paris
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Colbert by W. Holl after a picture by Pierre Mignard
image.creator: Mignard, Pierre
image.description: Engraved portrait of the French statesman Jean Baptiste Colbert (1619-1683). Colbert served as Louis XIV's minister of finance from 1665 to 1683 and is credited with saving the nation from bankruptcy. In Tales of a Grandfather, Fourth Series (1831), Scott praises his tolerant attitude to France's Protestant minority. He argues that Colbert's death deprived the Protestants of a powerful protector, exposing them to the persecutions of the chancellor Michel le Tellier and his son Louvois, and leading directly to the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes (1685). The original portrait by Pierre Mignard was painted in 1667.

image.title1: Captain Cook: From an Original picture by Dance in the Gallery of Greenwich Hospital
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Captain Cook by E. Scriven from a picture by Dance-Holland
image.creator: Dance-Holland, Nathaniel
image.description: Engraved portrait of the British explorer James Cook (1728-1779). Sir Walter Scott was named as literary executor to the poetess Anna Seward (1742-1809) and prepared a posthumous edition of her works (1810). In a biographical preface he recalled the immense popularity of her 'Elegy on Captain Cook' (1780). The poem was 'dictated by those feelings of admiration and gratitude, which in common with Europe at large, Miss Seward felt for the firm and benevolent character of the dauntless navigator, and for his tragical destiny'. The original portrait by Nathaniel Dance-Holland was painted in 1776.

image.title1: Nicolao Copernico: From a Picture in the Possession of the Royal Society Presented by Dr. Wolf of Danzic, June 6, 1776
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Copernicus by E. Scriven
image.creator: Lohrmann, Friedrich Anton
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Polish astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus (1473-1543). In a footnote to his edition of The Works of Jonathan Swift (1814) Sir Walter Scott alludes to the tradition that Copernicus discovered that the world revolved during a drunken fit. The engraving is from a portrait by an unknown artist copied by Friedrich Anton Lohrmann (ca. 1735-after 1776).

image.title1: Corneille: From an Original Picture by C. Lebrun in the Possession of the Institute of France
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Corneille by T. Woolnoth from a picture by C. Le Brun
image.creator: Le Brun, Charles
image.description: Engraved portrait of the French dramatist Pierre Corneille (1606-1684). In his 'Essay on the Drama' (1819) Scott credited Corneille with overcoming the arbitrary restrictions imposed on French Classical Drama by the observance of the Aristotelian unities of time, place, and action. Despite being 'surrounded by the worst possible models', he 'vanquished the taste of his age, the competition of his rivals, and the envy of Richelieu'. Scott nonetheless regrets that in his own 'Essay on Dramatic Poetry', Corneille helped to impose the observance of the unities on future generations of French dramatists, even though they had at times forced him to 'violate the rules of probability and common sense'. In his essay on 'Moli̬re' (1828), Scott considered the differences between the French classical tragedy of Corneille and Racine and the English tragedy of Shakespeare, and analysed the radically differing tastes of French and English audiences. In his The Life of Napoleon Bonaparte (1827-28), Scott attributed Napoleon's preference for Racine and Corneille over Voltaire to the fact that 'they wrote their immortal works for the meridian of a court, and at the command of the most monarchical of monarchs, Louis XIV'. Unlike Voltaire, their masterpieces contain 'nothing that can wound the ear of the most sensitive sovereign'. Corneille is, with Boileau, one of the authors for whom Frank Osbaldistone neglects his commercial studies in chapter 1 of Rob Roy (1818). The original portrait by Charles LeBrun was painted in 1647.

image.title1: Correggio: After a Head by Himself in the Cathedral of Parma
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Correggio by H. Meyer after a self-portrait
image.creator: Correggio
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Italian artist Correggio (1489?-1534). On first viewing Raphael's 'St Cecilia' at Bologna, Correggio exclaimed 'Anch'io son' pittore' ('I too am a painter!'). Sir Walter Scott quoted Correggio's words in a letter to Sir George Beaumont, dated 28 August 1825, to describe his passion for planning the buildings and plantations of his Abbotsford estate. In his Life of Napoleon Buonaparte (1827-28), Scott also describes how the peace treaty between the French general and the Duke of Parma (1796) stipulated for the delivery to France of twenty masterpieces from the Duke's collections, including Correggio's 'St Jerome'. The Duke offered two million 'livres' in place of the Correggio, but Napoleon replied that the millions would soon be spent, whereas the painting would be an ornament to Paris for ages, and would inspire future masterpieces.

image.title1: Cortez: From a Picture in the Florence Gallery
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Cortes by W. Holl
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Engraved portrait of Hernan Cort̩s (1485-1547), conqueror of Mexico. In Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft (1830), Scott cites an episode in the life of the conquistador Hernan Cort̩s (or Cort̩z) as an instance of the 'infectious character of superstition'. According to Bernal Diaz del Castillo's Historia verdadera de la Nueva Espana, Cort̩s did not himself see a vision of Saint Iago on a white horse which appeared to his soldiers and urged them on to a victory against great odds. Instead he saw a cavalier, named Francisco de Morla, mounted on a chestnut horse. Rather than concluding, however, that the vision was a figment of the collective imagination, Cort̩s exclaimed: 'Sinner that I am, what am I that I should have beheld the blessed apostle!' There are further references to Cort̩s in Rokeby (1813) and The Pirate (1821). In canto I, stanza 12 of the former Bertram Risingham describes the Battle of Marston Moor. If he had led such valiant men, he exclaims, he would not have sought 'El Dorados in the sky' but would have outstripped the conquests of Cort̩s and Pizarro (lines 19-28). In chapter 4 of The Pirate, Scott remarks that the Scottish plough that Triptolemus Yellowly seeks attempts to introduce to Shetland would seem stranger to a modern Scottish farmer 'than the corslets and casques of the soldiers of Cortes might seem to a regiment of our soldiers'. The engraving is taken after a portrait by an unknown artist in the Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence.

image.title1: Cowper: From a Picture in the Possession of the Publisher
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of William Cowper by W. Holl
image.creator: Abbott, Lemuel Francis
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English poet William Cowper (1731-1800). In both his published works and private correspondence, Sir Walter Scott frequently quoted Cowper's poetry, particularly 'The Task' which is cited in both The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818, ch. 1) and Saint Ronan's Well (1823, ch. 15). According to Basil Hall's Fragments of Voyages and Travels (1834), when sailing from Portsmouth Harbour in 1831, Scott asked to be shown the spot where the HMS Royal George was accidentally sunk. Scott then quoted the following lines from Cowper's 'Loss of the Royal George': 'His sword was in its sheath | His fingers held the pen, | Where Kempenfield went down | With twice four hundred men.' The engraving is derived from a portrait by Lemuel Francis Abbott (1792) probably via an earlier engraving by Henry Hoppner Meyer (1816).

image.title1: Cranmer: From an Original Picture in the Collection at Lambeth Palace
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Thomas Cranmer by W. Holl
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Engraved portrait of Thomas Cranmer (1489-1556), Archbishop of Canterbury and Protestant theologian. Although there appears to be no direct reference to Thomas Cranmer in Scott's works, he is significant as author of The Book of Common Prayer, attempts to introduce which into Scotland gave birth to the Covenanting movement. In Old Mortality (1816) the hero Henry Morton when awaiting death instinctively recites the 'petition for deliverance and for composure of spirit which is to be found in the Book of Common Prayer of the Church of England' (ch. 33). This is taken as evidence of treason to the Covenanting cause, and overcomes Ephraim MacBriar's reluctance to have him executed. The engraving is derived ultimately from a 16th-century woodcut by an unknown artist.

image.title1: Cromwell. From the Picture Presented by Cromwell to Coll. Rich, and Bequeathed by his great grandson, Sir Robt. Rich, Bar. to the British Museum
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Cromwell by E. Scriven after a painting by R. Walker
image.creator: Walker, Robert
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English statesman Oliver Cromwell (1599-1658). Cromwell figures prominently in Sir Walter Scott's novel Woodstock (1826), which revolves around the escape of King Charles II following his decisive defeat by Cromwell at the Battle of Worcester (3 September 1651). Cromwell also features in further works on the religious and civil conflicts of the sixteenth century, including Rokeby (1813) and Peveril of the Peak (1823). His occupation of Scotland is described in Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829). The original portrait by Robert Walker was painted ca. 1649.

image.title1: His Roy. Highs. Henry Frederick, Late Duke of Cumberland
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Henry Frederick, Duke of Cumberland by J. J. Jenkins after a painting by J. Reynolds
image.creator: Reynolds, Joshua, Sir (b.1723, d.1792)
image.description: Engraved vignette portrait of Henry Frederick, Duke of Cumberland (1745-1790). Henry Frederick, Duke of Cumberland and Strathearn, was the sixth child of Frederick, Prince of Wales and Augusta of Saxe-Gotha, and a younger brother of George III. He acceded to the Duchy in 1766, following the death of Prince William Augustus, known as 'Butcher Cumberland' for his persecution of the Jacobites following their defeat at Culloden. Sir Walter Scott portrays William Augustus in Waverley (1814) and Redgauntlet (1824). There appears to be no mention, however, of Henry Frederick in Scott's writings, although Scott's son Walter served under his successor Prince Ernest Augustus, Duke of Cumberland and Teviotdale.

image.title1: Cuvier: From an Original Drawing in the Possession of the Baroness Cuvier, at Paris
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait by J. Thomson
image.creator: Heim, Fran̤ois-Joseph
image.description: Engraved portrait of the French naturalist and zoologist Georges, Baron Cuvier (1769-1832). Sir Walter Scott's biographer and son-in-law J. G. Lockhart wrote that the deaths of Goethe, Scott, and Cuvier in 1832 saw Germany, Britain, and France simultaneously mourning over their greatest intellects, an observation made by a number of obituarists. Ralph Waldo Emerson in English Traits also noted erroneously that Scott and Cuvier shared the same date of birth, a mistake frequently repeated by later writers. The original portrait may be a drawing by Fran̤ois-Joseph Heim, now in the Louvre.

image.title1: Dante Alighieri: From a Print by Raffaelle Morghen after a Picture by Tofanelli
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Dante by C. E. Wagstaff after an original picture by Tofanelli
image.creator: Tofanelli, Stefano
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Italian poet Dante Alighieri (1265-1321). While a college student, Scott took private Italian lessons to be able to read Ariosto, Tasso, Boiardo, and Dante in the original. His admiration for Dante, however, was always qualified. Discussing the Inferno with Anna Seward, Scott complained that 'the plan appeared to him unhappy; the personal malignity and strange mode of revenge presumptuous and uninteresting'. In Italy in 1832, he told Captain Edward Cheney that he found Dante too obscure and difficult and thought it 'mortifying that Dante seemed to think nobody worth being sent to hell but his own Italians, whereas other people had every bit as great rogues in their families, whose misdeeds were suffered to pass with impunity'. Scott had forgotten that Dante had damned his own ancestor, the wizard Michael Scott. In chapter 12 of Rob Roy (1817), Diana Vernon seeks a pretext for a private interview with Frank Osbaldistone and asks for help deciphering a 'difficult passage' in the 'obscure Florentine's Divine Comedy. Frank's rival Rashleigh offers to accompany them as he is 'something better skilled [...] at tracking the sense of Dante through the metaphors and elisions of his wild and gloomy poem'. The print is derived from an earlier engraving by Raphael Morghen taken from a portrait by Stefano Tofanelli (1752-1812).

image.title1: Sir Humphrey Davy: From the Original Picture by Sir Thomas Lawrence, in the Possession of the Royal Society
image.title2: Steel engraving of Sir Humphry Davy by E. Scriven after a painting by T. Lawrence
image.creator: Lawrence, Thomas
image.description: Engraved portrait of the British scientist, inventor, and poet Sir Humphry Davy (1778-1829). Sir Walter Scott and Davy were fellow guests of William Wordsworth's at Dove Cottage, Grasemere, in August 1805. Scott 'liked him excessively' and was 'particularly delighted with the total absence of pedantry which has always appeared to me the test of true genius' (letter to Jane Kerr Apreece, 2 April 1811). Davy later made two visits to Scott at Abbotsford in 1820 and 1823. In 1812 Davy had become a member of Scott's extended family by marrying his widowed cousin Jane Kerr Apreece. As a favour to her Scott wrote a review of Davy's Salmoniana for the Quarterly Review in 1828. The original portrait by Sir Thomas Lawrence was painted ca. 1821.

image.title1: De Foe: From a Print by M. Vandergucht
image.title2: Steel engraving of Defoe by J. Thomson after a print by M. van der Gucht
image.creator: Taylor, Jeremiah
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English author Daniel Defoe (1661?-1731). According to John Robert Moore, it was Sir Walter Scott 'more than any other individual [...] who raised Defoe from obscurity in literary history to his modern position as a master of prose fiction' ('Defoe and Scott', PMLA, 56 (1941), 710-35). Scott edited the first collection of Defoe's novels for the Ballantyne Press (1809-10) and assembled many of his anonymous tracts in his edition of the Somers Tracts (1809-15). For Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott (1827), Scott added extensive critical remarks to the biographical sketch co-written with John Ballantyne that preceded his edition of Defoe's novels. This influential essay ascribed Defoe's appeal to 'the unequalled dexterity with which our author has given an appearance of REALITY to the incidents which he narrates'. Defoe's influence on Scott has been observed particularly in Old Mortality (1816), Rob Roy (1817), and The Pirate (1821). The engraving is derived from a 1703 print by Michael Vandergucht (1660-1725) itself engraved from a painting by Jeremiah Taylor (fl. 1700-50).

image.title1: Delambre: From the Original by Boilly in the Possession of Delambre's Family at Amiens
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Delambre by B. Holl after a painting by Boilly
image.creator: Boilly, Louis L̩opold
image.description: Engraved portrait of the French mathematician and astronomer J.B.J. Delambre (1749-1822). Delambre is best-known for preparing tables that plot the location of Uranus.

image.title1: Des Cartes: From the Original picture by Francis Hals in the Gallery of the Louvre
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Descartes by W. Holl after a painting by F. Hals
image.creator: Hals, Frans (b.1581, d.1666)
image.description: Engraved portrait of the French philosopher Rene Descartes (1596-1650). In Paul's Letters to His Kinsfolk, a record of Scott's visit to France and Belgium in 1815, Scott admires the monument to Descartes in the Mus̩e des monuments fran̤ais. The portrait by Hals was painted ca. 1649.

image.title1: Dollond: From an Original Picture in the Royal Observatory, Greenwich
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Dollond by J. Posselwhite
image.creator: Wilson, Benjamin
image.description: Engraved portrait of the British optician John Dollond (1706-1761). Dollond is best-known as the first person to patent the achromatic doublet. The original portrait is by Benjamin Wilson.

image.title1: Sir Andrew Snape Douglas: Omre Jun.r sculp.t 1795
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Andrew Snape Douglas (by Daniel Orme?)
image.creator: Orme, Daniel
image.description: Engraved portrait of the British naval officer Sir Andrew Snape Douglas. As Captain of the 'Queen Charlotte', Sir Andrew Snape Douglas fought in the Glorious First on 1 June 1794 and at the Battle of Groix on 23 June 1795. In the latter he suffered a head wound from which he would eventually die. Douglas also sat on the Court Martial that tried the Bounty mutineers. The portrait was probably engraved by the miniature painter and engraver Daniel Orme after his own design.

image.title1: Drake: From an Original Picture in the Possession of Sir T. F. Eliot Drake Bart. of Nutwell Court near Exeter
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Sir Francis Drake by W. Holl
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English sailor Sir Francis Drake (1540?-1596). In a footnote to chapter 7 of the Magnum Opus edition of Kenilworth (1831), Scott writes that 'Sir Francis Drake, Morgan, and many a bold buccaneer of those days, were, in fact, little better than pirates'. Indeed, in The Pirate (1821) Bunce laments that pirates can no longer achieve respectability whereas 'Old Drake, in Queen Bess's time, could plunder Peru and Mexico without a line of commission to shew for it, and blessed be her memory, he was knighted for it on his return' (vol, III, ch. 4). In the same novel, tales of Drake tempt Mordaunt Mertoun to join Captain Cleveland's pirate crew (I, 9).

image.title1: Dryden: From a Picture by Hudson in the Hall of Trinity College Cambridge
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Dryden by C. E. Wagstaff after a painting by T. Hudson
image.creator: Hudson, Thomas
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English poet John Dryden (1631-1700). In 1808, Scott published the first complete and uniform edition of Dryden's works which is still regarded as one of the best-edited projects in English. Scott immersed himself in the literary and controversial writings of Dryden's age, and his edition provides a vivid picture of Restoration England. It is prefaced by a 'Life of Dryden' in which Scott praises the poet for the 'power of ratiocination, of investigating, discovering, and appreciating that which is really excellent [...] accompanied with the necessary command of fanciful illustration and elegant expression'. Scott placed Dryden behind only Shakespeare and Milton, but argued that he excelled both in versatility and had 'no equal' as a lyric poet. No other writer is quoted as frequently as Dryden in Scott's published works. Dryden's dramas also influenced Scott's own portrayal of seventeenth-century England, particularly Absalom and Achitopel, which informs the portrayal of Charles II and his favourite Buckingham in Peveril of the Peak (1823).

image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Viscount Dundee by R. C. Bell after a picture by Williams
image.creator: Williams, R.
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Scottish soldier and nobleman John Graham of Claverhouse, Viscount Dundee (1648-1689). Claverhouse's campaign against the Covenanters is the subject of Sir Walter Scott's Old Mortality (1816). In a footnote to the Magnum Opus edition of the novel (1830), Scott writes: 'This remarkable person united the seemingly inconsistent qualities of courage and cruelty, a disinterested and devoted loyalty to his prince, with a disregard of the rights of his fellow-subjects. He was the unscrupulous agent of the Scottish Privy Council in executing the merciless severities of the government in Scotland during the reigns of Charles II. and James II.; but he redeemed his character by the zeal with which he asserted the cause of the latter monarch after the Revolution, the military skill with which he supported it at the battle of Killiecrankie, and by his own death in the arms of victory.' Scott was fascinated by the figure of Claverhouse, whom he believed had been traduced by Presbyterian historians, and displayed a portrait of him in his study at Castle Street, Edinburgh. Claverhouse is also portrayed in 'Wandering Willie's Tale' (1824) and in the song 'Bonnie Dundee' in Scott's play The Doom of Devorgoil (1830).

image.title1: Elizabeth: From the Picture in His Majesty's Collection at St. James's Palace
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Queen Elizabeth I by W. Holl after I. Oliver
image.creator: Oliver, Isaac I
image.description: Engraved portrait of Elizabeth I, Queen of England (1533-1603). The plot of Sir Walter Scott's novel Kenilworth (1821) centres around the ill-fated secret marriage of Queen Elizabeth I's favourite, the Earl of Leicester to Amy Robsart. Elizabeth figures prominently in the novel, particularly during the celebrations held in her honour at Kenilworth Castle. Elizabeth also features as a supporter of the Protestant cause in Scotland in The Monastery and The Abbot (1820). Her relations with Mary Queen of Scots are discussed in the latter novel and, at length, in Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829). The engraving is probably derived from a portrait by Isaac Oliver.

image.title1: Erasmus: From the Original Picture by G. Penn in his Majesty's Collection at Windsor
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Erasmus by E. Scriven after G. Pencz after H. Holbein the Younger
image.creator: Holbein, Hans the younger
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Dutch humanist Erasmus (d. 1536). There are a number of references to and borrowings from Erasmus in Sir Walter Scott's works. In The Antiquary (1815), Jonathan Oldbuck's German ancestor Aldobrand has conversed with Erasmus (ch. 11). In Kenilworth (1821), the pedantic schoolmaster Erasmus Holiday derives his name 'partly from his father having been the son of a renowned washerwoman, who had held that great scholar in clean linen all the while he was at Oxford' and partly due to 'the secret presentiment of his mother's mind that, in the babe to be christened, was a hidden genius, which should one day lead him to rival the fame of the great scholar of Amsterdam' (ch. 9). In Anne of Geierstein (1829), the description of a German tavern and of 15th-century Germany manners is derived, without acknowledgment, from Erasmus's dialogue Diversoria (ch. 19). There is a further quotation from Diversoria in chapter 1 of Saint Ronan's Well (1823). The engraving by Scriven is taken from a portrait by Georg Pencz which is itself, however, an enlargement of a portrait by Hans Holbein the Younger.

image.title1: Erskine: From the Original picture by Hoppner in his Majesty's collection at Windsor
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Baron Erskine by R. Woodman after a picture by Hoppner
image.creator: Hoppner, John
image.description: Engraved portrait of the lawyer and Whig politician Baron Thomas Erskine (1750-1823). Erskine was Lord Chancellor from 1806 to 1807. In his Journal for 20 April 1829, Sir Walter Scott describes him as 'positively mad', recalling 'him tell a cock-and-a-bull story of having seen the ghost of his father's servant, John Burnet, with as much sincerity as if he believed every word he was saying'. Scott refers to the same episode in slightly more measured terms in a letter to Lady Abercorn (13 September 1822), describing Lord Londonderry 'as the only man I ever heard affirm that he had seen an apparition excepting Lord Erskine a person of so flighty a character that one does not wonder at anything he could say'. Scott credited Erskine with a portion of his family's wit but of a 'moody and maddish' kind. He acknowledged, however, that 'I never saw him in his best days' (Journal, 20 April 1829). The original portrait by John Hoppner was painted in 1787 or 1788.

image.title1: Euler: From a Picture by A. Lorgna in the Collection of the Institute of France
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Euler by B. Holl after a painting by A. Lorgna
image.creator: Lorgna, A
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Swiss mathematician and physicist Leonhard Euler (1707-1783).

image.title1: F̩n̩lon [sic]: From the Original Picture by Vivien in the Collection at the Louvre
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of F̩nelon by J. Thomson after a painting by Vivien
image.creator: Vivien, Joseph
image.description: Engraved portrait of the French theologian and novelist Francois de Salignac de la Mothe-F̩nelon (1651-1715). In his Introduction to the Magnum Opus edition of Quentin Durward (1831), Sir Walter Scott quotes F̩nelon's description of the paranoid solitude of the tyrant Pygmalion in Book 3 of Les Aventures de T̩l̩maque (1699). In common with most scholars, Sir Walter Scott believes that in Pygmalion F̩nelon intended to portray Louis XI of France. Scott's own portrayal of Louis in Quentin Durward owes much to F̩nelon's Pygmalion.

image.title1: John Flaxman: From the Original Picture by John Jackson in the Possession of the Right Hon. Lord Dover
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of John Flaxman by R. Woodman after a painting by John Jackson
image.creator: Jackson, John
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English sculptor and designer John Flaxman (1755-1826). Sir Walter Scott's friend George Ellis suggested that he invite Flaxman to illustrate The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805). Scott feared, however, that Flaxman's style was 'too classical to stoop to body forth my Gothic Borderers' and that there would be 'some risk of their resembling the antique of Homer's heroes, rather than the iron race of Salvator' (letter of 21 August 1804). Scott had, in fact, already arranged to have the volume illustrated by engravings from paintings by John James Masquerier. Flaxman himself was no admirer of Scott. According to Crabb Robinson's diary, he remarked to Samuel Rogers that 'his works have in no respect tended to improve the moral condition of mankind'. The original portrait by John Jackson was painted in the mid-1820s.

image.title1: The Right Hon.ble Chas. James Fox: Principal Secretary of State for the Foreign Department andcandcandc
image.title2: Engraved portrait by James Ogbourne
image.creator: Ogbourne, James
image.description: Engraved vignette portrait of the British statesman Charles James Fox (1749-1806). When, in 1806, Scott's political patron Henry Dundas, 1st Viscount Melville, was acquitted of misappropriation of public funds, Sir Walter Scott composed a celebratory song which mocked Melville's Whig opponents Samuel Whitbread and Charles James Fox: 'But the Brewer we'll hoax, | Tallyho to the Fox, | And drink MELVILLE for ever, as long as we live!' ('Health to Lord Melville', lines 82-84). These lines, composed when Fox was gravely ill, gave serious offence to his supporters and cost Scott the friendship of Dugald Stewart and the Countess of Rosslyn. Scott made partial amends by praising Fox's patriotism in the Introduction to Canto I of Marmion (1808): 'When Europe crouch'd to France's yoke, | And Austria bent, and Prussia broke, | And the firm Russian's purpose brave, | Was barter'd by a timorous slave, | Even then dishonour's peace he spurn'd, | The sullied olive-branch return'd, | Stood for his country's glory fast, | And nail'd her colours to the mast!' (lines 154-161). In the Introduction to the 1830 edition of Marmion, Scott recalls his reluctance to appeal to Fox to sort out a clerical error jeopardizing his appointment as Principal Clerk to the Court of Session. He feared that it might appear an expression of 'political opinions different from those which I have always professed', although 'in his private capacity, there is no man to whom I would have been more proud to owe an obligation'. Scott was also told that Fox admired his Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), and wrote: 'Although my Tory principles prevent my coinciding with his political opinions, I am very proud of his approbation in a literary sense' (letter to George Ellis, 26 May 1805). The engraving may derive from a painting by John Raphael Smith.

image.title1: Charles James Fox: From a Picture by Sir Joshua Reynolds in the Possession of Lord Holland
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Charles James Fox by J. W. Cook after a painting by Sir Joshua Reynolds
image.creator: Reynolds, Joshua, Sir (b.1723, d.1792)
image.description: Engraved portrait of the British statesman Charles James Fox (1749-1806). When, in 1806, Scott's political patron Henry Dundas, 1st Viscount Melville, was acquitted of misappropriation of public funds, Sir Walter Scott composed a celebratory song which mocked Melville's Whig opponents Samuel Whitbread and Charles James Fox: 'But the Brewer we'll hoax, | Tallyho to the Fox, | And drink MELVILLE for ever, as long as we live!' ('Health to Lord Melville', lines 82-84). These lines, composed when Fox was gravely ill, gave serious offence to his supporters and cost Scott the friendship of Dugald Stewart and the Countess of Rosslyn. Scott made partial amends by praising Fox's patriotism in the Introduction to Canto I of Marmion (1808): 'When Europe crouch'd to France's yoke, | And Austria bent, and Prussia broke, | And the firm Russian's purpose brave, | Was barter'd by a timorous slave, | Even then dishonour's peace he spurn'd, | The sullied olive-branch return'd, | Stood for his country's glory fast, | And nail'd her colours to the mast!' (lines 154-161). In the Introduction to the 1830 edition of Marmion, Scott recalls his reluctance to appeal to Fox to sort out a clerical error jeopardizing his appointment as Principal Clerk to the Court of Session. He feared that it might appear an expression of 'political opinions different from those which I have always professed', although 'in his private capacity, there is no man to whom I would have been more proud to owe an obligation'. Scott was also told that Fox admired his Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), and wrote: 'Although my Tory principles prevent my coinciding with his political opinions, I am very proud of his approbation in a literary sense' (letter to George Ellis, 26 May 1805). The original portrait was painted by Reynolds in 1782-83.

image.title1: Franklin: From an Original picture by J. A. [sic] Duplessis in the Possession of Mr. Barnet Consul General for the United States of America at Paris
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Benjamin Franklin by J. Thomson after a painting by J. A. Duplessis
image.creator: Duplessis, Joseph Siffred
image.description: Engraved portrait of Benjamin Franklin (1706-1790), American author, publisher, scientist, inventor, and diplomat. Walter Scott quotes from the maxims of Benjamin Franklin in letters to Alexander Ballantyne (24 April 1817) and Daniel Terry (18 February 1824). The original portrait by Duplessis was painted in 1778.

image.title1: Frederick II: From the original by Carlo Vanloo in the private collection of the King of the French
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Frederick II of Prussia by E. Scriven from a picture by Carlo Vanloo
image.creator: Loo, Carle van
image.description: Engraved portrait of Frederick II ('the Great'), King of Prussia (1712-1786). In Munich in May 1832, Sir Walter Scott admired the coat, pistols, saddle and bridle of Frederick the Great. He had earlier advised his soldier son Walter to read Frederick's instructions to light troops as 'he was the first who reduced that important part of an army to system and principle' (letter of 27 June 1820). In his Life of Napoleon Buonaparte (1827-28), Scott describes the King of Prussia and Tsar of Russia swearing to liberate Germany on Frederick the Great's tomb. In Paul's Letters to His Kinsfolk (1815), he unfavourably compares Napoleon who plundered the artistic treasures of Dresden with Frederick who was content to admire them.

image.title1: Galileo: From a picture by Ramsay in Trinity College, Cambridge
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Galileo by R. Hart after a painting by Ramsay
image.creator: Suttermans, Justus
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei (1564-1642). In May 1832 Sir Walter Scott visited the Basilica di Santa Croce in Florence where he would have seen Galileo's tomb. The painting by Ramsay is copied from an original portrait by Justus Sustermans in the Palazzo Pitti, Florence.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of George II by S. F. Ravenet probably after T. Worlidge
image.creator: Worlidge, Thomas
image.description: Engraved profile portrait of George II, King of Great Britain (1683-1760). Sir Walter Scott's first novel Waverley (1814) is set during the Jacobite Rebellion of 1745-46 which sought to place Charles Edward Stewart on the British throne in place of the Hanoverian George II. The hero, Edward Waverley, is arrested on a charge of 'levying war against the king, the highest delinquency of which a subject can be guilty' (ch. 31). A further fictional rebellion against George II is described in Redgauntlet (1824). Here the ultimate failure of the Jacobite cause is proved by the reading of George II's personal orders to let the conspirators return in peace to the Continent (ch. 23). The Jacobite Rebellions are also described in Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1829), where Scott terms Georges I and II 'men of honour, courage, and good sense; but, being born and educated foreigners [...] strangers to the peculiar character, no less than to the very complicated form of government, of the country over which they were called by Providence to reign'. Despite Scott's insistence on George II's 'good sense', there are references in The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818) to his notorious temper. Miss Damahoy has heard 'that King George flang his periwig in the fire when he heard o' the Porteous mob', kicked Sir Robert Walpole, and, according to Bartholomew Saddletree 'was for kicking the Duke of Argylle too'. Miss Damahoy concludes that 'he might keep mair wit in his anger' (ch. 23). In the same novel Jeanie Deans successfully pleads with Queen Caroline to intercede with George II to pardon her sister Effie. The engraving by Ravenet is probably derived from a 1753 painting by Thomas Worlidge.

image.title1: His Majesty King George the IV: Born August 12 1762
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of George IV
image.creator: Phillips, Thomas
image.description: Engraved vignette portrait of George IV, King of Great Britain (1762-1830) with geometrical surround design. George IV, both as Prince Regent and King, bestowed a number of favours upon Sir Walter Scott. In 1813 he offered Scott the post of Poet Laureate (which Scott refused in favour of Robert Southey). In 1815 he twice invited Scott to dine with him and granted him free access to the Regent's Library, where Scott consulted papers on the Jacobite Rebellions of 1715 and 1745-46. In 1818 Scott became the first man to be knighted under George IV and the first ever to be knighted in recognition of literary merit. When the new king commissioned Sir Thomas Lawrence to paint the most distinguished men of the age for the great gallery at Windsor Castle, he desired that Scott be foremost amongst the men of science and letters. For his part, Scott played a leading role in organizing the visit of King George IV to Edinburgh in 1822, the first visit of a Hanoverian monarch to Scotland. The 'Magnum Opus' edition of the Waverley Novels is dedicated to the King. The uncredited engraving is based on a painting by Thomas Phillips and closely resembles an engraving by Luigi Schiavonetti in the National Portrait Gallery.

image.title1: Gibbon: From a Print by Jas. Hall after a Picture by Sir Joshua Reynolds
image.title2: Steel engraving of Edward Gibbon by W. Holl after a painting by J. Reynolds
image.creator: Reynolds, Joshua, Sir (b.1723, d.1792)
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English historian Edward Gibbon (1737-1794). Edward Gibbon, best known for his History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire (1776-88), was a constant source and model for Sir Walter Scott, particularly in Count Robert of Paris (1831), which drew extensively on Gibbon's account of the Byzantine Empire under the Komnenian Restoration. The Introduction to the novel quotes extensively from Gibbon's judgment of the princess and historian Anna Komnene or Comnena. The original portrait by Sir Joshua Reynolds was painted ca. 1779. The engraving by Holl is based on an earlier engraving by John (not James) Hall published in 1780.

image.title1: Goethe: From a Picture by George Dawe. Esqr. RA in the Possession of Henry Dawe Esq
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Goethe by J. Posselwhite after a painting by George Dawe
image.creator: Dawe, George
image.description: Engraved portrait of the German author Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749-1832). Sir Walter Scott began his literary career with a series of translations from contemporary German literature. Of Goethe, the European writer whom Scott most admired, he translated Goetz of Berlichingen (1799), 'The Erl-King' (1799), 'Frederick and Alice' (1800), and 'Lamentation of the Faithful Wife of Asan Aga' (1806). Scott described Goethe as 'a wonderful fellow, the Ariosto at once, and almost the Voltaire of Germany' (Journal, 15 February 1827) and acclaimed him as 'an author born to arouse the slumbering fame of his country' (Introduction to 'Magnum' edition of Anne of Geierstein, 1831). Scott was bitterly disappointed that Goethe's death on 22 March 1832 thwarted a long-cherished plan to visit him at Weimar. Goethe, in his turn, was a great admirer of the Waverley Novels, praising Scott in a letter of 12 January 1827 for his 'wonderful pictures of human life'. Deeply flattered, Scott sent Goethe a copy of his Life of Napoleon Buonaparte and hailed him as 'the father of the German literature' (letter of 9 July 1827). The original portrait by George Dawe was painted in 1819.

image.title1: Rev. James Grahame, Author of "The Sabbath." andC
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Rev. James Grahame by S. Freeman
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Scottish poet the Rev. James Grahame (1765-1811). Sir Walter Scott was a great admirer of James Grahame's The Sabbath (1804), 'a very pretty poem' which he recommended to James Currie and Anna Seward in letters of 25 February and 21 March 1805. John Ballantyne and Co., in which Scott held a half-share, published his British Georgics (1809). Grahame was a fellow Advocate who abandoned the Bar to take orders as an Anglican clergyman. Scott sought unsuccessfully to use his influence to have Grahame elected to the Lectureship of St George's Chapel, Edinburgh, in October 1808. On his death in 1811, Scott lamented him as 'one good man lost to the best of possible worlds' who 'had conscience and modesty enough for a whole General Assembly or Convocation' (letter to Charles Kirkpatrick Sharpe, 4 December 1811). He regretted however that his 'principles and prejudices and feelings made an odd jumble', hampering both his legal and ecclesiastical careers. He was a Jacobite yet a Whig, an Anglican yet an apologist for the Covenanters. Scott recalled teasing him for his detestation of his own kinsman John Graham of Claverhouse. Grahame is also mentioned in Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft as sharing the family superstition that the colour green is fatal to the Grahame clan, and having his library table covered in blue or black cloth.

image.title1: Grotius: From an Original Picture by M.J. Mirevelt in the Possession of the Publisher
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Grotius by J. Posselwhite after a painting by M. J. van Miereveld
image.creator: Miereveld, Michiel Jansz van (b.1567, d.1641)
image.description: Engraved portrait of the Dutch jurist and scholar Hugo Grotius (1583-1645). In chapter 1 of A Legend of Montrose (1819), Sir Walter Scott quotes Grotius's condemnation of mercenaries: 'Nullum vitae genus est improbius, quam eorum, qui sine causae respectu mercede conducti, militant' ('There is no more immoral way of life than that of these men who, regardless of the cause, fight for money'). Equally, when in Old Mortality (1816), James Graham of Claverhouse laments the Covenanters' contempt for the 'laws of war', he is referring to Grotius's De jure belli ac pacis libri (1625). In a letter to his son Captain Walter Scott of 25 December 1827, Scott hopes that his younger son Charles is busy studying 'Grotius, Puffendorf and others of that class of jurists' in order to obtain a post at the Foreign Office. The original portrait by Miereveld was painted in 1614.

image.title1: Gustavus Adolphus: From a Print by Paul Pontius after a Picture by Van Dyck
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Gustavus Adolphus by J. Posselwhite after a painting by Van Dyck
image.creator: Dyck, Anthony van (b.1599, d.1641)
image.description: Engraved portrait of Gustavus Adolphus, King of Sweden (1594-1632). Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden achieved renown as a military commander during the Thirty Years War (1618-48) with the aid of a brigade of Scottish mercenaries. In Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819), the soldier of fortune Captain Dalgetty refers constantly to his service under 'that invincible monarch, the bulwark of the Protestant faith, the Lion of the North, the terror of Austria, Gustavus the Victorious' (ch. 2). Captain Dalgetty's horse Gustavus is named in honour of his former commander. In Old Mortality (1816), Henry Morton considers taking up arms abroad: 'Perhaps some lucky chance may raise me to a rank with our Ruthvens, our Lesleys, our Monroes, the chosen leaders of the famous Protestant champion, Gustavus Adolphus' (ch. 6). Gustavus Adolphus's Scottish brigade is also discussed in Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829).

image.title1: Hale: From an Original Picture in the Library of Lincolns Inn
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Sir Matthew Hale by J. W. Cook after a painting by John Michael Wright
image.creator: Wright, John Michael
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English jurist Sir Matthew Hale (1609-1676). In Letter VIII of Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft (1830), Sir Walter Scott regrets to quote 'the venerable and devout Sir Matthew Hales [sic]', as presiding at a trial in 1644 which saw two women Amy Dunny and Rose Callender hanged as witches on the flimsiest evidence. 'But no man', adds Scott, 'unless very peculiarly circumstanced, can extricate himself from the prejudices of his nation and age.' Scott had previously published the final recommendations of the Hale Committee (1652) on law reform in the Somers Tracts, vol. VI (1811). He quoted from this document in his own 'Essay on Juridical Reform' (1810). The original portrait was painted ca. 1670.

image.title1: Halley: From an Original Picture Ascribed to Dahl in the Possession of the Royal Society
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Edmond Halley by W. T. Fry from a picture ascribed to Dahl
image.creator: Dahl, Michael
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English astronomer Edmond Halley (1656-1742). The original portrait was painted in 1736.

image.title1: Hampden: From a Print by J. Houbraken 1740
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of John Hampden by J. Posselwhite after a print by J. Houbraken
image.creator: Houbraken, Jacobus
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English parliamentarian John Hampden (1594-1643). Hampden was staunchly opposed to autocratic rule of Charles I, particularly the King's attempts to levy the 'ship money' tax. There are several references to Hampden in Scott's novels of 17th-century England and Scotland. In Old Mortality (1816), the putative narrator Peter Pattieson writes that many Covenanters 'united the independent sentiments of a Hampden with the suffering zeal of a Hooper or Latimer' (ch. 1). In Woodstock (1826), the hostility of the wolfhound Bevis to the fugitive Charles II leads the King to believe that 'the spirit of Pym or Hampden has transmigrated into the rogue and continues to demonstrate his hatred against royalty and all its adherents' (ch. 24). In an Appendix to the Introduction to the 'Magnum Opus' edition of Peveril of the Peak (1831), Scott writes that 'the adventures ascribed to "historical characters" would, however, fail in their moral aim, if fiction were placed at variance with truth; if Hampden or Sydney, for example, were painted as swindlers'. Finally, a note to the 'Magnum' edition of Ivanhoe (1830) reveals that Scott borrowed his hero's name 'from a manor forfeited by the ancestor of the celebrated Hampden, for striking the Black Prince a blow with his racket, when they quarrelled at tennis'.

image.title1: Handel: From a Picture in the Collection of His Majesty at Windsor
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of Handel by J. Thomson after a painting by T. Hudson
image.creator: Hudson, Thomas
image.description: Engraved portrait of the German-British composer Georg Friedrich Handel (1685-1759). Sir Walter Scott was, by his own admission, no connoisseur of music. When his wife Charlotte attended the Edinburgh Music Festival in 1815, the highlight of which was a performance of Handel's Messiah, Scott preferred to stay at Abbotsford. He wrote that he was 'delighted with your having found the gaieties of the time acceptable' but that he would not 'give one "wheeble of a whaup" from the moss at Keaside for all the fine music you have heard' (letter of 11 November 1805). Scott nonetheless named Handel as pre-eminent in the art of music in his Life of Dryden (1808), where Handel's setting of Dryden's 'Alexander's Feast' is discussed. Handel is also quoted as identifying the morris dance as the quintessential English dance in a note to the Magnum Opus edition of The Fair Maid of Perth (1832). This engraving is based on a 1756 portrait of Handel by Thomas Hudson, now in the National Portrait Gallery.

image.title1: John Harrison: From an Engraving by Tassaert, Published in 1768, after a Painting by King
image.title2: Steel engraved portrait of John Harrison by W. Holl after a painting by T. King
image.creator: King, Thomas
image.description: Engraved portrait of the English horologist John Harrison. The English horologist John Harrison is best known for inventing the first practical marine chronometer, enabling navigators to compute accurately their longitude at sea. This engraving by William Holl is based on a previous engraving by Philippe Joseph Tassaert. The original portrait by Thomas King was painted in 1767.

image.title1: [Title page of Scott's poem The Lay of the Last Minstrel with vignette engraving by J. Pye from a drawing by R. Westall]
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Vignette depiction of the Minstrel's harp with a castle and mounted figures in the background.

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's poem The Lay of the Last Minstrel
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts the Lady of Branksome Hall listening to the voices of the Mountain Spirit and River Spirit (Lay of the Last Minstrel, canto I, stanza 18). Illustrates canto I, stanza 18, lines 9-10: 'She raised her stately head, | And her heart throbbed high with pride'.

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's poem The Lay of the Last Minstrel
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Sir William Deloraine addressing the monk of St Mary's (Lay of the Last Minstrel, canto II, stanza 5). Illustrates canto II, stanza 5, lines 3-4: 'And, dar'st thou, warrior! seek to see | What Heaven and Hell alike would hide?'

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's poem The Lay of the Last Minstrel
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts the Lady of Branksome Hall discovering the wounded Deloraine (Lay of the Last Minstrel, canto III, stanza 22). Illustrates canto III, stanza 22, lines 7-8: 'She thought some spirit of the sky | Had done the bold moss-trooper wrong'.

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's poem The Lay of the Last Minstrel
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Tinlinn telling the Lady of Branksome Hall of the approach of the English army (Lay of the Last Minstrel, canto IV, stanza 6). Illustrates canto IV, stanza 6, lines 1-3: 'Thus to the ladye did Tinlinn shew | The Tidings of the English foe:- | Belted Will Howard is marching here'.

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's poem The Lay of the Last Minstrel
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts the Lady of Branksome Hall reunited with her rescued son, with Lord Cranstoun kneeling at her feet (Lay of the Last Minstrel, canto V, stanza 25). Illustrates canto V, stanza 25, lines 5-6: 'Yet not Lord Cranstoun deigned she greet, | Though low he kneeled at her feet'.

image.title2: Steel engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by R. Westall of a scene from Scott's poem The Lay of the Last Minstrel
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts the Abbot of Melrose Abbey blessing pilgrims on the day of penitence (Lay of the Last Minstrel, canto VI, stanza 31). Illustrates canto VI, stanza 31 (not stanza 30 as stated), lines 10-11: 'The mitred abbot stretched his hand, | And blessed them as they kneeled'.

image.title1: [Title page of Scott's poem Marmion with vignette engraving by J. Pye from a drawing by R. Westall]
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Marmion's coat of armour propped against a shrine.

image.title2: Engraving by F. Engleheart from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Sir Ralph de Wilton in the guise of a palmer confronting Marmion (Marmion, canto I, stanza 28). Illustrates canto I, stanza 28: 'For no saluting did he wait, | But strode across the hall of state, | And fronted Marmion where he sate'.

image.title2: Engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Constance de Beverley on trial before the Abbot of St. Cuthbert and the Abbess of St. Hilda (Marmion, canto II, stanza 21). Illustrates canto II, stanza 21, lines 5-6: 'Her look composed, and steady eye, | Bespoke a matchless constancy'.

image.title2: Engraving by S. Noble from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Sir Ralph de Wilton, disguised as a palmer, facing Marmion in the hostel (Marmion, canto III, stanza 5). Illustrates canto III, stanza 5, lines 5-7: 'Still fixed on Marmion was his look, | Which he, who ill such gaze could brook, | Strove by a frown to quell'.

image.title2: Engraving by J. Mitan from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts King James IV listening to Lady Heron sing 'Lochinvar' (Marmion, canto V, stanza 12). Illustrates canto V, stanza 12, lines 1-2: 'The monarch o'er the siren hung, | And beat the measure as she sung'.

image.title2: Engraving by J. Heath from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem Marmion
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts the dying Marmion at Flodden Field, attended by Clara de Clare and a monk (Marmion, canto VI, stanza 32). Illustrates canto VI, stanza 32, lines 28-29: 'Charge, Chester, charge! On, Stanley, on!' | Were the last words of Marmion.'

image.title1: [Title page of Scott's poem The Lady of the Lake with vignette engraving by J. Pye after R. Westall]
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts the 'Harp of the North' hung on the witch-elm that shades St. Fillan's Spring (Lady of the Lake, canto I, stanza 1). Illustrates canto I, stanza 1, lines 1-6: 'Harp of the North! that mouldering long hast hung | On the witch-elm that shades Saint Fillan's spring | And down the fitful breeze thy numbers flung, | Till envious ivy did around thee cling, | Muffling with verdant ringlet every string,-- | O Minstrel Harp, still must thine accents sleep?'

image.title2: Engraving by C. Heath from a drawing by R. Westall of the heroine of Scott's poem The Lady of the Lake
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Ellen Douglas hearing James Fitz-James's hunting horn (Lady of the Lake, canto I, stanza 17). Illustrates canto I, stanza 17, lines 23-24: 'In listening mood, she seemed to stand, | The guardian Naiad of the strand.'

image.title2: Engraving by F. Engleheart from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem The Lady of the Lake
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Ellen Douglas waving farewell to James Fitz-James with the harper Allan-bane in the foreground (Lady of the Lake, canto II, stanza 6). Illustrates canto II, stanza 6, lines 3-4: 'But when he turned him to the glade, | One courteous parting sign she made.'

image.title2: Engraving by J. Romney from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem The Lady of the Lake
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Brian the Hermit brandishing the Cross of Fire, with Roderick Dhu at his side (Lady of the Lake, canto III, stanza 10). Illustrates canto II, stanza 10, lines 10-11: 'Woe to the wretch who fails to rear | At this dread sign the ready spear!'

image.title2: Engraving by F. Engleheart from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem The Lady of the Lake
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Ellen Douglas's surprise at the sudden appearance of James Fitz-James, with the harper Allan-bane in the background (Lady of the Lake, canto IV, stanza 16). Illustrates canto IV, stanza 16, lines 7-8: 'Ellen beheld as in a dream, | Then, starting, scarce suppressed a scream'.

image.title2: Engraving by R. Golding from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem The Lady of the Lake
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Ellen Douglas at the feet of James Fitz-James (aka James V of Scotland) (Lady of the Lake, canto VI, stanza 27). Illustrates canto VI, stanza 27, lines 5-6: 'No word her choking voice commands,-- | She showed the ring'.

image.title1: [Title page of Scott's Glenfinlas, and Other Ballads, with vignette engraving by W.B. Cooke after R. Westall]
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts a cross thrown from an altar during the Moorish occupation of Spain (Vision of Don Roderick, canto II, stanza 23). Illustrates The Vision of Don Roderick, canto II, stanza 23, lines 5-6: 'Then too, the holy cross, salvation's sign, | By impious hands was from the altar thrown.'

image.title2: Engraving by R. Golding from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem Glenfinlas
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts a spirit in the form of Flora of Glengyle appearing before the seer Moy (Glenfinlas, stanza 40). Illustrates stanza 40, lines 3-4: 'As, bending o'er the dying gleam, | She wrung the moisture from her hair.' The ballad-imitation Glenfinlas, one of Scott's earliest original compositions, was first published in Matthew Lewis's Tales of Wonder (1801) and reprinted in The Minstrelsy of the Scottish Borders, vol. II (1802).

image.title2: Engraving by S. Noble from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem The Vision of Don Roderick
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts the Bishop of Toledo after hearing Don Roderick's confession (Vision of Don Roderick, canto II, stanza 8). Illustrates canto II, stanza 8, line 9: 'He stay'd his speech abrupt, and up the prelate stood.'

image.title2: Engraving by A. Raimbach from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem The Vision of Don Roderick
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Don Roderick and the Bishop of Toledo beholding a future vision of Don Roderick's defeat at the hands of the Moors (Vision of Don Roderick, canto II, stanza 21). Illustrates canto II, stanza 21, lines 8-9: '"Rivers ingulph him!" "Hush," in shuddering tone | The Prelate said; "Rash Prince, yon vision'd form's thine own."'

image.title2: Engraving by A. Smith from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem Cadyow Castle
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts the ghosts of Bothwellhaugh's wife and infant child, murdered by the Regent Moray's men (Cadyow Castle, stanza 25). Illustrates stanza 25, lines 1-2: 'What sheeted phantom wanders wild, | Where mountain Eske through woodland flows'. The ballad-imitation Cadyow Castle was first published in The Minstrelsy of the Scottish Borders, vol. III (1803).

image.title2: Engraving by F. Engleheart from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem Thomas the Rhymer
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Thomas the Rhymer bidding farewell to his home of Ercildoune (present-day Earlston, Berwickshire) (Thomas the Rhymer, part III, stanza 38). Illustrates part III, stanza 38, lines 3-4: 'And there, before Lord Douglas' face, | With them he cross'd the flood.' This modern continuation of the ancient ballad Thomas the Rhymer was first published in The Minstrelsy of the Scottish Borders, vol. II (1802).

image.title2: Engraving by F. Engleheart from a drawing by R. Westall illustrating a scene from Scott's poem Helvellyn
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Charles Gough's dog guarding his master's corpse from predators on the slopes of Helvellyn, Lake District(Helvellyn, stanza 2). Illustrates stanza 2, lines 7-8: 'The much-loved remains of her master defended, | And chased the hill-fox and the raven away.' This poem was inspired by the death by exposure of Charles Gough on Helvellyn in the Lake District, April 1805. It was first published in A Collection of Scottish Airs (Edinburgh: William Whyte, 1806).

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Williamina, Lady Forbes by C.H. Jeens
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Portrait of Williamina Belsches (1776-1810), later Lady Forbes of Pitsligo, Walter Scott's first love.

image.title1: Anne Scott, Second Daughter of Sir Walter Scott
image.title2: Portrait of Anne Scott engraved by G.B. Shaw after W. Nicholson
image.creator: Nicholson, William
image.description: Portrait of Walter Scott's younger daughter Anne Scott (1803-1833) at the age of fifteen. The original portrait by William Nicholson was painted in 1818.

image.title1: Anne Rutherford, Mother of Sir Walter Scott
image.title2: Portrait of Anne Rutherford Scott engraved by G.B. Shaw after J.W. Gordon
image.creator: Gordon, John Watson, Sir (b.1788, d.1864)
image.description: Portrait of Walter Scott's mother, Anne Rutherford Scott (d. 1819).

image.title1: Mrs J.G. Lockhart, Elder Daughter of Sir Walter Scott
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Charlotte Sophia Scott after W. Nicholson
image.creator: Nicholson, William
image.description: Portrait of Walter Scott's older daughter Charlotte Sophia (1799-1837) at the age of nineteen in Norwegian peasant dress. Charlotte Sophia Scott married Scott's future biographer John Gibson Lockhart on 29 April 1820. The original portrait by William Nicholson was painted in 1818.

image.title2: Portrait of Charlotte, Lady Scott, engraved by G.B. Shaw after J. Saxon
image.creator: Saxon, James
image.description: Three-quarter portrait of Walter Scott's wife, Charlotte, nee Carpenter (or Charpentier) (1770-1826) at the age of forty. The original portrait by James Saxon was painted in 1810 and is on display at Abbotsford House.

image.title1: Walter Scott. Surnamed "Beardie", Great-Grandfather of Sir Walter Scott
image.title2: Portrait of Walter Scott of Raeburn engraved by G.B. Shaw
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Three-quarter portrait of Walter Scott's great-grandfather, Walter Scott, 1st Laird of Raeburn (1653-1729). Walter Scott of Raeburn was known as 'Beardie' having sworn not to shave until the Stuarts were restored to the crown of Scotland. His property was confiscated following his participation in the Jacobite Rebellion of 1715. The painter of the original portrait is unknown.

image.title1: Walter Scott, Writer to the Signet, Father of Sir Walter Scott
image.title2: Portrait of Walter Scott, W.S., engraved by G.B. Shaw
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Three-quarter portrait of Sir Walter Scott's father, Walter Scott, W.S. (1729-1799), in his late twenties. The original portrait was painted c. 1758 by an unknown artist.

image.title2: Facsimile reproduction of a print portrait of J.G. Lockhart by Daniel Maclise
image.creator: Maclise, Daniel
image.description: Sketch of Sir Walter Scott's son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart. The writer and editor John Gibson Lockhart was Scott's son-in-law and biographer. He married Scott's daughter Sophia in 1820 and in 1837-38 published the monumental Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart., regarded by many as the greatest Romantic biography and still a standard reference work for scholars of Scott. Lockhart edited the influential Tory periodical, the Quarterly Review, from 1826 to 1853. This is a facsimile reproduction, on a slightly reduced scale, of one of a series of portraits originally published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-38, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.

image.title2: Portrait of J.G. Lockhart engraved by G.B. Shaw after W. Allan
image.creator: Allan, William
image.description: Three-quarter portrait of Sir Walter Scott's son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart. The writer and editor John Gibson Lockhart was Scott's son-in-law and biographer. He married Scott's daughter Sophia in 1820 and in 1837-38 published the monumental Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart., regarded by many as the greatest Romantic biography and still a standard reference work for scholars of Scott. The original portrait by Allan has not been identified. The engraving may derive from the depiction of Lockhart in Allan's group-portrait 'Celebration of James Hogg, the Ettrick Shepherd's Birth Day (1819).

image.title2: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott engraved by H.T. Ryall after J.P. Knight
image.creator: Knight, John Prescott
image.description: Half-length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-four. Scott sat for the original portrait by John Prescott Knight in January 1826. It was destroyed by fire in 1832. The engraving by Ryall was first published on June 1, 1833 by Harding and Lepard of London. It was subsequently reprinted in numerous publications. It is not known from which this engraving was extracted.

image.title2: Steel engraving by G.B. Shaw of a statue of Sir Walter Scott by J. Greenshields
image.creator: Greenshields, John
image.description: Engraving of a statue of Sir Walter Scott (aged around sixty) with 'Sic Sedebat' inscribed on the pedestal. The original statue by John Greenshields was commenced in 1831 and completed in 1835. It is now displayed in Parliament House, Edinburgh. The engraving was first published in vol. II of J.G. Lockhart's Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. (Edinburgh: Cadell, 1837).

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott as a child by J. Horsburgh from a copy of the original miniature
image.creator: Daniel, Abraham
image.description: Profile portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of four or five. The original 'Bath miniature' was painted by an anonymous artist during the young Scott's visit to Bath in 1775/76. Although the dates for this visit are uncertain, it is likely that Lockhart's dating (1777) is wrong, and that Scott was at most five years old at the time of the sitting. The miniature has been attributed to Abraham Daniel of Bath (d. 1806) by Sir John Pope-Hennessy (Francis Russell, Portraits of Sir Walter Scott, p. 36). The engraving is made from a copy of the miniature at Abbotsford which Lockhart erroneously believed to be the original. The original is held by the Society of Antiquaries.

image.title1: The Author of Waverley in his Study
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott in his study by E. Goodall after W. Allan
image.creator: Allan, William
image.description: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott, aged around fifty-six, sitting at his desk in his study at Abbotsford. The original portrait by William Allan was painted from sketches of Sir Walter Scott's study at Abbotsford, possibly made when Allan was working on his oil sketch A F̻te Champ̻tre at Abbotsford in August 1827. The editor of The Anniversary notes that some minor changes to the arrangement took place after these sketches were taken. Francis Russell suggests that the painting may have been made specifically in order to be engraved (Portraits of Sir Walter Scott, p. 25).

image.title1: [Engraved portrait by G.B. Shaw from a bust of Sir Walter Scott by Sir F. L. Chantrey]
image.creator: Chantrey, Francis Legatt (b.1781, d.1841)
image.description: Engraving of a bust of Sir Walter Scott aged around fifty. Scott first sat for the original plaster bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. This engraving is from the marble replica (known as the 'Abbotsford Bust') that Chantrey made for Scott in 1821. It was first published in 1839 in vol. VII of J.G. Lockhart's Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart., 2nd edn (Edinburgh: Cadell, 1839).

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by Thomson from a bust by F. Chantrey
image.creator: Chantrey, Francis Legatt (b.1781, d.1841)
image.description: Engraving of a bust of Sir Walter Scott aged around fifty with facsimile of signature. Scott first sat for the original plaster bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. This engraving is from the marble replica (known as the 'Abbotsford Bust') that Chantrey made for Scott in 1821. It was first published in the New Monthly Magazine, January 1, 1831, then reprinted as a supplement with the Court Journal of October 6, 1832. This copy is probably one of the 1832 prints. The engraver is probably James Thomson (occasionally spelt Thompson).

image.title1: [Engraved profile portrait of Sir Walter Scott by A. Collas derived from a bust by F. Chantrey]
image.creator: Chantrey, Francis Legatt (b.1781, d.1841)
image.description: Profile portrait of Sir Walter Scott aged around fifty with facsimile of signature. Scott first sat for the original plaster bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. This engraving is from the marble replica (known as the 'Abbotsford Bust') that Chantrey made for Scott in 1821.This print was engraved by Achille Collas from a medallion by Henry Weekes derived from Chantrey's statue. It was first published in 1838 in The Authors of England (London: Charles Tilt).

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by T. Woolnoth after J. Graham-Gilbert
image.creator: Graham-Gilbert, John
image.description: Three-quarter length portrait of a seated Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-seven. Scott sat for the original portrait by John Graham (later Graham-Gilbert) between January and June 1829. It was commissioned by the Royal Society of Edinburgh which still owns the portrait. Scott is depicted wearing the gold chain of the President of the Society. Woolnoth's engraving was first published in 1832 in the National Portrait Gallery of Illustrious and Eminent Personages of the Nineteenth Century (London: Fisher, 1831-32) and in the Imperial Magazine, 2nd ser., vol. II (November 1832).

image.title1: [Reproduction of a photograph of a portion of mural featuring notable Scotsmen, including Sir Walter Scott, by W.B. Hole]
image.creator: Hole, William Brassey
image.description: A frieze of notable Scotsmen including Sir Walter Scott (seventh from the left). The original mural was commissioned for the Central Hall of the Scottish National Portrait Gallery and completed in 1898.

image.title1: [Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by H.W. Smith after Sir T. Lawrence]
image.creator: Lawrence, Thomas
image.description: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-five including a facsimile signature. Scott first sat for the original portrait by Sir Thomas Lawrence in March 1821 (not 1820). Further sittings followed in November 1826, but the painting was not ready for delivery until November 1828. Commissioned by George IV, it is part of the collection at Windsor Castle. A version of this engraving by Hezekiah Wright Smith was published in James F. Hunnewell's The Lands of Scott (Edinburgh: A. and C. Black; Boston: James R. Osgood, 1871).

image.title2: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott from an engraving by W. Humphrys after Sir T. Lawrence
image.creator: Lawrence, Thomas
image.description: Three-quarter length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-five. Scott first sat for the original portrait by Sir Thomas Lawrence in March 1821 (not 1820). Further sittings followed in November 1826, but the painting was not ready for delivery until November 1828. Commissioned by George IV, it is part of the collection at Windsor Castle. The engraving by William Humphrys (not Humphrey) was first published by Graves and Co. in 1844. This is a fascimile of a drawing made from the engraving by an unknown artist.

image.title1: [Photograph of a lithograph of Sir Walter Scott from a pencil drawing by Elliot Aitchison]
image.creator: Aitchison, Elliot
image.description: Three-quarter portrait of Sir Walter Scott. Elliot Aitchison (1797-1858) was the nephew of Robert Shortreed, Sheriff-substitute for Roxburghshire and close friend of Sir Walter Scott. The original lithograph is held by Hawick Museum.

image.title1: 'We're proud to see ye, Shirra. Would ye honour us by comin' ben?'
image.title2: Facsimile of a drawing depicting a meeting between Sir Walter Scott and Tom Purdie
image.creator: Eustace
image.description: Depicts Tom Purdie inviting Scott, whom he addresses as Sheriff Deputy of Selkirkshire, into his home. 'A Friend in Need' by Halbert Johnston Boyd is a fictionalized account of the first meeting between Scott and his retainer Tom Purdie ca. 1804 following a poaching incident.

image.title2: Photograph of R. Dease's designs for stamps of John Keats, Thomas Gray and Sir Walter Scott
image.creator: Dease, Rosalind
image.description: Design for stamps with profile portraits of John Keats (3p), Thomas Gray (5p) and Sir Walter Scott (7 1/2p) The three stamps were designed by Rosalind Dease to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the death of John Keats, the 200th anniversary of the death of Thomas Gray and the 200th anniversary of the birth of Sir Walter Scott. The stamps were first issued on July 28, 1971. Dease's design is freely inspired by the bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey.

image.title2: Engraved profile portrait by E. Lacey from a medal of Sir Walter Scott by A. J. Stothard
image.creator: Stothard, Alfred Joseph
image.description: Depicts a medallion with a profile portrait of Sir Walter Scott (aged around fifty) and a border decorated with military and Scottish motifs. The portrait is engraved by Edward Lacey from a medal cast by A. J. Stothard in 1827. The ornament is by Samuel Mitan after Henry Corbould. Stothard's medal is derived from the bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey.

image.title2: Facsimile of a drawing of Sir Walter Scott by B. Driscoll after a bust by F. Chantrey
image.creator: Chantrey, Francis Legatt (b.1781, d.1841)
image.description: Drawing from a bust of Sir Walter Scott aged around fifty. Scott first sat for the original bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. Further sittings took place in February-July 1821 and the bust was completed in that year. It is now on display at Abbotsford. This drawing by Driscoll was made to commemorate the bicentenary of Sir Walter Scott's birth in 1971. It was published by Noel Tatt of Hythe, Kent.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by M.I. Danforth after C.R. Leslie
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Three-quarter length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-three, seated with his coat of arms and motto ('Watch weel') in the background. Scott sat for the original portrait by Charles Robert Leslie in September 1824. Commissioned by the American man of letters George Ticknor, the painting was completed in 1824 and is now held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. Leslie made a copy of his portrait for Archibald Constable, from which this engraving is probably derived. Danforth's engraving was published in the Literary Souvenir in 1829.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by W. Read after C.R. Leslie
image.creator: Leslie, Charles Robert
image.description: Half-length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-three, seated, with landscape in background. Scott sat for the original portrait by Charles Robert Leslie in September 1824. Commissioned by the American man of letters George Ticknor, the original painting was completed in 1824 and is now held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. Leslie made a copy of his portrait for Archibald Constable, from which this engraving is probably derived. The engraving by William Read was first published in 1832 as the frontispiece to part 1 of The Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart., begun by William Weir and completed by George Allan.

image.title2: Facsimile of a sketch by D. Maclise of Sir Walter Scott and two dogs
image.creator: Maclise, Daniel
image.description: Full-length portrait of Sir Walter Scott aged fifty-four standing in left profile accompanied by two dogs. Below the portrait there is a facsimile of his signature. The original sketch by Daniel Maclise was made on 9 August 1825. It later formed one of a series of portraits published in Fraser's Magazine, 1830-38, under the title 'A Gallery of Illustrious Literary Characters'.

image.title1: Walter Scott's Introduction to Percy's Reliques
image.title2: Facsimile of a portrait of Sir Walter Scott as a child reading in a garden by W. Matthews
image.creator: Matthews, Winifred
image.description: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott as an eleven-year-old child, reading under a tree in a walled garden. The original portrait was painted in 1914. It depicts Scott in his Aunt Jenny's garden in Kelso, Scottish Borders, in the spring or summer of 1783. The artist is probably Winifred Matthews (born 1886).

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by Roffe after H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Head and shoulders portrait, facing right, of Sir Walter Scott at the age of thirty-six. Scott sat for the original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn in spring 1808.
