Commissioned by Archibald Constable, it was completed in the same year. It is now in the possession of the Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry at Bowhill. This engraving was originally published in The Mirror of Literature, 1826. The engraver was probably John Roffe (1769-1850). It is likely, however, that part of Roffe's work has been confused with that of an identically named engraver, possibly a son, active between 1820 and 1861. Roffe's engraving is itself based on an 1810 mezzotint by Charles Turner and an 1821 engraving by J. R. West.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by C. Heath after H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Half-length portrait facing left of Sir Walter Scott at the age of thirty-six. Scott sat for the original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn in spring 1808. Commissioned by Archibald Constable, it was completed in the same year. It is now in the possession of the Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry at Bowhill. Charles Heath's engraving, first published by Constable, Edinburgh, in 1820, is itself derived from an earlier engraving, made by Henry Meyer and published in the New Monthly Magazine, 1818 (see record 1039).

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by J. Horsburgh after H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Full-length portrait facing left of Sir Walter Scott at the age of thirty-six, seated with Camp at his feet and Hermitage Castle, Liddesdale, Scottish Borders, in the background. Scott sat for the original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn in spring 1808. Commissioned by Archibald Constable, it was completed in the same year. It is now in the possession of the Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry at Bowhill. The engraving by Horsburgh was originally made for the 2nd edition of J.G. Lockhart's Life of Scott in 1839.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by W. H. Lizars after H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Three-quarter length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of thirty-six. In his Portraits of Sir Walter Scott (1987), Frances Russell treats this engraving as a derivation of the portrait painted by Raeburn for Archibald Constable in spring 1808 (p. 74). In unpublished research James C. Corson argues that it was more probably derived from a second portrait by Raeburn, painted in 1809. and now on display at Abbotsford. The portrait was copied by J. G. Lockhart. The initials P.M. on the plate stand for Peter Morris, the pseudonym that Lockhart adopted when writing Peter's Letters to His Kinsfolk (1819), the publication for which this engraving was made. The engraver was William Home Lizars, son of Daniel Lizars. Although Daniel Lizars died in 1812, the family occasionally continued to use W. and D. Lizars as a collective signature.

image.title1: [Etching of Sir Walter Scott by R.S. Forrest after H. Raeburn]
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Shoulder-length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-one. In 1823 Raeburn worked simultaneously on two portraits of Scott, one for Lord Montagu of Boughton and one for Raeburn's private gallery. This etching probably derives from the latter which is now held by the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. Robert Smith Forrest (1871-1943) was active as an etcher from 1908 onwards.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by J. Horsburgh after J.W. Gordon
image.creator: Gordon, John Watson, Sir (b.1788, d.1864)
image.description: Three-quarter length portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-eight. Scott is accompanied by his dog Maida. Scott sat for the original portrait by Sir John Watson Gordon in March 1830. Painted for Scott's publisher Robert Cadell, it is now in the possession of the Viscount Cowdray at Dunecht House. The engraving by Horsburgh was first published in 1831 as one of A New Series of Original Illustrations to All Editions of the Waverley Novels (London: Moon, Boys, and Graves).

image.title1: Altrieve Cottage: The Residence of the Ettrick Shepherd
image.title2: Engraving of Altrive Cottage by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts Altrieve Cottage, near Ettrick, Selkirkshire, and the attached hill-farm. Altrieve Cottage was the home of poet and novelist James Hogg, known as the 'Ettrick Shepherd'. Sir Walter Scott met Hogg while researching material for Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border and became his lifelong friend and patron.

image.title1: Altrive: The Residence of the Ettrick Shepherd
image.title2: Engraving of Altrive by W. Richardson after D.O. Hill
image.creator: Hill, David Octavius
image.description: Depicts Altrieve Cottage, near Ettrick, Selkirkshire, with James Hogg and family in the foreground. Altrieve Cottage was the home of poet and novelist James Hogg, known as the 'Ettrick Shepherd'. Sir Walter Scott met Hogg while researching material for Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border and became his lifelong friend and patron.

image.title2: Engraving of Barnard Castle by E. Finden after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts the moonlit ruins of Barnard Castle, County Durham. Barnard Castle features in Sir Walter Scott's poem Rokeby: 'Those towers, which in the changeful gleam | Throw murky shadows on the stream, | Those towers of Barnard hold a guest, | The emotions of whose troubled breast, | In wild and strange confusion driven, | Rival the flitting rack of heaven.' (Canto I, stanza 2, lines 1-6)

image.title1: Ben Lomond from above Luss, Dumbarton-shire
image.title2: Engraving of Ben Lomond by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts a view of Loch Lomond with Ben Lomond in the background. The dramatic scenery of Loch Lomond and Ben Lomond feature prominently in both The Lady of the Lake and Rob Roy. While researching Rob Roy in July 1817, Scott visited the outlaw's cave at the head of Loch Lomond.

image.title1: Ashestiel: Scott's First House in the Border Country
image.title2: Facsimile of a painting of Ashestiel by E.W. Haslehust
image.creator: Haslehurst, Ernest William
image.description: Depicts a view of the house and gardens of Ashestiel near Selkirk, Scottish Borders. Ashestiel was Sir Walter Scott's summer residence from 1804 to 1811. It was here that Marmion and the first abortive chapters of Waverley were written. When the Ashestiel lease expired in May 1811 the Scott family moved to the site which was to become Abbotsford.

image.title2: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Ashestiel Bridge by G. Home
image.creator: Home, Gordon
image.description: Depicts a bridge over the River Tweed at Ashestiel, near Selkirk, Scottish Borders. Ashestiel was Sir Walter Scott's summer residence from 1804 to 1811. It was here that Marmion and the first abortive chapters of Waverley were written. When the Ashestiel lease expired in May 1811 the Scott family moved to the site which was to become Abbotsford.

image.title1: Scott's Favourite View: The Eildons and the Tweed from above Bemersyde
image.title2: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of the Eildon Hills by G. Home
image.creator: Home, Gordon
image.description: Presents a view of the River Tweed, the Tweed Valley, and the Eildon Hills from Bemersyde Hill near Melrose, Scottish Borders. According to popular tradition, Sir Walter Scott so favoured this view and paused there so frequently on his way home to Abbotsford, that his horses eventually learned to stop without command. They are reputed to have stopped at the viewpoint even when drawing Scott's funeral carriage en route for Dryburgh Abbey in 1832.

image.title1: Scott's Favourite View from Bemersyde Hill, Roxburghshire.
image.title2: Facsimile of a painting of the River Tweed and the Eildon Hills by H.S. Palmer
image.creator: Palmer, Harold Sutton
image.description: Presents a view of the River Tweed, the Tweed Valley, and the Eildon Hills from Bemersyde Hill near Melrose, Scottish Borders. According to popular tradition, Sir Walter Scott so favoured this view and paused there so frequently on his way home to Abbotsford, that his horses eventually learned to stop without command. They are reputed to have stopped at the viewpoint even when drawing Scott's funeral carriage en route for Dryburgh Abbey in 1832.

image.title2: Facsimile of a painting of Bemersyde House by E.W. Haslehust
image.creator: Haslehurst, Ernest William
image.description: Presents a view of Bemersyde House, near Melrose, Scottish Borders, and its gardens. The view from Bemersyde Hill, near Melrose, which overlooks the Tweed Valley and Eildon Hills, was a particular favourite of Scott's. Directly under the brow of the hill lies Bemersyde House, seat of the Haigs of Bemersyde, where Scott was a frequent visitor. The house incorporates a rectangular tower built around 1535 which was restored and greatly extended in the 18th century.

image.title2: Facsimile of a painting of Branxholme Castle by E.W. Haslehust
image.creator: Haslehurst, Ernest William
image.description: Presents a view of Branxholme Castle, near Hawick, Scottish Borders, with the River Teviot in the foreground. Branxholme Castle is the ancient seat of the Dukes of Buccleuch, and provides the setting for much of The Lay of the Last Minstrel. Alternative spellings include Branxholm and Branksome, the latter preferred by Scott. The Lay of the Last Minstrel portrays the efforts of the Lady of Branksome to prevent marriage between her daughter and a feudal enemy and the siege of Branksome at the hands of an English army.

image.title2: Engraved picture of Cadzow Forest by W. Forrest after H. McCulloch
image.creator: McCulloch, Horatio
image.description: Depicts Cadzow Forest, near Hamilton, Lanarkshire, with white cattle grazing. In the Introduction to Sir Walter Scott's ballad Cadyow Castle, he describes Cadyow (or Cadzow) Forest: 'In the immediate vicinity of Cadyow is a grove of immense oaks, the remains of the Caledonian Forest... they have witnessed the rites of the Druids... There was long preserved in this forest the breed of the Scottish wild cattle... Their appearance was beautiful, being milk-white, with black muzzles, horns, and hoofs.' Cadzow Forest was a favourite subject of Horatio McCulloch who depicted it in a number of paintings between 1834 and 1865. It is unknown which formed the basis for this engraving.

image.title2: Engraved picture of Caerlaverock Castle by unknown artist
image.creator: Landseer, John (b.1763, d.1852)
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Caerlaverock Castle, Dumfriesshire. Ellangowan Castle, seat of the Bertrams in Sir Walter Scott's Guy Mannering (1815), is often thought to be based on Caerlaverock Castle which Scott visited with Guthrie Wright in 1806. The engraver may be John Landseer who signed the frontispieces to The Beauties of Scotland (presumably working from his own design).

image.title2: Engraved view of Carlisle by E. Francis after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: A prospect of the city of Carlisle, Cumbria, from the north bank of the River Eden, with St Mary's Church in the background. Scott married Margaret Charlotte Carpenter (or Charpentier) at St Mary's Church (which formed parted of what is now Carlisle Cathedral) on 24 December 1797. Carlisle also features in a number of Scott's works, most notably Waverley where Fergus MacIvor and Evan Dhu are executed at Carlisle Castle. Carlisle is also the scene of the trial and execution of Robin Oig M'Combich in 'The Two Drovers'.

image.title2: Engraving of Carlisle Castle by E. Francis after R. Westall
image.creator: Westall, Richard
image.description: Depicts Carlisle Castle, Cumbria, with grazing cattle in the foreground. Edward Waverley visits the captive Fergus MacIvor in Carlisle Castle in Waverley ch. 69. MacIvor is subsequently executed outside the castle gate along with Evan Dhu. Besides featuring in a number of Scott's works, Carlisle was also the scene of Scott's wedding to Margaret Charlotte Carpenter on 24 December 1797.

image.title1: Communion Rail, in the Old Church St. Mary, Carlisle
image.title2: Lithograph of the communion rail at St Mary's in Carlisle by W. H. MacFarlane
image.creator: Bell, George
image.description: Depicts the communion rail in St. Mary's Church in Carlisle, Cumbria. On Christmas Eve 1797 Sir Walter Scott married Margaret Charlotte Carpenter at St. Mary's Church, Carlisle (which formed part of what is now Carlisle Cathedral). According to C.S.M. Lockhart the ceremony took place at the communion rail depicted in this lithograph (The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, pp. 24-26). The lithograph by W. H. MacFarlane was based on a photograph taken by George Bell of Carlisle.

image.title1: The Crown and Mitre Coffee House, English Street, Carlisle
image.title2: Lithograph of the Crown and Mitre Coffee House by W.H. MacFarlane
image.creator: Scott, J.
image.description: Depicts the Crown and Mitre Inn and Coffee House in Carlisle, Cumbria. According to C.S.M. Lockhart, Scott put up at the Crown and Mitre Coffee House and Inn when visiting his fianc̩e Charlotte Carpenter in Carlisle in 1797 (The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, p. 21). The lithograph by W.H. MacFarlane was made from a photograph taken by J. Scott of Carlisle.

image.title1: No. 83, Castle Street and the Crown and Mitre Coffee House, Carlisle
image.title2: Lithograph of Castle Street and the Crown and Mitre Coffee House in Carlisle by W.H. McFarlane
image.creator: MacFarlane, William Husband
image.description: Depicts, left, the Crown and Mitre Inn and Coffee House in Carlisle, Cumbria, and, directly opposite, no. 83 Castle Street. According to C.S.M. Lockhart, Scott put up at the Crown and Mitre Coffee House and Inn when visiting his fianc̩e Charlotte Carpenter in Carlisle in 1797 (The Centenary Memorial of Sir Walter Scott, p. 21). While in Carlisle, Charlotte Carpenter stayed with her friend Miss Nicholson at No. 83 Castle Street. The lithograph is taken from a photograph by either J. Scott or George Bell of Carlisle.

image.title2: Lithograph of No. 83 Castle Street, Carlisle by W.H. McFarlane
image.creator: Scott, J.
image.description: Depicts No. 83 Castle Street, Carlisle, Cumbria. While in Carlisle in 1797, Sir Walter Scott's future wife, Charlotte Carpenter, stayed with her friend Miss Nicholson at No. 83 Castle Street. She remained there until her marriage to Scott was celebrated in St. Mary's Church, Carlisle, on 24 December 1797. The lithograph by W.H. MacFarlane was made from a photograph taken by J. Scott of Carlisle.

image.title1: Dunstaffnage Castle and Entrance to Loch Etive (West Highlands)
image.title2: Engraving of Dunstaffnage Castle by E. Benjamin after T. Allom
image.creator: Allom, Thomas
image.description: Depicts armed Highlanders outside Dunstaffnage Castle, near Oban, Argyllshire, with a vista of mountains in the background. Dunstaffnage Castle is often regarded as the model for Sir Duncan Campbell's castle of Ardenvohr in Scott's A Legend of Montrose. Scott visited the castle on 1 September 1814, but had earlier seen it from the sea when crossing to Mull in July 1810. This engraving was first published in William Beattie's Scotland Illustrated (1838).

image.title1: The Inn at Clovenfords Where Scott Stayed
image.title2: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Clovenfords Inn by G. Home
image.creator: Home, Gordon
image.description: Depicts Clovenfords Inn, near Galashiels, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott stayed at Clovenfords Inn (now Clovenfords Country Hotel) when fulfilling his duties as Sheriff-Depute of Selkirkshire until 1804 when he moved to Ashestiel.

image.title1: Remains of the Old Castle of Douglas, Douglas-dale, Lanarkshire.
image.title2: Engraving of the ruins of Douglas Castle by W. Forrest after J.C. Brown
image.creator: Brown, John Crawford (b.1805, d.1867)
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Douglas Castle, Lanarkshire, with an agricultural labourer and a draught horse in the foreground. Douglas Castle is portrayed as 'Castle Dangerous' in Scott's novel of that name. Scott, who had visited the castle in childhood, had previously contemplated writing a drama on it in 1802, and had discussed its role in the Wars of Independence in his 'Essay on Chivalry' (1818).

image.title2: Engraving of Drumlanrig Castle by Angus after F. Grose
image.creator: Grose, Francis
image.description: Engraving of Drumlanrig Castle, Dumfriesshire, and grounds. Scott and his family were frequent visitors at Drumlanrig Castle, seat of the Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry, Scott's clan-chief and patron. The table in the dining room at Abbotsford was made from oak wood from the grounds of Drumlanrig Castle. This engraving was probably made by William Angus (1752-1821). The original drawing by Francis Grose was made before 1791.

image.title1: Dryburgh Abbey: The Resting Place of Sir Walter Scott
image.title2: Engraving of St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey by J. Le Keux after D. Roberts
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, the burial place of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.

image.title1: Sir Walter Scott's Tomb, Dryburgh Abbey
image.title2: Engraving of St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey by W. Banks and Son
image.creator: Banks, William
image.description: Depicts visitors at St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, the burial place of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here. The engraving may have been based on an original drawing by William Banks or his son. William Banks and Co. (or William Banks and Son) were active between 1858 and 1890.

image.title2: Facsimile of a watercolour of Dryburgh Abbey by William Smith
image.creator: Smith, William
image.description: Depicts Gothic arches at Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, and a vista of Scott's burial place. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, on September 26, 1832. Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.

image.title1: Les debris de l'Abbaye de DRYBURGH
image.title2: Engraving of the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey by J. Goeree
image.creator: Goeree, Jan
image.description: Depicts tourist visiting the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, future resting place of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' The original engraving, probably by Jan Goeree, was made expressly for Les d̩lices de la Grand' Bretagne, and de l'Irelande by James Beeverell. The engravings in this publication are largely based on previously published work.

image.title2: Engraving of Dryburgh Abbey and its grounds by J. Goeree
image.creator: Goeree, Jan
image.description: Presents a view of the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, from the south bank of the River Tweed. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, on September 26, 1832. image.title1: Dryburgh Abbey, Roxburghshire: (The Burial Place of Sir Walter Scott)
image.title2: Engraving of St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey by J.C. Varrall after T. Allom
image.creator: Allom, Thomas

This engraving was originally published in William Beattie's Scotland Illustrated (1838).

image.title1: Dryburgh Abbey: Sir Walter Scott's Sepulchre
image.title2: Engraving of the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey by J. Johnstone after J. Bower
image.creator: Bower, John
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, and the burial place of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' The print was made by one, or possibly both, of the Edinburgh engravers James and John Johnstone.

image.title2: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Sir Walter Scott's burial place, Dryburgh Abbey by G. Home
image.creator: Home, Gordon
image.description: Depicts Sir Walter Scott's burial place in St Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.

image.title2: Engraving of Dunstanburgh Castle by W. Floyd after J.W. Carmichael
image.creator: Carmichael, James Wilson
image.description: Depicts a storm-tossed sea boat with Dunstanburgh Castle, near Alnwick, Northumberland, in the background. Dunstanburgh (or Dunstanborough) Castle, dominates a stretch of coastline portrayed in Scott's Marmion: 'And next, they crossed themselves, to hear | The whitening breakers sound so near, | Where, boiling through the rocks, they roar | On Dunstanborough's caverned shore' (canto II, stanza 7, lines 17-20).

image.title2: Engraving of Elvet Bridge, Durham by E. Francis after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts the Elvet Bridge with Durham Castle in the background. The city of Durham features in a number of Scott's works, most notably Harold the Dauntless: 'Grey towers of Durham!... | Well yet I love thy mix'd and massive piles, | Half church of God, half castle 'gainst the Scot,' (canto III, pt. 1, lines 1,10-11). Jeannie Deans passes through Durham on her way to London in The Heart of Midlothian (ch. 27), and it also mentioned as the resting place of St Cuthbert in Marmion: 'There, deep in Durham's Gothic shade, | His relics are in secret laid' (canto II, stanza 14, lines 27-28).

image.title2: Coloured wood block engraving of Blenheim Palace by B. Fawcett after A.F. Lydon
image.creator: Lydon, A. F.
image.description: Depicts a view of Blenheim Palace, Oxfordshire, including the lake and Vanbrugh's Grand Bridge. The royal park and lodge featured in Sir Walter Scott's Woodstock have since been levelled and replaced by Blenheim Palace and the gardens of Capability Brown. The Palace is also mentioned in Waverley and Kenilworth. Scott visited Blenheim Palace with Richard Heber in May 1803. The original drawing (on wood) by A.F. Lydon was made expressly for The Ancestral Homes of Britain by F.O. Morris.

image.title2: Engraving of Canterbury Cathedral by E. Francis after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts Canterbury Cathedral, Kent, with grazing cattle in the foreground. Scott's son Walter was stationed in Canterbury as a Captain in the King's Hussars between 1827 and 1828. There are also brief references to Canterbury in Rob Roy, The Talisman, The Betrothed, and Count Robert of Paris.

image.title2: Engraving of the city of Chester by E. Francis after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts the River Dee and the city of Chester, Cheshire. Hugo de Lacy, the Constable of Chester, is a principal character in Sir Walter Scott's novel The Betrothed (1825).

image.title2: Engraving of Dobbs Linn by W. Forrest after D.O. Hill
image.creator: Hill, David Octavius
image.description: An image of Dobbs Linn, near Moffat, Dumfriesshire, depicting a ravine with a waterfall cascading into a pool. A young girl, Katharine Laidlaw, is indicating the entrance to a hidden cave. Dobbs Linn was used as hiding-place by the Covenanters during the 'Killing Times'. The Linn and its surroundings influenced the geography of Sir Walter Scott's Tale of Old Mortality. ('Linn' can mean either a cascade, the pool into which a cascade falls, or a ravine.) The original painting by David Octavius Hill was made expressly for the 1837 edition of Tales and Sketches by the Ettrick Shepherd [i.e. James Hogg]. It illustrated a scene from 'The Brownie of Bodsbeck' where Katharine, daughter of the hero Walter Laidlaw, leads him to a hidden cave in the Linn.

image.title2: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of the Rhymer's Tower by G. Home
image.creator: Home, Gordon
image.description: Depicts the Rhymer's Tower in Earlston, Berwickshire, with fields of wheat in the foreground. The Rhymer's Tower is traditionally considered to have been the home of poet and prophet, Thomas the Rhymer. Sir Walter Scott included the ballad of Thomas the Rhymer in the second volume of his Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802), adding a 'Third Part' of his own composition. Scott also believed Thomas to be the author of 'Sir Tristrem', which he edited for publication in 1804.

image.title2: Engraving of a view of Edinburgh by W.H. Lizars after J.B. Kidd
image.creator: Kidd, Joseph Bartholomew
image.description: Presents a view of Edinburgh from Corstorphine Hill. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). The original work by Joseph Bartholomew Kidd was probably made expressly for Robert Chambers's The Picture of Scotland, a publication aimed at the tourist market.

image.title2: Engraving of Brown Square, Edinburgh by W. Forrest after D. Wilson
image.creator: Wilson, Daniel
image.description: Depicts a scene of daily life in Brown Square, Edinburgh. Brown Square or Brown's Square, named after the architect James Brown, was built as a residential development in 1763. It is the fictional home of Alan Fairford's family in Scott's novel Redgauntlet (1824). Brown Square was demolished in the 19th century to permit the building of George IV Bridge and Chambers Street. The original painting by Sir Daniel Wilson was made expressly for his book Memorials of Edinburgh in the Olden Time, which was first published in 1848.

image.title1: Edinburgh Castle: From the Grey Friar's Church Yard.
image.title2: Engraving of Edinburgh Castle by J.H. Kernot after G. Cattermole
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts a lone figure in Greyfriars Kirkyard with Edinburgh Castle in the background. Edinburgh Castle is the most prominent landmark of Scott's hometown. It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). This engraving was first published in the first edition of Leitch Ritchie's Scott and Scotland (1835).

It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).

The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).

image.title1: No 39, Castle Street, Edinburgh: The Town Residence of Sir Walter Scott for Upwards of Twenty-Five Years.
image.title2: Engraving of No.39 Castle Street, Edinburgh by W. Miller after J.M.W. Turner
image.creator: Turner, Joseph Mallord William (b.1775, d.1851)
image.description: Depicts Castle Street with Edinburgh Castle in the background. During court term Sir Walter Scott lived with his family at 39 Castle Street, Edinburgh, from 1801 until 1826 when financial disaster compelled Scott to sell up.

image.title1: Heriot's Hospital: From the Grass Market
image.title2: Engraving of George Heriot's School, Edinburgh by G. Aikman after J. Storer
image.creator: Storer, James
image.description: Depicts the Grassmarket, Edinburgh, with George Heriot's School in the background. George Heriot's School, formerly George Heriot's Hospital, was founded in 1628 as a result of a bequest by George Heriot, Goldsmith and Jeweller to James VI and I. Scott portrayed Heriot as 'Jingling Geordie' in his 1822 novel The Fortunes of Nigel. Scott also described the Hospital (i.e. orphanage) in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). His family burial site lay in Greyfriars Kirkyard near the entrance to the Hospital.

image.title2: Engraving of Greyfriars Kirk, Edinburgh by T. Steuart after D. Wilson
image.creator: Wilson, Daniel
image.description: Presents a view of Greyfriars Kirk, Edinburgh, from (modern-day) Bristo Place, with Heriot's Hospital in the background. Greyfriars Kirk is mentioned in a number of Scott's novels, notably Guy Mannering and Redgauntlet. Scott's father and sister were both buried in the Scott family burial-plot in the Kirkyard. According to Lockhart, Scott also first made the acquaintance of his first love Williamina Belsches in the Kirkyard. Much of the older part of the church was destroyed by fire in 1845, but the building had been successfully restored by 1857.

image.title1: Original Design for the Scott Monument
image.title2: Facsimile of the design for the Scott Monument by G.M. Kemp
image.creator: Kemp, George Meikle
image.description: Depicts the original design for the Scott Monument, Edinburgh, including small turrets at the corners. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in Edinburgh in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue of Scott by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.

image.title2: Engraving of Mary, Queen of Scot's Closet in the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh by J. Lewis after G. Cattermole
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts Mary, Queen of Scots' Closet in the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh. The Queen's 'closet' was a private meeting-room adjoining the Royal bed-chamber. It is best known as the scene of the murder of her secretary David Rizzio. This episode is described in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).The murder is also alluded to in The Abbot and Chronicles of the Canongate. This engraving was first published in the first edition of Leitch Ritchie's Scott and Scotland (1835).

image.title2: Engraving of the Palace of Holyroodhouse by J. Fife after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Presents a view of the Palace of Holyroodhouse and Holyrood Park, Edinburgh, from Calton Hill. The Royal Palace of Holyroodhouse appears in a number of Scott's works, most notably in Waverley (1814) where it is occupied by Prince Charles Edward Stuart and is the scene of a ball (chapter 43). The Palace is also described in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and is repeatedly mentioned in Tales of a Grandfather, First to Third Series (1828-30).

image.title2: Engraving of Mary, Queen of Scot's Bedchamber by J. Lewis after G. Cattermole
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts Mary, Queen of Scots' bedchamber in the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh (with a seated Sir Walter Scott). The murderers of Mary Stuart's secretary David Rizzio dragged their victim from the Queen's presence into the royal bedchamber at the Palace of Holyroodhouse before dispatching him. This episode is described in Sir Walter Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).There are further references to the murder in The Abbot and Chronicles of the Canongate. The bedchamber was also the birth-place of Mary's son James who would unite the kingdoms of England and Scotland. He is a central character in Scott's 1822 novel The Fortunes of Nigel. This engraving was first published in the first edition of Leitch Ritchie's Scott and Scotland (1835).

image.title2: Engraving of David Hume's Monument by an unattributed artist
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts Leith Wynd, Edinburgh, with a view of David Hume's tomb on Calton Hill. The Memorial to David Hume on Calton Hill, Edinburgh, was built to a design by Robert Adam in 1777. It is described in Sir Walter Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). Hume's History of England (1754-62) exerted a profound effect on Scott's own historical thought. In The Heart of Mid-Lothian, ch. 15, Sharpitlaw threatens to send Madge Wildfire to a workhouse in Leith Wynd.

image.title2: Engraving of St. Anthony's Chapel, Edinburgh by an unattributed artist
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts St. Anthony's Chapel, Holyrood Park, Edinburgh, with Calton Hill in the background. In Sir Walter Scott's The Heart of Midlothian (ch. 15), the heroine Jeanie Deans meets her sister's seducer by moonlight beneath St. Anthony's Chapel. The Chapel is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).

image.title1: St. Giles' Church: From the N.West, Altered 1827
image.title2: Engraving of St. Giles' Cathedral by T. Steuart after D. Wilson
image.creator: Wilson, Daniel
image.description: Depicts the north-west face of St. Giles' Cathedral, Edinburgh. The Cathedral or High Kirk of St. Giles is described in Sir Walter Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). It is also mentioned in a number of Scott's other works, notably The Heart of Midlothian, Redgauntlet, The Antiquary, The Abbot, and The Fortunes of Nigel. The original work by Sir Daniel Wilson was made expressly for his book, Memorials of Edinburgh in the Olden Time, first published in 1848.

image.title2: Engraving of Salisbury Crags by J. Fife after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts the Salisbury Crags, Edinburgh, with Arthur's Seat in the background. The Salisbury Crags are described in Sir Walter Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). According to the General Preface to the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels (1829) Scott entertained his school-friends with his story-telling abilities during long walks in their vicinity. According to Lockhart, Scott also first tried his hand at composing verse during rambles on the Crags.

image.title2: Engraving by R. Scott of G.M. Kemp's design for the Scott Monument, Edinburgh
image.creator: Kemp, George Meikle
image.description: Depicts the design for the Scott Monument in Princes Street, Edinburgh. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.

image.title1: Sir Walter Scott's Monument, From East Princes Street Gardens
image.title2: Facsimile of a watercolour of the Scott Monument by J. Fulleylove
image.creator: Fulleylove, John
image.description: Depicts Princes Street Gardens, Edinburgh, and the Scott Monument. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.

image.title2: Chromo-lithograph of Scott Monument by T. Nelson and Sons
image.creator: Thomas Nelson and Sons
image.description: Depicts a view along Princes Street, Edinburgh, including the Scott Monument and Edinburgh Castle. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.

image.title2: Engraving of St. Giles' Cathedral and Tolbooth by W. Forrest after D. Wilson
image.creator: Wilson, Daniel
image.description: Depicts the Tolbooth outside St. Giles' Cathedral, Edinburgh. The Old Tolbooth, a prison in Edinburgh's High Street nicknamed 'The Heart of Midlothian', features prominently in Sir Walter Scott's novel of that name, published in 1818. Although the Tolbooth was demolished in 1817, its former entrance is marked by a heart-shaped pattern of stones in the pavement by St. Giles' Cathedral. Following the demolition, the Tolbooth's doorway, door, and lock were incorporated into Scott's house of Abbotsford.

image.title2: Engraving of Old College, Edinburgh University by an unattributed artist
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts the Old College, University of Edinburgh. The foundation stone of the building now known as Old College was laid in 1789, but construction work was hindered by the Napoleonic Wars, and only a small part of Robert Adam's original design was built. The building was completed between 1817 and 1840 following an amended design by William Playfair. A dome by Robert Rowand Anderson was added in 1877. Scott attended the University of Edinburgh between 1783 and 1786 and between 1789 and 1792. The Old College faces College Wynd, Scott's birthplace.

image.title2: Engraving of West Bow, Edinburgh by J. Cousen after G. Cattermole
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts a street scene in West Bow, Edinburgh. In The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818), ch. 3, a group of people including Bartoline Saddletree and Reuben Butler discuss the reprieve of Captain Porteous while returning to their houses in the Lawnmarket via 'the steep declivity of the West Bow'. The West Bow was originally a steep winding road leading from the Grassmarket (site of the gallows) to Castle Hill, offering the only means of access to Edinburgh Castle from the South. It was largely demolished in the 1830s when Victoria Street and George IV Bridge were built to provide more convenient access. Only a small portion of the West Bow now survives at the foot of Victoria Street.

image.title1: Cottage in Ettrick: The Birth Place of James Hogg
image.title2: Engraving of Ettrick Cottage by D. Wilson after D.O. Hill
image.creator: Hill, David Octavius
image.description: Depicts Ettrick Cottage, Selkirkshire, with horse and cart on the road outside. The engraving shows the birthplace of novelist and poet James Hogg, known as the Ettrick Shepherd. Sir Walter Scott met Hogg while researching material for The Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border and became his lifelong friend and patron.

image.title2: Engraving of Fast Castle by W. H. Lizars after J. Ewbank
image.creator: Ewbank, John Wilson
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Fast Castle near St Abbs Head, Berwickshire. Fast Castle has been identified as an inspiration for Wolf's Crag, the home of the Master of Ravenswood in Sir Walter Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor (1819). In the Magnum Opus edition of the novel (1830), Scott claims that he cannot comment on the perceived resemblance between Wolf's Crag and Fast Castle as he has only seen the latter from the sea. He acknowledges, however, that the position of Fast Castle resembles that of Wolf's Crag as much as any other fortalice on the East Coast of Scotland. Scott also describes the castle in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). Scott owned a painting of Fast Castle by the Rev. John Thomson (Letters, VIII, 459).

image.title2: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Flodden Field by G. Home
image.creator: Home, Gordon
image.description: Depicts a stormy sky over Flodden Field, Northumberland. Sir Walter Scott's poem Marmion culminates in one of the greatest disasters in Scottish history, the Battle of Flodden Field. It is described at length in Canto Sixth ('The Battle'). Scott visited the battlefield in August 1791.

image.title2: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Floors Castle by G. Home
image.creator: Home, Gordon
image.description: Depicts a view of Floors Castle, Kelso, Scottish Borders, and grounds. Scott was a frequent visitor to Floors (formerly Fleurs) Castle which was built by William Adam for the 1st Duke of Roxburghe in 1721. In his unfinished Autobiography (1808) Sir Walter Scott describes the awakening of a sense of beauty during childhood stays in Kelso, 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic, village in Scotland'. Among its sights, he lists the castle 'which is so situated as to combine the ideas of ancient baronial grandeur with those of modern taste'. He again praises the beauty of Floors Castle in Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft (1830).

image.title2: Coloured wood block engraving of Floors Castle by B. Fawcett after A.F. Lydon
image.creator: Lydon, A. F.
image.description: Depicts a view of Floors Castle, Kelso, Scottish Borders, and grounds. Scott was a frequent visitor to Floors (formerly Fleurs) Castle in Kelso which was built by William Adam for the 1st Duke of Roxburghe in 1721. In his unfinished Autobiography (1808; published in Lockhart's Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart.) Sir Walter Scott describes the awakening of a sense of beauty during childhood stays in Kelso, 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic, village in Scotland'. Among its sights, he lists the castle 'which is so situated as to combine the ideas of ancient baronial grandeur with those of modern taste'. He again praises the beauty of Floors Castle in Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft (1830).

image.title2: Lithograph of 'The Popping Stone', Gilsland by W.H. McFarlane
image.creator: MacFarlane, William Husband
image.description: Depicts a large stone with hawthorn trees in the background. According to local tradition, the 'Popping Stone' in Gilsland, Cumbria, is where Sir Walter Scott proposed to his future wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter and the 'Kissing-Thorn' the site of their first kiss. The lithograph is taken from an uncredited photograph.

image.title2: Engraving of the city of Glasgow by E. Francis after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts Glasgow Green and the Clyde River with the city in the background. The city of Glasgow features prominently in Sir Walter Scott's Rob Roy (1817). Francis Osbaldistone crosses (and describes) Glasgow Green in Chapter 21 of the novel. Scott visited Glasgow on several occasions, notably in 1808, 1814, and 1817.

image.title2: Engraving of Keswick Bridge and Greta Hall by E. Francis after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts Keswick Bridge, Cumbria, with Greta Hall in the background. Greta Hall, when the home of Samuel Taylor Coleridge and, later, Robert Southey, played host to many literary figures including Sir Walter Scott, who visited Southey in August 1805, August 1813 and August 1825. In 1813, Scott was offered the post of Poet Laureate, but refused and instead suggested Southey.

image.title2: Engraving of Goldielands Tower by T. Vivares after F. Grose
image.creator: Grose, Francis
image.description: Depicts Goldilands Tower, near Hawick, Scottish Borders, overlooking the Teviot River. Goldilands (or Goldielands) Castle is a sixteenth-century peel tower built by the Scotts of Buccleuch to protect Branxholme Castle. It has been identified as the model for Westburnflat Tower in Sir Walter Scott's The Black Dwarf (1816). It is also mentioned in The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), where, on his way to Melrose Abbey, Sir William of Deloraine 'passed the Peel of Goldiland | And crossed old Borthwick's roaring strand' (canto I, stanza XXV, lines 7-8). The original drawing by Francis Grose was made expressly for his book The Antiquities of Scotland.

image.title2: Engraving of Glencoe by W.H. Lizars after J.B. Kidd
image.creator: Kidd, Joseph Bartholomew
image.description: Depicts Glen Coe, Scottish Highlands, under a stormy sky. Sir Walter Scott wrote the poem 'On the Massacre of Glencoe' in 1814. He also described the massacre at length in Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1828).

image.title1: Front View of the Old University at Glasgow
image.title2: Lithograph of Old College, Glasgow University by W.H. McFarlane
image.creator: MacFarlane, William Husband
image.description: Depicts the main fa̤ade of the Old College, Glasgow University. Old College Garden is the scene of a duel between Frank and Rashleigh Osbaldistone in Rob Roy (1817), ch. 25. There are further references to Glasgow University in Guy Mannering, The Fortunes of Nigel, A Legend of Montrose, and Old Mortality. Scott was elected Rector of Glasgow University in 1828 but declined the office. Old College was the location of Glasgow University until 1870 when it moved to its current premises. The lithograph is taken from an uncredited photograph.

image.title1: View of the First College Court, in the Old University, Glasgow
image.title2: Lithograph of courtyard in the Old College, Glasgow University by W.H. McFarlane
image.creator: MacFarlane, William Husband
image.description: Depicts courtyard in the Old College, Glasgow University. Old College Garden is the scene of a duel between Frank and Rashleigh Osbaldistone in Rob Roy (1817), ch. 25. There are further references to Glasgow University in Guy Mannering, The Fortunes of Nigel, A Legend of Montrose, and Old Mortality. Old College was the location of Glasgow University until 1870 when it moved to its current premises. The lithograph is taken from an uncredited photograph.

image.title1: Ground Plan of the House in which Walter Scott Was Born: From Edgar's Plan of Edinburgh, Drawn in 1742
image.title2: Facsimile of a map of Edinburgh showing Sir Walter Scott's birthplace
image.creator: Edgar, William (active Circa 1741)
image.description: Depicts a portion of a plan of Edinburgh showing College Wynd, the birthplace of Sir Walter Scott. Sir Walter Scott was born on 15 August 1771 in a house (since demolished) in College Wynd, Edinburgh. His family moved into new, healthier accommodation in George Square in 1774.

image.title2: Facsimile of a pencil drawing by W.J. Maskell of the Scott Monument
image.creator: Maskell, W.J.
image.description: Depicts the Scott Monument, Edinburgh, with the spire of St Giles' Cathedral visible in the background. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.

image.title2: Engraving of Hawthornden Castle by an unattributed artist
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts the North Esk River and Hawthornden Castle, Midlothian. The glen of Hawthornden, near Roslin, Midlothian, features in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works, including Rokeby, The Antiquary, 'The Gray Brother', and, in particular, The Lay of the Last Minstrel where 'a wondrous blaze... | 'Twas seen from Dryden's groves of oak, | And seen from cavern'd Hawthornden.' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 26-32). The site is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). The castle itself was built by the poet William Drummond in the seventeenth century.

image.title2: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Hermitage Castle by G. Home
image.creator: Home, Gordon
image.description: Depicts Hermitage Castle, Scottish Borders, and surrounding countryside. The sixteenth-century castle of Hermitage was a favourite of Scott's and is described in his 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814). While gathering ballads in Liddesdale Scott carried out excavations at the Hermitage and made a sketch of the castle. A print derived from Scott's sketch was published in Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-04), and the backdrop of Sir Henry Raeburn's 1808 portrait of Scott is also based on it.

image.title2: Engraving of Inveraray Castle by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts Inveraray Castle, Argyll and Bute, and surrounding countryside. The original castle of Inveraray features prominently as the seat of the Marquis of Argyle in Sir Walter Scott's novel A Legend of Montrose (1819). It was burnt down by the Marquis of Montrose in 1644 and the present castle, depicted here, was built in the 1740s. There are further references to Inveraray as the seat of the Duke of Argyll in The Heart of Mid-Lothian.

image.title2: Engraving of Jedburgh Abbey by an unattributed artist
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Jedburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott describes Jedburgh Abbey in his 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814), inaccurately praising its Anglo-Norman chapter-house as 'a very perfect specimen of Saxon architecture'. There are further references in The Black Dwarf and The Monastery. The Abbey was built by David I around 1138 but fell into ruin by the mid-sixteenth century. Scott was a frequent visitor to Jedburgh in his capacity as Sheriff Depute of Selkirkshire. He subscribed 10 toward the repair-work on the Abbey's tower in 1824-1826.

image.title2: Facsimile of a watercolour of Jedburgh Abbey by W. Smith
image.creator: Smith, William
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Jedburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, with the River Tweed in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott describes Jedburgh Abbey in his 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814), inaccurately praising its Anglo-Norman chapter-house as 'a very perfect specimen of Saxon architecture'. There are further references in The Black Dwarf and The Monastery. The Abbey was built by David I around 1138 but fell into ruin by the mid-sixteenth century. Scott was a frequent visitor to Jedburgh in his capacity as Sheriff Depute of Selkirkshire. He subscribed �10 toward the repair-work on the Abbey's tower in 1824-1826.

image.title1: Kelso: The River Tweed and Abbey Ruins
image.title2: Facsimile of a painting of Kelso Abbey by E.W. Haslehust
image.creator: Haslehurst, Ernest William
image.description: Depicts the Tweed River and the ruins of Kelso Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott described Kelso in his unfinished Autobiography (1808) as 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic village in Scotland'. Scott spent many summers in Kelso at his uncle Captain Robert Scott's house of Rosebank, which Scott inherited in 1804. In 1783, a convalescent Scott also attended Kelso Grammar School, where he made the acquaintance of his future business partner James Ballantyne. The Abbey at Kelso is one of four founded in the Borders by King David I. It is described in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).

image.title2: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Kelso Abbey by G. Home
image.creator: Home, Gordon
image.description: Depicts the bridge over the Tweed River and the ruins of Kelso Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott described Kelso in his unfinished Autobiography (1808) as 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic village in Scotland'. Scott spent many summers in Kelso at his uncle Captain Robert Scott's house of Rosebank, which Scott inherited in 1804. In 1783, a convalescent Scott also attended Kelso Grammar School, where he made the acquaintance of his future business partner James Ballantyne. The Abbey at Kelso is one of four founded in the Borders by King David I. It is described in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).

image.title2: Engraving of Kelso Abbey by an unattributed artist
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Kelso Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott described Kelso in his unfinished Autobiography (1808) as 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic village in Scotland'. Scott spent many summers in Kelso at his uncle Captain Robert Scott's house of Rosebank, which Scott inherited in 1804. In 1783, a convalescent Scott also attended Kelso Grammar School, where he made the acquaintance of his future business partner James Ballantyne. The Abbey at Kelso is one of four founded in the Borders by King David I. It is described in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).

image.title1: Loch of Monteath, Perthshire: Looking South East
image.title2: Engraving of the Lake of Menteith by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts the Lake of Menteith and Inchmahome Priory, Stirling, with a family seated by the shore. The Lake of Menteith (or Monteath) on the Flanders Moss is often called the only lake, as opposed to 'loch', in Scotland. It is glimpsed briefly in Rob Roy, ch. 32. There are further references to the historical lands of Menteith in The Lady of the Lake and in A Legend of Montrose, where the Earl of Menteith plays a significant role. An island on the lake is the site of Inchmahome Priory where the infant Mary Queen of Scots took refuge after the defeat of the Scottish army at Pinkie Cleuch (1547).

image.title2: Engraving of Lancaster Castle by R. Parr after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts the John O' Gaunt Gateway, Lancaster Castle, Lancashire. Lancaster Castle was founded by Roger of Poitou at the end of the eleventh century. Sir Walter Scott, in his Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft, describes the Lancashire witch trials of 1612 (Letter VIII) where ten women were convicted of witchcraft at Lancaster Castle and hanged.

image.title2: Engraving of Lincluden Collegiate Church by an unattributed artist
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Lincluden Collegiate Church, Dumfriesshire. Lincluden College was established in 1389 by Archibald the Grim, Lord of Galloway. According to the Magnum Opus edition of The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1830), it was here that Helen Goldie, Scott's source for the tale, first met Helen Walker, the prototype for Jeanie Deans. It has also been suggested that the monastic ruins which Guy Mannering sketches in the opening chapter of the novel of that name are those of Lincluden College.

image.title2: Engraving of Linlithgow Palace by W.H. Lizars after J.B. Kidd
image.creator: Kidd, Joseph Bartholomew
image.description: Depicts Linlithgow Palace, West Lothian, beside the shore of Linlithgow Loch. Linlithgow Palace was built in the eleventh century and was a royal residence from the twelfth to the late sixteenth century. It was accidentally gutted by fire in 1746. In Marmion (1808), Sir Walter Scott describes Linlithgow as: 'Of all the palaces so fair, | Built for the royal dwelling, | In Scotland, far beyond compare | Linlithgow is excelling;' (canto IV, stanza XV, lines 1-4). The Palace is more fully described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and features in a number of his other works, notably Waverley (1814) and Tales of a Grandfather (1828-1830). The entrance porch at Scott's home of Abbotsford was modelled after that of Linlithgow Palace.

image.title1: Loch Achray (Perthshire): From the Black Rock
image.title2: Engraving of Loch Achray by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts cattle grazing by the shores of Loch Achray, Stirling. Loch Achray appears in Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810): 'The Minstrel came once more to view | The eastern ridge of Benvenue, | For, ere he parted, he would say | Farewell to lovely Loch Achray--- | Where shall he find, in foreign land, | So lone a lake, so sweet a strand!' (canto VI, stanza XV, lines 1-6).

image.title2: Engraving of Loch Ard by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts Loch Ard, Stirling, and the surrounding countryside. Loch Ard is described in chapter 20 of Scott's Rob Roy (1817): 'But the road now suddenly emerged from the forest ground, and, winding close by the margin of the loch, afforded us a full view of its spacious mirror, which now, the breeze having totally subsided, reflected in still magnificence the high dark heathy mountains, huge grey rocks, and shaggy banks, by which it is encircled.' The Falls of Ledard at the head of the Loch are thought to be the model for the waterfall in the Glen of Glennaquoich in Waverley, ch. 22. Scott recommended the Loch and the Falls as artistic subjects to Sir David Wilkie and James Skene (Letters, IV, 484, and IX, 224).

image.title1: Loch Awe and Kilchurn Castle (Argyleshire): From the Gooses Rock
image.title2: Engraving of Loch Awe and Kilchurn Castle by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts Kilchurn Castle on the shores of Loch Awe (Argyll and Bute). Loch Awe and its surrounding countryside feature in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works. 'The Highland Widow' (1827) is set on its banks. In 'Nora's Vow', translated from the Gaelic for Albyn's Anthology (published by Alexander Campbell in 1816), the heroine protests that she will never marry the Earl's son even if 'The Awe's fierce stream may backward turn, | Ben-Cruaichan fall, and crush Kilchurn' (III.3-4). Loch Awe also appears in A Legend of Montrose, ch. 17. In a letter to the painter Sir David Wilkie, dated 2 August 1817), Scott recommends that he 'visit the head of Loch Awe, which I look upon as equal to any thing in the Highlands' (Letters, IV, 484).

The Loch is also mentioned briefly in The Fair Maid of Perth (1828).

Following the success of the poem, the Loch and the surrounding Trossachs region became major tourist attractions. The original work by Thomas Allom was made expressly for William Beattie's Scotland Illustrated (1836).

image.title2: Engraving of Loch Katrine and Ellen's Isle by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts Ellen's Isle in Loch Katrine, Stirling. In Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810), the Earl of Bothwell and his daughter Ellen take refuge on an island in Loch Katrine. Following the success of the poem, the Loch became a major tourist attractions and one of its islands was identified as Scott's setting and became known as 'Ellen's Isle'.

image.title1: Loch Leven and Castle (Kinross-shire): Looking West
image.title2: Engraving of Loch Leven Castle by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts three figures among the ruins of Loch Leven Castle, Fife. Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820) centres around the imprisonment and escape from Loch Leven Castle of Mary, Queen of Scots. The thirteenth-century castle, built on the largest island in the Loch, also figures repeatedly in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).

image.creator: Cattermole, George

Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820) centres around the imprisonment and escape from Loch Leven Castle of Mary, Queen of Scots. The thirteenth-century castle, built on the largest island in the Loch, also figures repeatedly in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828). This engraving was first published in the first edition of Leitch Ritchie's Scott and Scotland (1835).

image.title1: Loch Lochy (Invernesshire): From Tor-a-cromerk, Looking North East
image.title2: Engraving of Loch Lochy by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts a small farmstead on the shores of Loch Lochy, Scottish Highlands. Loch Lochy appears in Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819), ch. 18, as the Marquis of Argyll's army prepares to set up headquarters in Inverlochy Castle.

image.title1: Loch Lomond (Dumbartonshire): From Mount Misery Looking North
image.title2: Engraving of Loch Lomond by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts Loch Lomond and surrounding mountains. Loch Lomond forms a dramatic part of the scenery in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works, including Rob Roy and The Lady of the Lake, where Roderick Dhu is portrayed as 'the terror of Loch Lomond's side' (canto II, stanza XI, line 14). Scott visited the Loch with his wife in the summers of 1809, 1816, and 1817.

image.title2: Engraving of Loch Vennachar by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts Loch Vennachar, Perthshire, and surrounding countryside. Loch Vennachar, Perthshire, figures prominently in both Marmion (1808) and The Lady of the Lake (1810). In canto V of the latter, the wounded Roderick Dhu is carried on horseback from the shores of Loch Vennachar to Stirling Castle. In September 1809, Scott made the same ride himself to verify whether it was possible in the time he planned to allot to it in the poem.

image.title2: Engraving of Hawick by W. Warwick after D.O. Hill
image.creator: Hill, David Octavius
image.description: Depicts the town of Hawick, Scottish Borders, and the surrounding countryside. Hawick appears in Sir Walter Scott's The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'Dimly he view'd the Moat-hill's mound, | Where Druid shades still flitted round; | In Hawick twinkled many a light' (canto I, stanza XXV, lines 9-11). It is described in detail in Scott's Border Antiquities of England and Scotland (1814). Hawick is also connected to Scott through the prototype for Old Mortality, Robert Patterson, who was a native of the town.

image.title2: Engraving of Loch Lubnaig by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts Loch Lubnaig, Stirling, and surrounding countryside. Loch Lubnaig appears in Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810): 'Then, trusting not a second look, | In haste he sped him up the brook, | Nor backward glanced, till on the heath | Where Lubnaig's lake supplies the Teith' (canto III, stanza XXII, lines 5-8). Scott had first seen the Loch when travelling to Crieff in September 1796.

image.title1: Loch Oich and Invergarry Castle (Inverness-shire): Looking West
image.title2: Engraving of Loch Oich by J. Swan after J. Fleming
image.creator: Fleming, John
image.description: Depicts Loch Oich, Scottish Highlands, with Invergarry Castle on the far shore. Invergarry Castle was the seat of the MacDonells of Glengarry until it was burned down in 1746 following the battle of Culloden. The fugitive Prince Charles Edward Stuart is reputed to have taken refuge in the castle, an episode which Scott relates in Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1830). In The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818), the Jacobite Captain of Knockdunder recalls being garrisoned in the Castle during the '45.

image.title1: Loch Skene: A Retreat of the Covenanters
image.title2: Engraving of Loch Skene by W. Forrest after D.O. Hill
image.creator: Hill, David Octavius
image.description: Depicts a coventicle (an illegal open air religious service) on the banks of Loch Skeen (or Skene), Dumfries and Galloway. Scott describes the 'savage scene [...] which frowns round dark Loch-skene' in the Introduction to Canto II of Marmion (1808), lines 237-63. The same Moffatdale landscape, a refuge for the Covenanters, is also invoked in Old Mortality (1816). Scott first visited Moffatdale in 1805 in the company of James Skene of Rubislaw, Sir Adam Fergusson and James Hogg.

image.title1: The Heart of London: From Tower Bridge
image.title2: Facsimile of a painting of London by E.W. Haslehust
image.creator: Haslehurst, Ernest William
image.description: Depicts a view of London from the Tower Bridge, including the Thames River and St. Paul's Cathedral. Sir Walter Scott visited London on several occasions, and the city appears in a number of his novels, most notably The Fortunes of Nigel (1822) and Peveril of the Peak (1823).

image.title2: Facsimile of a painting of the Tower of London by E.W. Haslehust
image.creator: Haslehurst, Ernest William
image.description: Depicts a guard at the Gateway to the Tower of London. The eponymous hero of Sir Walter Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel (1822) is imprisoned on a charge of treason in the Tower of London, as are Julian and Sir Geoffrey Peveril in Peveril of the Peak (1823).

image.title1: Looking West up Fleet Street to the Law Courts
image.title2: Facsimile of a painting of Fleet Street by E.W. Haslehust
image.creator: Haslehurst, Ernest William
image.description: Depicts a view down Fleet Street, London, to the Royal Courts of Justice. Fleet Street is the location for the shop of David Ramsay, the watchmaker, in Sir Walter Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel (1822). Nigel's retainer Richie Moniplies is wounded in an affray on Fleet Street in the first chapter of the novel.

image.title2: Facsimile of a painting of Temple Church by E.W. Haslehust
image.creator: Haslehurst, Ernest William
image.description: Depicts the Gothic arches of the porch of Temple Church, London. In chapter 14 of The Fortunes of Nigel (1822), Nigel Olifaunt compares the face of his retainer Richie Moniplies to one of the gargoyles of the 12th-century Temple Church. There is also a reference in chapter 35 of Ivanhoe (1819), where the Grand Master of the Knights Templar declares: 'Not one object in England hath met mine eye which it could rest upon with pleasure, save the tombs of our brethren, beneath the massive roof of our Temple Church in yonder proud capital.' The Temple Church was built by the Knights Templar in the 12th century as their English headquarters.

image.title1: Melrose from the East: The Tweed in the Foreground
image.title2: Facsimile of a pencil drawing of Melrose by G. Home
image.creator: Home, Gordon
image.description: Depicts a view of the Melrose countryside, Scottish Borders, with the River Tweed in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott's home of Abbotsford lay only a few miles west of the town of Melrose in the Scottish Borders. Melrose is set in the heart of the 'Scott Country', and is featured in many of his works, most notably The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) and, under the guise of 'Kennaquhair', in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820). Town and abbey are described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).

image.title2: Engraving of the ruins of Melrose Abbey by E. Finden after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts the Gothic vaulted arches of the ruins of Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott coordinated the restoration of Melrose Abbey in 1822. The Abbey features in many of Scott's works, most famously The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'If thou would'st view fair Melrose aright, | Go visit it by the pale moonlight [...] | Then view St. David's ruin'd pile; | And, home returning, soothly swear, | Was never scene so sad and fair!' (canto II, stanza I, lines 1-2, 16-18). The religious house of Kennaquhair in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) is based on the Abbey, and it is described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).

image.description: Depicts the south front of Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott coordinated the restoration of Melrose Abbey in 1822. The Abbey features in many of Scott's works, most famously The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'If thou would'st view fair Melrose aright, | Go visit it by the pale moonlight [...] | Then view St. David's ruin'd pile; | And, home returning, soothly swear, | Was never scene so sad and fair!' The print was made by one, or possibly both, of the Edinburgh engravers James and John Johnstone.

image.title2: Engraving by T. Higham after G. Cattermole of a scene from Scott's novel The Abbot
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts Magdalen and Roland Graeme visiting Melrose Abbey, Scottish Borders, after it has been sacked by the Reformers (The Abbot, ch. 8). Lances and swords of antique size, which had hung over the tombs of mighty warriors of former days, lay now strewed among relics.' The engraving was first published in the first edition of Leitch Ritchie's Scott and Scotland (1835).

image.title1: Neidpath Castle on the Tweed, Peebleshire
image.title2: Facsimile of a watercolour painting of Neidpath Castle by S. Palmer
image.creator: Palmer, Harold Sutton
image.description: Depicts Neidpath Castle, Scottish Borders, on a bluff overlooking the River Tweed. Sir Walter Scott's poem, 'The Maid of Neidpath', was published in William Whyte's A Collection of Scottish Airs (1806-07): 'Disease had been in Mary's bower | And slow decay from mourning, | Though now she sits on Neidpath's tower | To watch her Love's returning' (lines 5-8). Neidpath, near Peebles, is a 14th-century castle converted into a 17th-century tower house. At the turn of the 19th century, it was home to Scott's close friend Adam Ferguson. Neidpath Castle has also been suggested as the model for Saint Ronan's Castle as described in chapter I of Saint Ronan's Well (1823).

image.description: Depicts Newark Castle, Scottish Borders, overlooking the River Yarrow. Scott accompanied William Wordsworth on a visit to the ruined 15th-century castle in September 1831 which inspired Wordsworth's poem 'Yarrow Revisited'.

image.creator: Home, Gordon
image.description: Depicts the River Tweed with Norham Castle, Northumberland, in the background. Sir Walter Scott's Marmion (1808) begins with the arrival of Lord Marmion at Norham Castle: 'Day set on Norham's castled steep, | And Tweed's fair river, broad and deep, | And Cheviot's mountains lone: | The battled towers, the donjon keep, | The loophole grates, where captives weep, | The flanking walls that round it sweep, | In yellow lustre shone' (canto I, stanza I, lines 1-7) . Lord Marmion spends the night at Norham then proceeds on a mission to the Scottish Court.

image.title1: Entrance to the Peak Cavern, Derbyshire
image.title2: Engraving of Peak Cavern by E. Finden after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts cottages within the entrance of Peak Cavern, Derbyshire, and villagers making ropes. The hero of Sir Walter Scott's novel, Peveril of the Peak, is the descendant of the Norman knight William Peveril who built a castle overhanging the Peak Cavern or Devil's Cavern in Derbyshire. Peak Cavern has the largest natural cave entrance in the British Isles. A village was established within the entrance whose inhabitants made ropes for the local lead mines.

image.title2: Engraving of Preston, Lancashire by E. Finden after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts a view of the windmills of the city of Preston, Lancashire. The Battle of Preston (1715), in which the Jacobites were defeated by the Hanoverian army, features in a number of Scott's works. In Waverley (1814), Sir Everard Waverley befriends the Baron of Bradwardine when the latter is taken prisoner after the battle (ch. 6). In Rob Roy (1817), Frank Osbaldistone's uncle Sir Hildebrand and cousin John are taken prisoner and his cousin Wilfred killed in the engagement (ch. 37). In The Black Dwarf (1816), Sir Frederick Langley is also taken captive after the battle and subsequently executed. The Jacobite campaign of 1715 is discussed in depth in Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1830).

image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts the Church of St John the Evangelist in Preston, Lancashire, with a view of Church Street and Fishergate. The Jacobite campaign of 1715 is discussed in depth in Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1830). The church building depicted in this engraving was demolished in 1853 and a new church, Preston Minster, was built on the original foundations.

image.title2: Engraving of Roslin Castle by W. Forrest after D.O. Hill
image.creator: Hill, David Octavius
image.description: Depicts two female figures by the banks of the River Esk with Rosslyn Castle, Midlothian, in the background. Rosslyn (or Roslin) Castle is featured in Sir Walter Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) in the ballad of 'Rosabelle' recited by the bard Harold: 'O'er Roslin all that dreary night, | A wondrous blaze was seen to gleam; | 'Twas broader than the watch-fire's light, | And redder than the bright moon-beam' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 25-28). The castle, a ruined 14th-century building located 9 miles south of Edinburgh, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).

image.description: Depicts the interior of the south-east end of Rosslyn Chapel, Midlothian. Rosslyn (or Roslin) Chapel is featured in Sir Walter Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) in the ballad of 'Rosabelle' recited by the bard Harold: 'Seem'd all on fire that chapel proud, | Where Roslin's chiefs uncoffin'd lie... | Seem'd all on fire within, around, | Deep sacristy and altar's pale; | Shone every pillar foliage-bound, | And glimmer'd all the dead men's mail' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 33-40). The chapel, a 15th-century building located 9 miles south of Edinburgh, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and is thought to have provided the model for the convent of Engaddi in The Talisman (1825). Its architecture inspired the rich moulded ceiling of the library at Scott's home of Abbotsford.

image.title2: Facsimile of a painting of Roxburgh Castle by E.W. Haslehust
image.creator: Haslehurst, Ernest William
image.description: Depicts the River Teviot with the ruins of Roxburgh Castle, Scottish Borders, in the background. In his unfinished Autobiography (1808), Scott lists the 'distant vestiges of Roxburgh Castle' among the sights which make Kelso 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic village in Scotland'. Roxburgh Castle is a ruined 11th-century royal residence which repeatedly changed hands during the Wars of Independence. Scott relates the tale of its daring capture by Sir James Douglas (the 'Black Douglas') in 1313 in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828). There are further brief mentions of the castle in The Monastery (1820) and The Talisman (1825). The entrance hall at Abbotsford boasts two cannonballs supposed to have been used in the siege of Roxburgh Castle in 1460.

Scott spent many summers in Kelso at his uncle Captain Robert Scott's house of Rosebank, which Scott inherited in 1804.

image.title2: Engraving of the village of Moffat by W. Forrest after D. O. Hill
image.creator: Hill, David Octavius
image.description: Depicts a group camped on a hillside overlooking the village of Moffat, Dumfries and Galloway, and surrounding countryside. Much of the scenery for Sir Walter Scott's Old Mortality (1816) was derived from a visit Scott made in 1805 to the region around Moffat, Dumfriesshire, with James Skene of Rubislaw, Sir Adam Ferguson and James Hogg. Moffatdale provided refuge for many Covenanters during the 'Killing Times'.

image.title2: Engraving of St. Mary's Loch by W. Miller after P. Paton
image.creator: Paton, Peter
image.description: Depicts a man and a woman by the banks of St. Mary's Loch, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott most famously describes St. Mary's Loch in Marmion (1808): 'Oft in my mind such thoughts awake, | By lone Saint Mary's silent lake; | Thou know'st it well,---nor fen, nor sedge, | Pollute the pure lake's crystal edge; | Abrupt and sheer, the mountains sink | At once upon the level brink; | And just a trace of silver sand | Marks where the water meets the land' (Introduction to Canto Second, lines 146-153). Scott made many excursions to the loch, situated near Moffat in the Scottish Borders. The surrounding landscape (Moffatdale) is featured in Old Mortality (1816).

image.title2: Coloured wood block engraving of Scone Palace by B. Fawcett after A.F. Lydon
image.creator: Lydon, A. F.
image.description: Depicts Scone Palace, Perthshire, and its grounds. Scone Palace, near Perth, was rebuilt between 1803 and 1812 under the supervision of William Atkinson, the architect whom Sir Walter Scott subsequently employed to create Abbotsford.

image.title2: Engraving of the town of Selkirk by W. Miller after P. Paton
image.creator: Paton, Peter
image.description: Depicts the town of Selkirk, Scottish Borders, and surrounding countryside. On 16 December 1799 Sir Walter Scott was appointed Sheriff Depute of Selkirkshire, a post which he held until his death in 1832. The post required Scott to reside in the county for part of the year, in order to perform his duties at Selkirk Sheriff Court. Initially Scott stayed at Clovenfords Inn, near Galashiels, but eventually in 1804 leased the property of Ashestiel. Selkirk is often thought to be the model for Middlemass, the Border town portrayed in the opening chapters of 'The Surgeon's Daughter' (1827).

image.title2: Engraving of the city of Sheffield by E. Finden after W. Westall
image.creator: Westall, William
image.description: Depicts the River Don with the city of Sheffield, South Yorkshire, in the background. Sir Walter Scott's Ivanhoe (1819) is largely set in a tract of forest lying between the cities of Doncaster and Sheffield in South Yorkshire. The disguised hero accompanies the Jewish financier Isaac of York as far as Sheffield in chapter 6 of the novel. Scott passed through Sheffield when returning to Edinburgh from London in May 1807. His son Walter was stationed there in 1830.

image.title1: [Facsimile of a painting of Smailholm Tower by Thomas Scott]
image.creator: Scott, Thomas
image.description: Depicts Smailholm Tower (Scottish Borders) atop Sandyknowe Crag with a horse and rider in the foreground. Smailholm Tower, near Kelso, is a fifteenth-century peel tower which was the home of Sir Walter Scott's ancestors the Scotts of Harden. The tower is situated on Sandyknowe Crag, above Sandyknowe Farm where Walter Scott spent much of his early childhood at the home of his paternal grandparents: 'Then rise those crags, that mountain tower, | Which charm'd my fancy's wakening hour.' (Marmion, Introduction to Canto Third, lines 158-59). Besides celebrating Smailholm Tower in Marmion, Scott set his ballad 'The Eve of St John' (1799) there and is thought to have modelled Avenel Castle in The Monastery and the Abbot (both 1820) on the tower.
