The architects were William Atkinson and Edward Blore, with assistance from Scott himself.

image.title2: Engraving of Ben Lomond by S. Lacey after T.H. Shepherd
image.creator: Shepherd, Thomas Hosmer
image.description: Depicts a view of Loch Lomond from Dumbarton, with Ben Lomond in the background. Ben Lomond and Loch Lomond form a dramatic part of the scenery in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works, including Rob Roy (1817) and The Lady of the Lake (1810), where Roderick Dhu is portrayed as 'the terror of Loch Lomond's side' (canto II, stanza XI, line 14). Scott visited the Loch with his wife in the summers of 1809, 1816, and 1817.

image.title2: Lithograph of Ben More by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
image.creator: Leitch, William Leighton
image.description: Depicts Ben More (or Benmore), Stirling, and surrounding mountains with a cowherd and his cattle in the foreground. The 'proud crest of proud Benmore' is described in one of Scott's earliest poems, Glenfinlas, or Lord Ronald's Coronach (1800). There are further references in Waverley (1814), The Lord of the Isles (1815), and The Fair Maid of Perth (1828).

image.title2: Engraving of the Battle of Bothwell Bridge by G. Greatbach
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts the opposing armies of the Government and the Covenanters clashing on Bothwell Bridge, South Lanarkshire. The Battle of Bothwell Bridge (22 June 1679) saw a government army under James, Duke of Monmouth, decisively defeat an army of Covenanters and effectively put an end to their rebellion. It is dramatized in ch. 31-32 of Scott's Old Mortality (1816). Scott also included the traditional 'Ballad of Bothwell Brig' in his Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-1803), adding extensive historical notes, and gave a further account of the battle in the Second Series of his Tales of a Grandfather (1828).

image.title2: Lithograph of the ruins of Bothwell Castle by E. Walker after S. Prout
image.creator: Prout, Samuel
image.description: Depicts the ruins of the South-East Tower of Bothwell Castle, South Lanarkshire. In ch. 37 of Scott's Old Mortality (1816), Henry Morton passes the 'romantic ruins of Bothwell Castle' as he revisits the scene of the Covenanters' defeat at the Battle of Bothwell Bridge (1679). Scott had first visited the castle, a 13th-century edifice located southeast of Glasgow, in 1799 when visiting Lord and Lady Douglas. He was inspired to write the unfinished ballad 'Bothwell Castle'. On a later visit he wrote the ballad of 'Young Lochinvar' which he published as part of Marmion (1808).

image.title1: Charles Edouard, fils ąn̩ de Jacques Stuard, n̩ a Rome, le 31. D̩cembre 1720
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Prince Charles Edward Stuart by J. Daull̩ after D. Dupra
image.creator: Dupra, Domenico
image.description: Engraved portrait of Charles Edward Stuart ('Bonnie Prince Charlie') (1720-1788). Charles Edward Stuart features as a character in two of Sir Walter Scott's novels, Waverley (1814) which is set during the Jacobite Rebellion of 1745-1746, and Redgauntlet (1824) which portrays a fictional further Jacobite uprising in 1765. Scott also describes Charles's role in the 1745-1746 Rebellion in Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1829). The original portrait by Domenico Dupra was painted c.1741.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Prince Charles Edward Stuart by E. Finden after L. Tocqu̩
image.creator: Tocqu̩, Louis
image.description: Engraved portrait of Charles Edward Stuart ('Bonnie Prince Charlie') (1720-1788). Charles Edward Stuart features as a character in two of Sir Walter Scott's novels, Waverley (1814) which is set during the Jacobite Rebellion of 1745-1746, and Redgauntlet (1824) which portrays a fictional further Jacobite uprising in 1765. Scott also describes Charles's role in the 1745-1746 Rebellion in Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1829). The original portrait by Louis Tocqu̩ was painted in 1748. Its whereabouts is unknown, and the engraver Edward Francis Finden was probably working from an earlier engraving executed in 1748 by Georg Johann Wille.

image.title2: Lithograph of Crichton Castle by T. Picken after T. Creswick
image.creator: Creswick, Thomas
image.description: Depicts the River Tyne with Crichton Castle, Midlothian, on a hill in the background. In Sir Walter Scott's Marmion (1808), Lord Marmion and Lord Lindesay spend two days at Crichton Castle in Midlothian: 'Crichtoun! though now thy miry court | But pens the lazy steer and sheep, | Thy turrets rude, and totter'd Keep, | Have been the minstrel's loved resort' (canto IV, stanza XI, lines 1-4). The castle is described in detail in stanzas X-XI of the poem. Scott traces the history of the fourteenth-century castle in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).

image.title1: John Wilson Croker, Esqr., M.P., Secretary to the Admiralty: Engraved by T. Blood for the European Magazine From an Original Painting by S. Drummond A.R.A.
image.title2: Engraved portrait of John Wilson Croker by T. Blood after S. Drummond
image.creator: Drummond, Samuel
image.description: Engraved portrait of British statesman John Wilson Croker (1780-1857) in a fur-collared coat. Croker was a close friend and political ally of Sir Walter Scott. In 1813 Scott wrote to Croker to suggest Robert Southey for the post of Poet Laureate (a post that Scott himself had declined). In 1818 Croker also assisted Scott in obtaining a warrant to search for the Regalia (Crown Jewels) of Scotland. In 1824 Croker persuaded Scott to join with Thomas Moore and others to found the Athenaeum Club. Their relations were momentarily strained in 1826 when Croker penned a caustic reply to Scott's Letters of Malachi Malagrowther. Scott would subsequently assist Croker with his new edition of Boswell's Life of Johnson (1831). Another work by Croker, Stories for Children from the History of England (1817), provided the model for Scott's Tales of a Grandfather (1828-1831). The original portrait by Samuel Drummond was probably commissioned by the European Magazine in 1812.

image.title1: The Right Honble. John Wilson Croker
image.title2: Engraved portrait of John Wilson Croker by W. Finden after T. Lawrence
image.creator: Lawrence, Thomas
image.description: Engraved half-length portrait of British statesman John Wilson Croker (1780-1857). Croker was a close friend and political ally of Sir Walter Scott. In 1813 Scott wrote to Croker to suggest Robert Southey for the post of Poet Laureate (a post that Scott himself had declined). In 1818 Croker also assisted Scott in obtaining a warrant to search for the Regalia (Crown Jewels) of Scotland. In 1824 Croker persuaded Scott to join with Thomas Moore and others to found the Athenaeum Club. Their relations were momentarily strained in 1826 when Croker penned a caustic reply to Scott's Letters of Malachi Malagrowther. Scott would subsequently assist Croker with his new edition of Boswell's Life of Johnson (1831). Another work by Croker, Stories for Children from the History of England (1817), provided the model for Scott's Tales of a Grandfather (1828-1831). The original portrait by Sir Thomas Lawrence was first exhibited in 1825. Finden's engraving was published in 1838 as an illustration to H.T. Ryall's Portraits of Eminent Conservatives and Statesmen.

image.title1: Sir Humphrey Davy, Bart. P.R.S. : By Permission From the Large Print Published by Messrs. Agnew and Lanitti
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Humphry Davy by J. Jenkins after J. Lonsdale.
image.creator: Lonsdale, James
image.description: Engraved portrait of British scientist Sir Humphry Davy (1778-1829), with facsimile of signature. Sir Walter Scott and Davy were fellow guests of William Wordsworth's at Dove Cottage, Grasemere, in August 1805. Scott 'liked him excessively' and was 'particularly delighted with the total absence of pedantry which has always appeared to me the test of true genius' (letter to Jane Kerr Apreece, 2 April 1811). Davy later made two visits to Scott at Abbotsford in 1820 and 1823. In 1812 Davy had become a member of Scott's extended family by marrying his widowed cousin Jane Kerr Apreece. As a favour to her Scott wrote a review of Davy's Salmoniana for the Quarterly Review in 1828.

image.title2: Lithograph of Doune Castle by T. Picken after J. Dobbin
image.creator: Dobbin, John
image.description: Depicts cattle on the banks of the Teith River with Doune Castle, Stirling, in the background. In ch. 38 of Sir Walter Scott's Waverley (1814), Edward Waverley is rescued by a party of Jacobite Highlanders and escorted to Doune Castle in the Menteith district, a 'gloomy yet picturesque structure'. There are further references to the Castle in other works by Scott, notably The Lady of the Lake, canto VI.

image.title2: Engraving of the Battle of Drumclog by G. Greatbach
image.creator: Greatbach, George
image.description: Depicts Covenanters and the King's forces clashing at the Battle of Drumclog. The Battle of Drumclog (1 June 1879), in which a Covenanting army defeated John Grahame of Claverhouse's Royalist forces, is portrayed in chapters 15-17 of Sir Walter Scott's Old Mortality (1816). A further account of the battle is given in Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829). The plate is engraved by George Greatbach, probably from his own design.

image.title2: Lithograph of St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey by T. Picken after J. Dobbin
image.creator: Dobbin, John
image.description: Depicts a man and a woman visiting Scott's Sir Walter Scott's tomb in St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' (1808) that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.

image.title1: Dryburgh Abbey: Burial Aisle of Sir W. Scott
image.title2: Engraving of St. Mary's Aisle and Dryburgh Abbey by J. Bower
image.creator: Bower, John
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, with St. Mary's Aisle in the midground. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' (1808) that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.

image.title2: Engraving of Dryburgh Abbey by W. H. Lizars
image.creator: Lizars, William Home
image.description: Depicts a man walking past the south wall of the ruins of Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' (1808) that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here.

image.title1: Sir Walter Scott's Burial Place, Dryburgh Abbey
image.title2: Engraving of St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey by W. H. Lizars
image.creator: Lizars, William Home
image.description: Depicts a pair of young children at St. Mary's Aisle, Dryburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott was interred in St. Mary's Aisle on September 26, 1832. Scott lamented in his 'Autobiography' (1808) that, though his ancestors, the Haliburtons, once owned the Abbey, 'we have nothing left of Dryburgh... but the right of stretching our bones.' Scott's wife, Margaret Charlotte Carpenter, his eldest son, Walter Scott, and his son-in-law and biographer, J.G. Lockhart, are also buried here. The engraving was made by W.H. Lizars from his own design.

image.title2: Lithograph of Dunbar Castle by T. Picken after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts the harbour and ruined castle of Dunbar, East Lothian. Sir Walter Scott traced the history of Dunbar Castle in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). In his notes to 'Thomas the Rhymer' in Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802), Scott discusses prophetic verses attributed to Thomas of Ercildoune concerning the heroic defence of Dunbar Castle (1337) by the Countess of March ('Black Agnes'). A further account of the siege is given in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).

image.title2: Engraving of Dunbar Castle by E. Goodall after J. C. Schetky
image.creator: Schetky, John Christian
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Dunbar Castle, East Lothian, with a group of people in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott traced the history of Dunbar Castle in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). In his notes to 'Thomas the Rhymer' in Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802), Scott discusses prophetic verses attributed to Thomas of Ercildoune concerning the heroic defence of Dunbar Castle (1337) by the Countess of March ('Black Agnes'). A further account of the siege is given in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828). The original oil painting by John Christian Schetky, probably made specifically for Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland, is displayed in Abbotsford.

image.title2: Lithograph of Dunfermline Abbey by T. Picken after D. O. Hill
image.creator: Hill, David Octavius
image.description: Depicts wooded parkland with Dunfermline Abbey, Fife, visible through the trees. In Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828), Sir Walter Scott describes how Robert the Bruce's heart was removed from his body in Dunfermline Abbey and taken to Melrose Abbey. He then describes how a skeleton, wrapped in rich cloth and with its heart removed, was discovered by workmen during restoration work on Dunfermline Abbey in 1819. Scott had a cast made from the skeleton's skull which he exhibited at Abbotsford. In 1822 the Magistrates of Dunfermline made a gift to Scott of panelling from a post-Reformation church built in the nave of Dunfermline Abbey.

image.title1: Edinburgh from the Frith of Forth
image.title2: Lithograph of the Firth of Forth and Edinburgh by T. Picken after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts ships in the Firth of Forth with a view of Edinburgh in the background. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818).

image.title2: Engraving of the Regalia of Scotland by E. Goodall after A. Geddes
image.creator: Geddes, Andrew (b.1783, d.1844)
image.description: Depicts, from left to right, the Sceptre of James V, the Scottish Crown, and the Sword of State, which together constitute the Regalia of Scotland. Following the Act of Union between England and Scotland in 1707, the ancient Regalia (or 'Honours') of Scotland were deposited in a locked oak chest in the Crown Room of Edinburgh Castle. Over the following decades, their whereabouts was forgotten, and it was rumoured that, counter to the terms of the Union, they had been carried away to England. Prompted by Sir Walter Scott, the Prince Regent set up a commission to search the Crown Room for the Regalia. On 4 February 1818, the Commissioners, including Scott, discovered the chest and found, wrapped in linen, the fourteenth-century Scottish Crown, the Sceptre of James V, and the Sword of State, a gift from Pope Julius II to James V. The Regalia were subsequently placed on permanent display in the Crown Room. Scott described the discovery in his Description of the Regalia of Scotland (1819). Andrew Geddes was asked to paint the Regalia for the frontispiece to the 9th Part of the Provincial Antiquities in 1824. The oil painting on which the engraving is based is held at Abbotsford.

image.title1: Greyfriars' Churchyard: Signing of the Covenant
image.title2: Lithograph of the signing of the National Covenant by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts a crowd of people in Greyfriars Churchyard, Edinburgh, gathered to sign the National Covenant, with Edinburgh Castle in the background. In Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829), Sir Walter Scott describes the mass signing of the National Covenant in Greyfriars Kirkyard, Edinburgh, which began on 28 February 1638. The Covenant challenged the Divine Right of Kings, demanding a free Scottish Parliament, a free General Assembly of the Church of Scotland, the abolition of bishops, and establishment of Presbyterian church government. The ensuing 'Covenanting' wars feature in a number of Scott's works, most notably Old Mortality (1816). Greyfriars Kirkyard also had personal associations for Scott. His and sister were both buried there in the Scott family burial-plot. According to J. G. Lockhart, Scott also made the acquaintance of his first love Williamina Belsches in the Kirkyard.

image.title2: Lithograph by T. Picken after G. Cattermole of the murder of Rizzio in Queen Mary's Bedchamber, Holyrood Palace
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts the murder of David Rizzio (ca. 1533-1566) in Queen Mary's Bedchamber, Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh. The murderers of Mary Stuart's secretary David Rizzio dragged their victim from the Queen's presence into the royal bedchamber at the Palace of Holyroodhouse before dispatching him. This episode is described in Sir Walter Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828).There are further references to the murder in The Abbot and Chronicles of the Canongate.

image.title2: Lithograph of Liberton's Wynd, Edinburgh by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts street life on Libberton's Wynd, Edinburgh, outside Burn's Tavern. From 1817 until the date of the last public execution, the head of Libberton's (or Liberton's) Wynd, Edinburgh, was the site of the gallows. Among other executions, Sir Walter Scott witnessed that of the body-snatcher and murderer William Burke, 28 January, 1829.

image.title2: Lithograph of Moray House, Edinburgh by T. Picken after J. Nash
image.creator: Nash, Joseph
image.description: Depicts a fierce battle outside Moray House on Canongate, Edinburgh. In Sir Walter Scott's Chronicles of the Canongate (1827), Mrs Bethune Baliol recalls her mother's account of watching the last riding of the Scottish Parliament in 1707 from 'the balcony in front of Lord Moray's Lodging in the Canongate'. Moray House was built in the 1620s by Mary, Dowager Countess of Home. It served as Cromwell's Edinburgh lodgings in 1648 and 1650-1651, and was the scene of some of the negotiations which led to the Treaty of Union in 1707. The building is now part of Edinburgh University's Moray House School of Education.

image.title2: Lithograph of the National Monument, Calton Hill, Edinburgh by T. Picken after J.D. Harding
image.creator: Harding, James Duffield
image.description: Depicts the National Monument on Calton Hill, Edinburgh. The National Monument was built between 1824 and 1829 in memory of those who had died in the Napoleonic Wars. It was modelled on the Parthenon in Athens, but only the fa̤ade was completed. It is generally believed that funding ran out, but surviving drawings by the architects C. R. Cockerell and William Playfair suggest that no building had been projected beyond the extant structure. Scott wrote approvingly of Playfair's plans in a letter to Robert Johnston, 19 September 1819. Scott described Calton Hill in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826), but made no reference to the National Monument.

image.title2: Lithograph of the Scott Monument, Edinburgh by J. Sutcliffe
image.creator: Sutcliffe, John
image.description: Depicts the Scott Monument on Princes Street, Edinburgh, with Edinburgh Castle in the background. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.

image.title1: Sir Walter Scott: From the Statue in the Monument at Edinburgh
image.title2: Lithograph of Sir J. Steell's statue of Sir Walter Scott by J. Sutcliffe
image.creator: Steell, John, Sir (b.1804, d.1891)
image.description: Depicts a profile view of the statue of Walter Scott by Sir John Steell in the Scott Monument, Edinburgh. George Meikle Kemp won the competition to design a monument to Sir Walter Scott in 1838. The structure was begun in 1840 and completed in 1844. The monument, including the statue by Sir John Steell, was officially inaugurated 15 August 1846.

image.title2: Lithograph of West Bow, Edinburgh, by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts a group of soldiers marching down West Bow, Edinburgh. In The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818), ch. 3, a group of people including Bartoline Saddletree and Reuben Butler discuss the reprieve of Captain Porteous while returning to their houses in the Lawnmarket via 'the steep declivity of the West Bow'. The West Bow was originally a steep winding road leading from the Grassmarket (site of the gallows) to Castle Hill, offering the only means of access to Edinburgh Castle from the South. It was largely demolished in the 1830s when Victoria Street and George IV Bridge were built to provide more convenient access. Only a small portion of the West Bow now survives at the foot of Victoria Street.

image.title2: Lithograph of West Bow, Edinburgh, by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts a crowded street scene at the foot of West Bow, Edinburgh. West Bow was originally a steep winding road leading from the Grassmarket to Castle Hill, offering the only means of access to Edinburgh Castle from the South. It was largely demolished in the 1830s when Victoria Street and George IV Bridge were built to provide more convenient access. Only a small portion of the West Bow now survives at the foot of Victoria Street.

image.title2: Hand-coloured aquatint of a view of Eildon Hills by J. Merigot after J. Girten.
image.creator: Girtin, Thomas
image.description: Depicts the River Tweed with the Eildon Hills (Scottish Borders) in the background. In The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), Sir Walter Scott alludes to the legend that the peak of Eildon Hill was split into three by the wizard Michael Scott. The Monk of Melrose Abbey recalls meeting the wizard and tells Sir William of Deloraine: 'And, Warrior, I could say to thee | The words that cleft Eildon hills in three, | And bridled the Tweed with a curb of stone: | But to speak them were a deadly sin | And for having but thought them my heart within | A treble penance must be done' (canto II, stanza 13, lines 8-13). Scott's first aborted attempt to write a prose romance Thomas the Rhymer revolved around the legend that a cavern existed beneath the Eildon Hills, where King Arthur and his knights lay sleeping (see the General Introduction to the Waverley Novels (1829)). The Hills are mentioned in numerous other works by Scott, notably 'The Eve of St John' (1799). The prospect of the Eildon Hills from Bemersyde was a favourite of Scott's and is now known as 'Scott's view'.

image.title2: Lithograph of Falkland Palace by T. Picken after D. Roberts
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts the entrance to Falkland Palace, Fife. In Sir Walter Scott's 'Fair Maid of Perth', the heroine Catharine Glover is tricked into taking refuge in Falkland Castle to escape the attentions of the Duke of Rothsay, the heir to the Scottish throne. A further stratagem brings the Duke to the Castle where he is murdered by his dismissed Master of the Horse, Sir John Ramorny. Scott's Journal for 27 June 1829 records a visit to the 'most interesting remains' of Falkland Palace. There are further references to the building throughout Scott's works, notably in Marmion (1808) and Tales of a Grandfather (1828-31).

image.title2: Engraving of Melrose Abbey by T. Barber after T.H. Shepherd
image.creator: Shepherd, Thomas Hosmer

image.creator: Shepherd, Thomas Hosmer

image.title2: Pencil drawing tinted with watercolour of Flodden Field by P. Home
image.creator: Home, Percy
image.description: Depicts Flodden Field, Northumberland, and surrounding countryside. Sir Walter Scott's poem Marmion culminates in one of the greatest disasters in Scottish history, the Battle of Flodden Field. It is described at length in Canto Sixth ('The Battle'). Scott visited the battlefield in August 1791.

image.title2: Lithograph of Fast Castle by T. Picken after H. Bright
image.creator: Bright, Henry
image.description: Depicts Fast Castle near St Abbs Head, Berwickshire. Fast Castle has been identified as an inspiration for Wolf's Crag, the home of the Master of Ravenswood in Sir Walter Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor (1819). In the Magnum Opus edition of the novel (1830), Scott claims that he cannot comment on the perceived resemblance between Wolf's Crag and Fast Castle as he has only seen the latter from the sea. He acknowledges, however, that the position of Fast Castle resembles that of Wolf's Crag. Scott also describes the castle in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). Scott owned a painting of Fast Castle by the Rev. John Thomson (Letters, VIII, 459).

image.title2: Lithograph of Glamis Castle by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts Glamis Castle, Angus. Scott visited Glamis (or Glammis) Castle, seat of the Earl of Strathmore in 1793. In his Letters on Demonology and Witchcraft (1830), he recalls experiencing 'that degree of superstitious awe that my countrymen call eerie' when spending the night at the notoriously haunted castle. He wrote: 'I must own, that as I heard door after door shut, after my conductor had retired, I began to consider myself too far from the living and somewhat too near the dead' (Letter X). Glenallan House in Scott's novel, The Antiquary (1816), is said to be based on Glamis Castle.

image.title2: Lithograph of Glencoe by T. Picken after H. McCulloch
image.creator: McCulloch, Horatio
image.description: Depicts the valley of Glencoe in the Scottish Highlands. Sir Walter Scott wrote the poem 'On the Massacre of Glencoe' in 1814. He also described the massacre at length in Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1828).

image.title2: Lithograph of Glen Falloch by T. Picken after G.F. Robson
image.creator: Robson, George Fennel
image.description: Depicts Glen Falloch with the River Falloch running into Loch Lomond. While researching Rob Roy (1817), Walter Scott visited Glen Falloch at the head of Loch Lomond. It is mentioned in ch. 29 of the novel as a sure place of refuge for Rob Roy Macgregor as it belongs to his wife's relatives. Glen Falloch has also been identified with the 'gloomy and desolate' spot, haunted by a spirit known as the 'Cloght-dearg', where the clergyman Mr Tyrie meets Elspat MacTavish Mhor in The Highland Widow (1827). The original drawing by G. F. Robson was probably taken expressly for Scotland Delineated.

image.title1: 'Julia Mannering' from Sir Walter Scott's 'Guy Mannering'
image.title2: Facsimile of painting of Julia Mannering by Sir J.D. Linton
image.creator: Linton, James Dromgole
image.description: Profile portrait of Julia Mannering, heroine of Scott's novel Guy Mannering. Julia Mannering is the daughter of Guy Mannering in the novel of that name (1815). She marries Harry Bertram, the hero of the tale.

image.title2: Engraving of Jedburgh Abbey by R. Godfrey
image.creator: Godfrey, Richard Bernard
image.description: Depicts Jedburgh Abbey, Scottish Borders, and kirkyard. Sir Walter Scott describes Jedburgh Abbey in his 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814), inaccurately praising its Anglo-Norman chapter-house as 'a very perfect specimen of Saxon architecture'. There are further references in The Black Dwarf and The Monastery. The Abbey was built by David I around 1138 but had fallen into ruin by the mid-sixteenth century. Scott was a frequent visitor to Jedburgh in his capacity as Sheriff Depute of Selkirkshire. He subscribed �10 toward the repair-work on the Abbey's tower in 1824-1826. The engraving by Richard Godfrey was probably made for Francis Grose's The Antiquarian Repertory (1775-1784). It is likely to have been made from Godfrey's own design.

image.title2: Lithograph of Kelso Abbey by T. Picken after D. Roberts
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Kelso Abbey, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott described Kelso in his unfinished Autobiography (1808) as 'the most beautiful, if not the most romantic village in Scotland'. Scott spent many summers in Kelso at his uncle Captain Robert Scott's house of Rosebank, which Scott inherited in 1804. In 1783, a convalescent Scott also attended Kelso Grammar School, where he made the acquaintance of his future business partner James Ballantyne. Kelso Abbey is one of four founded in the Borders by King David I. It is described in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814).

image.title1: The Back of old Leith Pier
image.title2: Lithograph of Leith Pier by T. Picken after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts Leith Pier, Edinburgh, with people gathered around a boat on the shore. According to his friend James Skene of Rubislaw, Scott frequently walked to Leith Pier, 'to which the freshness of the sea breeze offered a strong inducement to those accustomed to pass a few of the morning hours within the close and impure atmosphere of the Court of Session' (quoted in The Journal of Sir Walter Scott (Edinburgh: David Douglas, 1890), I, 210, n. 1). Scott gave a description and historical account of Leith harbour in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). Leith Pier features in Waverley (1814), ch. 56, where Edward Waverley obtains permission for his prisoner Colonel Talbot to sail from there to England, and in Old Mortality (1816), ch. 36, where Henry Morton sails into European exile from Leith. Scott himself sailed from Leith on 29 July 1814 when he accompanied the Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection.

image.title2: Lithograph of Linlithgow Palace by T. Picken after D. Roberts
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts Linlithgow Palace and Linlithgow Loch (West Lothian). Linlithgow Palace was built in the eleventh century and was a royal residence from the twelfth to the late sixteenth century. It was accidentally gutted by fire in 1746. In Marmion (1808), Sir Walter Scott describes Linlithgow as: 'Of all the palaces so fair, | Built for the royal dwelling, | In Scotland, far beyond compare | Linlithgow is excelling;' (canto IV, stanza XV, lines 1-4). The Palace is more fully described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and features in a number of his other works, notably Waverley (1814) and Tales of a Grandfather (1828-30). The entrance porch at Scott's home of Abbotsford was modelled after that of Linlithgow Palace.

image.creator: McCulloch, Horatio
image.description: Depicts Loch Lomond and surrounding mountains. Loch Lomond forms a dramatic part of the scenery in a number of Sir Walter Scott's works, including Rob Roy and The Lady of the Lake, where Roderick Dhu is portrayed as 'the terror of Loch Lomond's side' (canto II, stanza XI, line 14). Scott visited the Loch with his wife in the summers of 1809, 1816, and 1817.

image.title2: Watercolour painting of Melrose market-place by an unknown artist
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts the Market Square of Melrose, Scottish Borders. Sir Walter Scott's home of Abbotsford lay only a few miles west of the town of Melrose in the Scottish Borders. Melrose is set in the heart of the 'Scott Country', and is featured in many of his works, most notably The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) and, under the guise of 'Kennaquhair', in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820). Town and abbey are described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814). At a vital moment in The Monastery, ch. 37, the Earl of Murray meets the Abbot of Kennaqhair beneath the 'mercat cross' in the town's marketplace to demand that he hand over Sir Piercie Shafton.

image.title2: Engraving of Minto Tower by W. Thomas after F. Grose
image.creator: Grose, Francis
image.description: Depicts Minto Tower (or Fatlips Castle), Scottish Borders. In The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), Sir William of Deloraine rides past the Minto Crags on his way to Melrose Abbey: 'On Minto-crags the moonbeams glint, | Where Barnhill hew'd his bed of flint; | Who flung his outlaw'd limbs to rest, | Where falcons hang their giddy nest, | Mid cliffs, from whence his eagle eye | For many a league his prey could spy; |Cliffs, doubling, on their echoes borne, | The terrors of the robber's horn' (canto I, stanza 27, lines 5-12). Minto Tower, more commonly known by the less poetical name of Fatlips Castle, is a 16th-century tower house, situated 4 miles west of Jedburgh. It was built by the Turnbulls of Barnhill, one of whom became a notorious Border freebooter. This view was probably drawn by Francis Grose in 1789 for his Antiquities of Scotland.

image.creator: Honthorst, Gerrit van
image.description: Depicts James Graham, Marquis of Montrose (1612-1650) in armour. Initially a Covenanter, Montrose was won over to the Royalist cause and waged a successful campaign against the Covenanters in the Highlands in 1644-1645. Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819) is set against the backdrop of the 'Montrose wars'. Montrose's campaign, his subsequent betrayal by Charles II and execution by the Covenanters are also described in Scott's Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829). Scott, a great admirer of Montrose, came into possession of his sword which he displayed in his 'armory' at Abbotsford. The original portrait by Gerrit van Honthorst was painted in 1649.

image.title2: Lithograph of Newark Castle after T. Picken after G. Cattermole
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts Sir Walter Scott (seated) and William Wordsworth by the River Yarrow, Scottish Borders, with Newark Castle in the background. This image depicts a visit made by Scott and Wordsworth in September 1831 which inspired Wordsworth's poem 'Yarrow Revisited'. In Scott's The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805), the minstrel receives hospitality from the Duchess of Buccleuch at Newark Castle and, in return, recites a tale about her ancestors.

image.title1: The Challenge: From the Painting in the Collection of W. Cuthbert Quilter, Esq.
image.title2: Engraving by J. Stephenson after a painting by W. Q. Orchardson depicting a scene from Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Orchardson, William Quiller
image.description: Depicts Sir Jasper Cranbourne presenting Geoffrey Peveril's challenge to Major Bridgenorth (Peveril of the Peak, ch. 9). Illustrates the following text: 'So saying, he [Cranbourne] took his sheathed rapier from his belt, and passing the point through the silk thread which secured the letter, he once more, and literally at sword point, gracefully tendered it to Major Bridgenorth who again waved it aside, though colouring deeply at the same time, as if he was putting a marked constraint upon himself' (Peveril of the Peak, ch. 9). The third figure in the engraving is the clergyman, Mr Solsgrace, who seeks to dissuade Major Bridgenorth from accepting the challenge. 'The Challenge', one of Orchardson's most celebrated paintings was completed in 1864.

image.title2: Drawing of Pinkie House by W. Geikie
image.creator: Geikie, Walter
image.description: Depicts Pinkie House, Musselburgh, East Lothian. In Sir Walter Scott's novel Waverley (1814), ch. 49-50, Charles Edward Stuart ('Bonnie Prince Charlie') establishes his headquarters at Pinkie House near Musselburgh following his victory at the Battle of Prestonpans. Built as a tower house in the sixteenth century, Pinkie House was greatly expanded by Sir Alexander Seton, Chancellor of Scotland, in 1613.

image.title1: [Covent Garden Theatre playbill for J.S. Knowles's production of The Vision of the Bard!]
image.creator: Covent Garden Theatre
image.description: Playbill for The Vision of the Bard!, starring James Sheridan Knowles; also contains advertisements for Waverley, The Beaux Stratagem, and His First Campaign, among other productions. The Irish dramatist and actor James Sheridan Knowles (1784-1862) wrote and took the principal role in The Vision of the Bard! (1832), a masque in honour of the recently deceased Sir Walter Scott, which featured scenes from various of his novels. It was first performed at Covent Garden, London, on 29 October 1832.

image.title1: [Lyceum Theatre playbill for The Wizard, or, The Brown Man of the Moor, adapted from Sir Walter Scott's novel The Black Dwarf]
image.creator: Lyceum Theatre (London, England)
image.description: Playbill for The Wizard; or The Brown Man of the Moor, also includes advertisements for My Uncle and Batchelors' Wives, among other productions. The musical drama The Wizard, or, The Brown Man of the Moor was adapted from Sir Walter Scott's The Black Dwarf (1816), with words by Samuel James Arnold (1774-1852) and music by Charles Edward Horn (1786-1849). It was first performed at the Lyceum Theatre, London (then known as 'The English Opera House) on 26 July 1817.

image.title1: [Theatre Royal, Edinburgh playbill for Guy Mannering, or, The Gypsy's Prophecy, a musical drama adapted from Sir Walter Scott's novel]
image.creator: Theatre Royal (Edinburgh, Scotland)
image.description: Playbill for Guy Mannering, or The Gypsy's Prophecy; also advertises The Maid of the Mill. Guy Mannering, or, The Gypsy's Prophecy was a very successful musical drama adapted from Sir Walter Scott's 1815 novel with words by Daniel Terry (1789-1829) and music by Sir Henry Bishop (1786-1855). Scott himself contributed to the libretto. It was first performed at the Covent Garden Theatre, London, on 12 March 1816.

image.creator: Covent Garden Theatre
image.description: Playbill for Guy Mannering; or The Gypsy's Prophecy; also advertises Husbands and Wives and Harlequin Gulliver. image.creator: Theatre Royal (Edinburgh, Scotland)
image.description: Playbill for Guy Mannering, also advertising a performance of Rob Roy for the following night. image.title1: [Covent Garden Theatre playbill for The Heart of Midlothian, a musical drama adapted from Sir Walter Scott's novel]
image.creator: Covent Garden Theatre
image.description: Playbill for The Heart of Midlothian, also advertising Fortunatus and his Sons, among other productions. The Heart of Midlothian was a musical drama adapted from Sir Walter Scott's 1818 novel with words by Daniel Terry (1789-1829) and music by Sir Henry Bishop (1786-1855). It was first performed at the Covent Garden Theatre, London, on 17 April 1819.

image.title1: [Theatre Royal, Edinburgh playbill for The Heart of Midlothian, a musical drama adopted from Sir Walter Scott's novel]
image.creator: Theatre Royal (Edinburgh, Scotland)
image.description: Playbill for The Heart of Midlothian, also advertising Thirty Years of a Gambler's Life, among other productions. The 'national drama' The Heart of Midlothian is probably a version of The Heart of Midlothian, or, The Lily of St. Leonards, a musical drama adapted from Sir Walter Scott's 1818 novel with words by Thomas John Dibdin (1771-1841) and music by Erskine. It was first performed at the Royal Circus, London, on 13 January 1819.

image.title1: [Covent Garden Theatre playbill for The Maid of Judah, or, Knights Templars, based on Sir Walter Scott's novel, Ivanhoe]
image.creator: Covent Garden Theatre
image.description: Playbill for The Maid of Judah, or, Knights Templars, also advertising Master's Rival, among other productions. The Maid of Judah is an adaptation by Michael Rophino Lacy (1795-1867) of Rossini's pasticcio Ivanho̩. Ivanho̩ was first performed at the Od̩on, Paris, on 15 September 1826, with a libretto by Emile Deschamps and Gustave de Wailly. The music was selected from four Rossini operas, Semiramide, Mos̬, Tancredi, and La gazza ladra, and arranged by Antonio Pacini. Scott himself was in the audience for the 31 October performance and wrote in his Journal: 'It was superbly got up, the Norman soldiers wearing pointed helmets and what resembled much hauberks of mail, which looked very well. The number of the attendants, and the skill with which they were moved and grouped on the stage, were well worthy of notice. It was an opera, and of course the story greatly mangled, and the dialogue in a great part nonsense. Yet it was strange to hear anything like the words which I (then in an agony of pain with spasms in my stomach) dictated to William Laidlaw at Abbotsford, now recited in a foreign tongue, and for the amusement of a strange people.' Lacy's adaptation was first performed at Covent Garden on 7 March 1829.

image.title1: [Theatre Royal, Edinburgh playbill for Rossini's opera La Donna del Lago, based on Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake]
image.creator: Theatre Royal (Edinburgh, Scotland)
image.description: Playbill for La Donna del Lago, or, The Lady of the Lake; also advertises Il Fanatico per la Musica, among other productions. La Donna del Lago was the first opera to be based on Sir Walter Scott's work and has proved one of the most successful. It was adapted from Scott's narrative poem The Lady of the Lake (1810) with music by Rossini and a libretto by Andrea Leone Tottola. The premi̬re took place at the Teatro San Carlo, Naples, on 24 September 1819. The first British performance took place at the Theatre Royal, London, in February 1823.

image.title1: Mr. O Smith, as Christie of the Clint-hill, in the White Lady, Theatre Royal, Drury Lane
image.title2: Theatrical portrait of Mr O. Smith as Christie of Clint-hill in The White Lady
image.creator: West, William
image.description: Depicts actor O. Smith (1786-1855) in the role of Christie of the Clinthill for the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. Richard John Smith, better known as O. Smith, specialized in villainous parts. Here he is portrayed in the role of Christie of the Clinthill in The White Lady, or, La Dame Blanche, a comic opera combining motifs from Sir Walter Scott's Guy Mannering (1815) and The Monastery (1820). With music by Fran̤ois Adrien Boieldieu (1775-1834) and libretto by Eug̬ne Scribe (1791-1861), it was first performed at the Op̩ra comique, Paris, on 10 December 1825. The first British production took place at Drury Lane on 9 October 1826, with additional music by Thomas Cooke (1782-1848), and a libretto by Samuel Beazley (1786-1851),which deviated drastically from Scribe's original and which followed Scott more closely. The character of Christie of the Clinthill, absent from the Scribe version, was, in fact, introduced by Beazley from Scott's The Monastery.

image.title1: [Covent Garden Theatre playbill for Peveril of the Peak, a musical drama adapted from Sir Walter Scott's novel]
image.creator: Covent Garden Theatre
image.description: Playbill for Peveril of the Peak; also advertises The Vauxhall Gala and Mother Shipton, among other productions. Peveril of the Peak was a musical drama adapted from Sir Walter Scott's 1823 novel with words by Isaac Pocock (1783-1835) and music by Charles Edward Horn (1786-1849). It was first performed on 17 October 1826 at Covent Garden.

image.title1: [Theatre Royal, Edinburgh playbill for Rob Roy, a musical drama adapted from Sir Walter Scott's novel]
image.creator: Theatre Royal (Edinburgh, Scotland)
image.description: Playbill for Rob Roy; also advertises My Neighbour's Wife and The Twa Drovers, among other productions. The 'national opera' Rob Roy is probably a version of the musical drama Rob Roy Macgregor, or, Auld Lang Syne, written by Isaac Pocock (1783-1835) with music by Sir Henry Bishop (1786-1855) and John Davy (1763-1824). Adapted from Sir Walter Scott's 1817 novel, it was first performed at Covent Garden, London, on 12 March 1818 and went on to become one of the most popular and frequently revived dramas of the nineteenth century.

image.title1: View of the Clyde above Erskine Ferry
image.title2: Lithograph of the Clyde River by E. Walker after W. L. Leitch
image.creator: Leitch, William Leighton
image.description: Depicts the Clyde river valley from Erskine Ferry. The Clyde River features in a number of works by Walter Scott, notably Rob Roy (1817), The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818), and Old Mortality (1816). In Rob Roy, Frank Osbaldistone travels through the Clyde valley on his way to Glasgow (ch. 19). In The Heart of Mid-Lothian, Jeanie Deans 'travelled through a thousand beautiful and changing views down the side of that noble stream' on her way to Inverary (ch. 40). Old Mortality, meanwhile, is set in Clydesdale, and much of the action takes place on the banks of the river.

image.title2: Painted engraving of Rosslyn Castle by F. Jukes after G. Walker
image.creator: Walker, George
image.description: Depicts Rosslyn Castle, Midlothian, and the River Esk. Rosslyn (or Roslin) Castle is featured in Sir Walter Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) in the ballad of 'Rosabelle' recited by the bard Harold: 'O'er Roslin all that dreary night, | A wondrous blaze was seen to gleam; | 'Twas broader than the watch-fire's light, | And redder than the bright moon-beam' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 25-28). The castle, a ruined 14th-century building located 9 miles south of Edinburgh, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). This print is dated 1793 in Catalogue of Maps, Prints, Drawings, etc: Forming the Geographical and Topographical Collection Attached to the Library of His Late Majesty King George the Third (London: British Museum, 1829), vol. II, p. 279.

image.title2: Lithograph of Rosslyn Castle by T. Picken after J. D. Harding
image.creator: Harding, James Duffield
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Rosslyn Castle, Midlothian. Rosslyn (or Roslin) Castle is featured in Sir Walter Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) in the ballad of 'Rosabelle' recited by the bard Harold: 'O'er Roslin all that dreary night, | A wondrous blaze was seen to gleam; | 'Twas broader than the watch-fire's light, | And redder than the bright moon-beam' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 25-28). The castle, a ruined 14th-century building located 9 miles south of Edinburgh, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).

image.title2: Lithograph of Rosslyn Chapel by T. Picken after D. Roberts
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Scotland Delineated title-page depicting a group of soldiers talking to a girl outside the entrance to Rosslyn Chapel, Midlothian. Rosslyn (or Roslin) Chapel is featured in Sir Walter Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) in the ballad of 'Rosabelle' recited by the bard Harold: 'Seem'd all on fire that chapel proud, | Where Roslin's chiefs uncoffin'd lie... | Seem'd all on fire within, around, | Deep sacristy and altar's pale; | Shone every pillar foliage-bound, | And glimmer'd all the dead men's mail' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 33-40). The chapel, a 15th-century building located 9 miles south of Edinburgh, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and is thought to have provided the model for the convent of Engaddi in The Talisman (1825). Its architecture inspired the rich moulded ceiling of the library at Scott's home of Abbotsford.

image.title2: Lithograph of the interior of Rosslyn Chapel and the 'Prentice Pillar' by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
image.creator: Leitch, William Leighton
image.description: Depicts some of the elaborate carvings of the interior of Rosslyn Chapel, Midlothian, including the 'Prentice Pillar'. Rosslyn (or Roslin) Chapel is featured in Sir Walter Scott's Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805) in the ballad of 'Rosabelle' recited by the bard Harold: 'Seem'd all on fire that chapel proud, | Where Roslin's chiefs uncoffin'd lie... | Seem'd all on fire within, around, | Deep sacristy and altar's pale; | Shone every pillar foliage-bound, | And glimmer'd all the dead men's mail' (canto VI, stanza XXIII, lines 33-40). The chapel, a 15th-century building located 9 miles south of Edinburgh, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and is thought to have provided the model for the convent of Engaddi in The Talisman (1825). Its architecture inspired the rich moulded ceiling of the library at Scott's home of Abbotsford. According to tradition the 'Prentice Pillar' was carved by an apprentice while the master mason was studying in Rome. Upon his return, the master mason struck the apprentice dead with his mallet in a fit of jealousy.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by an unknown artist, possibly after J. W. Gordon
image.creator: Gordon, John Watson, Sir (b.1788, d.1864)
image.description: Portrait of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-eight, with a book in his left hand. The head and shoulders of Sir Walter Scott in this engraving are very similar to those in the portrait that John Watson Gordon painted for Robert Cadell in 1830. However, in Gordon's portrait, Scott is shown with a walking cane and his dog Bran, whereas here he is portrayed with a book. According to Francis Russell in his Portraits of Sir Walter Scott: A Study of Romantic Portraiture (1987), p. 41, unsigned derivations of Watson Gordon's portrait were issued by J. Lofts, by Harwood, and by L. Tallis.

image.title2: Engraved portrait by W. Holl from a bust of Sir Walter Scott by Sir F. Chantrey
image.creator: Chantrey, Francis Legatt (b.1781, d.1841)
image.description: Engraved portrait depicting a side view of Chantrey's bust of Sir Walter Scott. Scott first sat for the original plaster bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. This engraving is from the marble replica (known as the 'Abbotsford Bust') that Chantrey made for Scott in 1821. It was first published in Knight's Gallery of Portraits, VII (1837). The engraver was probably William Holl the Younger (1807-71) but may have been his father William Holl the Elder (ca. 1771-1838).

image.title1: [Pencil drawing by an unknown artist from a bust of Sir Walter Scott by Sir F. L. Chantrey]
image.creator: Chantrey, Francis Legatt (b.1781, d.1841)
image.description: Pencil drawing of Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey's bust of Sir Walter Scott. Scott first sat for the original plaster bust by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey in spring 1820. This drawing is of the marble replica (known as the 'Abbotsford Bust') that Chantrey made for Scott in 1821. A signature beginning with 'E' is visible to the bottom left of the sketch.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott by J. Heath after J. Saxon
image.creator: Saxon, James
image.description: Three-quarter length portrait of Sir Walter Scott, aged thirty-three, sitting with his dog, Camp. The original portrait by James Saxon was painted in 1805 for Sir Walter Scott's wife Charlotte and subsequently ceded to Scott's London publisher Longmans who wished to have it engraved. It now belongs to the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. The engraving by James Heath was published as the frontispiece to the second impression of Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810).

image.title1: Sir Walter Scott in His Study (Castle Street, Edinburgh)
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott at his desk by R. C. Bell after J. Watson Gordon
image.creator: Gordon, John Watson, Sir (b.1788, d.1864)
image.description: Engraved portrait of Sir Walter Scott seated at his desk at 39 North Castle Street, Edinburgh, with his cat Hinse of Hinsefeldt and dog Maida. The original portrait of Sir Walter Scott by John Watson Gordon is a posthumous likeness dating from the 1840s or 1850s. There are numerous inaccuracies and anachronisms. Scott's Castle Street study was lined with bookshelves and featured a portrait of John Graham of Claverhouse where Gordon has placed his own portrait of Scott's mother. The painting now belongs to the Scottish National Portrait Gallery.

image.title1: View of the Coast of Sleat, Isle of Skye
image.title2: Lithograph of Sleat, Isle of Skye, by T. Picken after H. McCulloch
image.creator: McCulloch, Horatio
image.description: Depicts part of the coastline of Sleat, the southern peninsula of the Isle of Skye. In Canto III of Sir Walter Scott's poem The Lord of the Isles (1815), Ronald, the Lord of the title, and his page Allan accompany Robert the Bruce to Skye. Scott had himself twice visited Skye, in July 1810 and again in the summer and autumn of 1814 when Scott joined a party of Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection around the coast of Scotland. In Waverley, ch. 22, Flora sings a Highland battle-song which calls on the 'proud chiefs of Clan Ranald, Glengarry, and Sleat' to 'combine like three streams from one mountain of snow, | And resistless in union rush down on the foe!' (lines 26-28).

image.title2: Lithograph of the Isle of Staffa by E. Walker after W. A. Nesfield
image.creator: Nesfield, William Andrews
image.description: Depicts the basalt cliffs and caves of the Isle of Staffa, Inner Hebrides. Sir Walter Scott visited the Isle of Staffa in 1810 and declared it 'one of the most extraordinary places I ever beheld' which 'exceeded in my mind every description I had heard of it' (Letter to Joanna Baillie, July 19, 1810). He was particularly struck by Fingal's Cave: 'the appearance of the cavern composed entirely of basaltic pillars as high as the roof of a cathedral and running deep into the rock, eternally swept by a deep and swelling sea, and paved as it were with ruddy marble baffles all description'. He subsequently described Fingal's Cave in The Lord of the Isles (1815), canto IV, stanza X: 'that wondrous dome, | Where, as to shame the temples deck'd | By skill of earthly architect, | Nature herself, it seem'd, would raise | A Minster to her Maker's p raise!' (lines 13-17). The island and its caves are further celebrated in 'Lines Addressed to Ranald Macdonald, Esq. of Staffa' (1814).

image.title2: Lithograph of Stirling Castle by T. Picken after G. F. Robson
image.creator: Robson, George Fennel
image.description: Depicts a regiment of soldiers patrolling the area around Stirling Castle. The concluding scenes of Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810) take place in 'the bulwark of the North, | Grey Stirling, with her towers and town' (canto V, stanza XVIII, lines 34-35). The castle features in a number of Scott's works, most notably Waverley, ch. 38, where the Jacobites guarding Edward Waverley exchange fire with the castle's garrison. The stained glass portraits of Scottish kings in the armoury window at Scott's home of Abbotsford are based on carvings in the presence chamber of Stirling Castle.

image.title2: Lithograph of Tantallon Castle by T. Picken after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts Tantallon Castle, East Lothian, on the Firth of Forth. In Canto Fifth of Marmion (1808), James IV of Scotland sends Lord Marmion and Clara de Clare to Tantallon Castle: 'And, sudden, close before them showed | His towers Tantallon vast; | Broad, massive, high, and stretching far, | And held impregnable in war. | On a projecting rock they rose, | And round three sides the ocean flows' (stanza 23, lines 4-8). Tantallon Castle, built by the Earls of Douglas in the fourteenth century, is also described in Scott's Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).

image.title1: The Hon. Alexander Fraser Tytler, Lord Woodhouselee
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Alexander Fraser Tytler, Lord Woodhouselee, by C. Picart after J. Jackson after H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Engraved half-length portrait of the Scottish historian Alexander Fraser Tytler, Lord Woodhouselee (1747-1813). Sir Walter Scott attended Alexander Fraser Tytler's courses in Universal History at Edinburgh University during the 1789-1790 session. Tytler's empiricism and his insistence on the determining influence of institutions, heredity, and environment had a profound impact on Scott's own vision of history. Scott was also greatly impressed by Tytler's translation of Schiller's Die Ra��uber (The Robbers) (1792) which inspired him to prepare his own translations of German drama and verse. Finally Tytler was sufficiently close a family friend to compose a Latin epitaph for Scott's dog Camp in 1809. The original portrait by Henry Raeburn was painted in 1804.

image.title2: Engraving of Kenilworth Castle by J. Godfrey after H. Warren
image.creator: Warren, Henry
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Kenilworth Castle, Warwickshire. Much of the decisive action of Sir Walter Scott's novel Kenilworth (1821) takes place in the Earl of Leicester's castle of that name. The now ruined castle was established by Geoffrey de Clinton, Chamberlain to Henry I, in about 1122.

image.title2: Lithograph of Edinburgh and Craigmillar Castle by T. Picken after W. Simpson
image.creator: Simpson, William
image.description: Depicts Craigmillar Castle with Edinburgh in the distance. Craigmillar Castle, built in the 15th century by the Preston family, was a favourite residence of Mary Queen of Scots. In ch. 17 of Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820), when Roland Graeme catches a first glimpse of Edinburgh, his companion Adam Woodcock points out Craigmillar Castle 'which I have known a merry place in my time'. The castle is also mentioned in Scott's account of Mary's reign in Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828). It is also described in detail in his Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).

image.title1: Sir Walter Scott, Bart., Born 1771: Died 1832
image.title2: Coloured lithograph of Sir Walter Scott by Riddle and Couchman
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Colour lithograph half-length portrait of Sir Walter Scott. This lithograph produced by the established London firm of Riddle and Couchman appears to be freely based on the 1823 portrait of Scott painted by Sir Henry Raeburn for his own private gallery. Scott, however, appears markedly younger in the lithograph.

image.title1: Prince Charles Edward Taking Leave of his Adherents = Le Prince Charles Edouard prenant cong̩ de ses adh̩rents
image.title2: Engraving by G. Presbury after a painting by F. W. Topham depicting a scene from Scott's novel Redgauntlet
image.creator: Topham, Francis William
image.description: Depicts Charles Edward Stuart ('Bonnie Prince Charlie') taking leave of his followers on the beach of Lochnanach (Redgauntlet, ch. 23). Sir Walter Scott's Redgauntlet (1824) portrays a fictional third Jacobite uprising in 1765. At its conclusion Charles Edward Stuart is permitted to return to France, and his supporters are not pursued. This engraving shows his final farewell to his followers. The figure kneeling before the Prince is the Scottish laird, Redgauntlet, who follows the Prince into exile.

image.title1: The Field of Prestonpan: (Death of Colonel Gardiner)
image.title2: Lithograph of the Battle of Prestonpans by E. Walker after W. Allan
image.creator: Allan, William
image.description: Depicts the death of Colonel Gardiner at the Battle of Prestonpans (Waverley, ch. 18). The Battle of Prestonpans (September 21, 1745) saw Charles Edward Stuart's Jacobite army defeat Sir John Cope's Hanoverian troups. It is depicted in Sir Walter Scott's novel Waverley (1814), where the eponymous hero deserts Colonel Gardiner's Hanoverian dragoons to join the Jacobites. Scott thus describes the fall of Gardiner (a real-life figure): 'Waverley, as he cast his eyes towards this scene of smoke and slaughter, observed Colonel Gardiner, deserted by his own soldiers in spite of all his attempts to rally them, yet spurring his horse through the field to take the command of a small body of infantry... Waverley could perceive that he had already received many wounds, his clothes and saddle being marked with blood. To save this good and brave man, became the instant object of his most anxious exertions. But he could only witness his fall. Ere Edward could make his way among the Highlanders, who, furious and eager for spoil, now thronged upon each other, he saw his former commander brought from his horse by the blow of a scythe, and beheld him receive, while on the ground, more wounds than would have let out twenty lives.' The battle and Gardiner's death are also described in Tales of a Grandfather, Third Series (1829).

image.title1: [Front and back cover illustrations for an edition of The Pirate by Walter Scott]
image.creator: Leighton, John
image.description: Front and back cover of an edition of Sir Walter Scott's The Pirate. Illustrator John Leighton FSA (1822-1912) also used the nom-de-plume 'Luke Limner'. The figures portrayed in alcoves on the front cover are probably Captain Cleveland, the pirate of the title, and his lover Minna Troil. The engraver is John Leighton's brother Henry. The scene on the back cover illustrates the parting interview of Cleveland and Minna, with Minna's sister Brenda in the background and John Bunce, Cleveland's lieutenant looking on (ch. 40). It was engraved by (W.T.?) Green, probably after Robert Scott Lauder.

image.title2: Lithograph of Loch Katrine by T. Picken after H. McCulloch
image.creator: McCulloch, Horatio
image.description: View of Loch Katrine, Stirling, with Ellen's Isle visible in the middle distance, and Ben Venue in the background. Loch Katrine provides the setting for Sir Walter Scott's The Lady of the Lake (1810). Following the success of the poem, the Loch and the surrounding Trossachs region became major tourist attractions.

image.title2: Lithograph of Edinburgh from Craigleith Quarry by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
image.creator: Leitch, William Leighton
image.description: Depicts Craigleith Quarry with a view of Edinburgh city in the background. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). Craigleith Quarry provided much of the fine sandstone used in building Edinburgh's New Town in the 18th and 19th centuries. It was first worked to provide stone for Edinburgh Castle in the 17th century.

image.title2: Lithograph of Edinburgh from Calton Hill by T. Picken after D. Roberts
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts a view of Edinburgh city centre from Calton Hill as it was in the 1840s. In the middle ground may be seen the recently completed Scott Monument. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). In Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826), Sir Walter Scott describes the view from Calton Hill 'where every passenger, however much accustomed to the wonderful scene, is inclined to pause, and, with eyes unsatisfied with seeing, to gaze on the mingled and almost tumultuous scene which lies before and beneath him'.

image.title1: View of Edinburgh: From the Castle
image.title2: Lithograph of Edinburgh from the Castle by T. Picken after D. Roberts
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Presents a view of Edinburgh city centre from the Castle ramparts. To the left may be seen the recently completed Scott Monument. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). Edinburgh Castle is the city's most prominent landmark. It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).

image.title1: High Street: From Head of West Bow, Lawnmarket
image.title2: Lithograph of High Street, Edinburgh by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
image.creator: Leitch, William Leighton
image.description: Depicts the junction of West Bow and High Street, Edinburgh. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). Scott gives a description and historical account of the High Street in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826), noting, not uncritically, the many innovations made during his own lifetime. The view of the High Street presented in this engraving was only made possible by the demolition of the Old Tolbooth and Luckenbooths in 1817. These buildings had previously stood between the Lawnmarket and the High Street proper. Scott still maintained that 'under all its mutilations, the High Street of Edinburgh is the most magnificent in Great Britain, excepting perhaps the High Street of Oxford'.

image.title2: Lithograph of Edinburgh Castle from the Grassmarket by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
image.creator: Leitch, William Leighton
image.description: Depicts the Grassmarket with Edinburgh Castle dominating the skyline. Edinburgh Castle is the most prominent landmark of Scott's hometown. It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826).

image.title2: Lithograph of the Assembly Hall, Edinburgh by T. Picken after W. L. Leitch
image.creator: Leitch, William Leighton
image.description: Depicts the Assembly Hall of the Church of Scotland, Edinburgh (now The Hub) and a crowded Castle Hill. Sir Walter Scott was born and raised in Edinburgh and worked there, first as an Advocate from 1792 to 1806, then as Clerk of the Court of Session until his retirement in 1830. The city features in many of his works, most notably The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). The building portrayed here, Assembly Hall on Castle Hill, was built in 1842-44, a decade after Scott's death. Scott did, however, give a description and historical account of the High Street in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826), noting, not uncritically, the many innovations made during his own lifetime. These had effectively extended the street to Castle Hill.

image.title2: Lithograph of Fleshmarket Close, Edinburgh by T. Picken after G. Cattermole
image.creator: Cattermole, George
image.description: Depicts Fleshmarket Close, Edinburgh. In the Magnum Opus edition of The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1830), Scott inserts a note containing a contemporary account of the inquiries made by Crown Counsel into the lynching of Captain Porteous in Edinburgh in 1737. This describes the unsuccessful attempt to arrest a suspect, Thomas Burns, a butcher, in an alehouse in Fleshmarket Close. Fleshmarket Close was intersected by Cockburn Street in 1859. Only the lower part of the historical Close now retains that name.

image.title2: Lithograph of the Palace of Holyroodhouse by T. Picken after J. D. Harding
image.creator: Harding, James Duffield
image.description: Depicts the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh, with Holyrood Park and Arthur's Seat in the background. The Royal Palace of Holyroodhouse appears in a number of Scott's works, most notably in Waverley (1814) where it is occupied by Prince Charles Edward Stuart and is the scene of a ball (chapter 43). The Palace is also described in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826) and is repeatedly mentioned in Tales of a Grandfather, First to Third Series (1828-30).

image.title1: View From the Summit of Goatfell, Island of Arran
image.title2: Lithograph of Goatfell on the Isle of Arran by T. Picken after J. D. Harding
image.creator: Harding, James Duffield
image.description: Presents a view from Goatfell across the Isle of Arran. In Canto IV of Sir Walter Scott's The Lord of the Isles (1815) Robert the Bruce sets sail for Arran where his forces are to assemble: 'Now launched once more, the inland sea | They furrow with fair augury, | And steer for Arran's isle; | The sun, ere yet he sunk behind | Ben-Ghoil, "the Mountain of the Wind," | Gave his grim peaks a greeting kind, | And bade Loch Ranza smile.' (stanza 12, lines 1-7). Ben Ghoil is the Gaelic name for Goatfell. Scott had himself visited Arran in September 1814 when he joined a party of Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection around the coast of Scotland. Arran is also described in chapter 41 of The Heart of Midlothian (1818) as abounding 'with the grandest and most romantic scenery'.

image.title2: Lithograph of Glasgow Cathedral by T. Picken after D. Roberts
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts crowds attempting to strip Glasgow Cathedral of Catholic symbols during the Reformation. Glasgow Cathedral is the scene of an important meeting between Frank Osbaldistone and Rob Roy in ch. 19 of Sir Walter Scott's novel Rob Roy (1817). Osbaldistone, the narrator, describes his first impression of the building in chapter 18: 'The pile is of a gloomy and massive, rather than of an elegant, style of Gothic architecture; but its peculiar character is so strongly preserved, and so well suited with the accompaniments that surround it, that the impression of the first view was awful and solemn in the extreme.' This engraving possibly depicts the (successful) efforts of the tradesmen of Glasgow to prevent the Cathedral from being demolished at the Reformation. This episode is recalled in Scott's novel by Osbaldistone's man-servant Andrew Fairservice.

image.title2: Lithograph of a scene inside Glasgow Cathedral by T. Picken after J. Nash
image.creator: Nash, Joseph
image.description: Depicts a confrontation inside Glasgow Cathedral at the time of the Reformation. Glasgow Cathedral is the scene of an important meeting between Frank Osbaldistone and Rob Roy in ch. 19 of Sir Walter Scott's novel Rob Roy (1817). Osbaldistone, the narrator, describes his first impression of the building in ch. 18: 'The pile is of a gloomy and massive, rather than of an elegant, style of Gothic architecture; but its peculiar character is so strongly preserved, and so well suited with the accompaniments that surround it, that the impression of the first view was awful and solemn in the extreme.' This engraving possibly depicts the (successful) efforts of the tradesmen of Glasgow to prevent the Cathedral from being demolished at the Reformation. This episode is recalled in Scott's novel by Osbaldistone's man-servant Andrew Fairservice.

image.title2: Coloured engraving of Peel Castle by W. Daniell
image.creator: Daniell, William
image.description: Depicts boats on the Irish Sea with Peel Castle (Isle of Man) and St. Patrick's Isle in the middle distance. Peel Castle, or Holm-Peel, Isle of Man, figures prominently in Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823) as the residence of the Countess of Derby. It is described in chapter 15 of the novel as 'one of those extraordinary monuments of antiquity with which this singular and interesting island abounds'. Scott did not personally visit the Isle of Man, but received information from his younger brother Thomas who served as an officer in the Manx Fencibles from 1808 to 1810. The image is both drawn and engraved by William Daniell.

image.title1: MacDonald of Glengarry: (The Fergus MacIvor of the Tale)
image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Waverley
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of Waverley, volume I in a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, featuring Colonel MacDonell in full Highland dress. Scott is thought to have based many of the traits of the Highland chieftain Fergus MacIvor in Waverley (1814) on his friend Alasdair (or Alexander) Ranaldson MacDonell, 15th Chief of Glengarry. Scott described him thus in his Journal (14 February 1826): 'This gentleman is a kind of Quixote in our age, having retained, in their full extent, the whole feelings of clanship and chieftainship, elsewhere so long abandoned. He seems to have lived a century too late, and to exist, in a state of complete law and order, like a Glengarry of old, whose will was law to his sept. Warmhearted, generous, friendly, he is beloved by those who know him, and his efforts are unceasing to show kindness to those of his clan who are disposed fully to admit his pretensions. To dispute them is to incur his resentment, which has sometimes broken out in acts of violence which have brought him into collision with the law. To me he is a treasure, as being full of information as to the history of his own clan, and the manners and customs of the Highlanders in general.' Glengarry gifted Scott the deerhounds Maida (1816) and Nimrod (1824). The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Waverley
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of Waverley, volume II in a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Edinburgh Castle. Approaching Edinburgh in Waverley (1814), ch. 39, Edward Waverly sees Edinburgh Castle besieged by a Jacobite army and is struck by the appearance of 'grandeur and gloom' that results from its partial concealment by gunsmoke. The Castle is also mentioned in other novels by Scott, notably The Heart of Midlothian (1818), and is described in his Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). It was also at Edinburgh Castle that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The original wood engraving, probably by John Greenaway, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Guy Mannering
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Title page of Guy Mannering, volume III of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, featuring Caerlaverock Castle, Dumfries and Galloway. Ellangowan Castle, seat of the Bertrams in Sir Walter Scott's Guy Mannering (1815), is often thought to be based on Caerlaverock Castle in Dumfriesshire. Scott visited Caerlaverock Castle (built by the Maxwells in the 13th century) with Guthrie Wright in 1806. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-47).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Guy Mannering
image.creator: Paton, Noel
image.description: Title page of Guy Mannering, volume IV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Writer's Court, Edinburgh. In chapter 7 of Guy Mannering (1815), Mannering and Dandie Dinmont seek the lawyer Counsellor Pleydell in Clerihugh's Tavern, Edinburgh, and find him engaged in a game of 'High Jinks'. Clerihugh's Tavern was a real-life locale where the lawyers and magistrates of Edinburgh transacted much of their business in the 18th century. The original wood engraving, probably based on the work of Joseph Noel Paton, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-47).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Antiquary
image.creator: Allan-Fraser, Patrick
image.description: Title page of The Antiquary, volume V of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, featuring Arbroath Abbey, Angus. St Ruth's Priory, scene of a number of important episodes in Sir Walter Scott's The Antiquary (1816), is often thought to be based on the 12th-century Arbroath Abbey. Scott visited Arbroath in September 1796. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). The artist is Patrick Allan-Fraser who assumed his wife's surname of Fraser on his marriage in 1843.

image.title1: Cabinet of Mr. Constable, (The Antiquary of the Tale)
image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Antiquary
image.creator: Allan-Fraser, Patrick
image.description: Title page of The Antiquary, volume VI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Mr Constable's cabinet. Sir Walter Scott himself acknowledged that Jonathan Oldbuck, the titular character of The Antiquary (1816), was based partly on a family friend George Constable who first introduced Scott to Shakespeare. In his unfinished Autobiography (1808), Scott wrote: 'He used always to dine at my father's house of a Sunday, and was authorized to turn the conversation out of the austere and Calvinistic tone, which it usually maintained on that day, upon subjects of history or auldlangsyne. He rememberd the forty-five, and told many excellent stories, all with a strong dash of a peculiar caustic humour.' The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-47). The artist is Patrick Allan-Fraser who assumed his wife's surname of Fraser on his marriage in 1843.

image.title1: David Ritchie: (The Original of the Black Dwarf)
image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Black Dwarf
image.creator: Gilbert, John
image.description: Title page of The Black Dwarf, volume IX of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting David Ritchie, real-life model for the dwarf of the title. As Sir Walter Scott himself acknowledged in his introduction to the 'Magnum Opus' edition of The Black Dwarf (1830), the character of Elshender the Recluse was based on a real-life hermit David Ritchie. Scott had visited Ritchie's cottage while staying with his friend Captain Adam Ferguson in Peeblesshire in 1797. The Gilbert portrait of David Ritchie was originally published in the Scot's Magazine 1817. The original wood engraving, probably by Thomas Gilks after John Gilbert, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Old Mortality
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of Old Mortality, volume X of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting James Sharp, Archbishop of St Andrews (1613-1679). In ch. 5-6 of Sir Walter Scott's Old Mortality (1816), the hero Henry Morton shelters John Burley of Balfour who is wanted for his part in the assassination of James Sharp, Archbishop of St Andrews (3 May 1679).
