Sharp was detested by the Covenanters for betraying the Presbyterian cause and playing a major role in the reintroduction of Episcopacy and oppression of the Covenanting party. In Tales of a Grandfather, Second Series (1829), Scott wrote of Sharp: 'He had some virtues, being learned, temperate, and living a life becoming his station; but his illiberal and intolerant principles, and the violences which he committed to enforce them, were the cause of great distress to Scotland, and of his own premature and bloody end.' The Dickes portrait of Archbishop Sharp is based on a 17th-century portrait by Sir Peter Lely. The wood engraving was originally made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Old Mortality
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of Old Mortality, volume XI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, featuring General Thomas Dalyell (1615-1685). Commander-in-Chief of the army in Scotland from 1661 to 1685, General Thomas Dalyell earned the epithet 'Bluidy Tam' after his suppression of the Covenanters at Rullion Green in 1666. In Old Mortality (1816) Scott describes him as 'as much feared for his cruelty and indifference to human life and human sufferings, as respected for his steady loyalty and undaunted valour'. The General also appears as a demonic ghost in 'Wandering Willie's Tale' in Redgauntlet (1824). The Dickes portrait appears to be based on an original portrait by David Paton (fl. 1660-1698). The wood engraving was originally made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: John Duke of Argyle and Greenwich
image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Heart of Midlothian
image.creator: Lodge, William
image.description: Title page of The Heart of Midlothian, vol. XIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, featuring John Campbell, 2nd Duke of Argyll (1678-1743). In Sir Walter Scott's The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818), the Duke of Argyll assists Jeanie Deans in seeking the aid of Queen Caroline and ultimately provides a home on his estates for the heroine and her husband Reuben Butler. Scott wrote that 'few names deserve more honourable mention in the history of Scotland' than the Duke; he 'was alike free from the ordinary vices of statesmen, falsehood, namely, and dissimulation; and from those of warriors, inordinate and violent thirst after self-aggrandisement' (The Heart of Mid-Lothian, ch. 34). The original wood engraving, probably after William Lodge, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of The Bride of Lammermoor, volume XIV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Queen Anne (1665-1714). Sir Walter Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor (1819) is set during the reign of Queen Anne in the years immediately preceding the Act of Union between England and Scotland (1707). The novel takes place at a time when the Jacobite party appears to be in the ascendant on both sides of the Border in the expectation that the Queen would be succeeded by her brother James (later known as the 'Old Pretender'). The Dickes portrait derives from a portrait by Sir Godfrey Kneller (ca. 1690) probably via the intermediary of earlier engravings. The wood engraving was originally made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's A Legend of Montrose
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of A Legend of Montrose, volume XV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Archibald Campbell, 1st Marquis of Argyll (1607-1661). Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819) is set during the campaign of James Graham, Earl of Montrose, against the Covenanters in the Highlands in 1644-1645. The Marquis of Argyll met Montrose in a series of battles, finally defeating him at Philiphaugh in 1645. Scott describes Argyll as 'a man rather of political enterprise than personal courage, and better calculated to manage an intrigue of state, than to control the tribes of hostile mountaineers' (A Legend of Montrose, ch. 1). The Dickes portrait of the Marquis of Argyll is drawn from an 'old print', possibly a 1713 engraving by Michael Vandergucht after an unknown artist. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Ivanhoe
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of Ivanhoe, volume XVI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, featuring Micklegate Bar, York. Sir Walter Scott's Ivanhoe (1819) is set in Yorkshire. The Jewish financier Isaac and his daughter Rebecca are both natives of the county-town York. Micklegate (or 'great street') was the principal thoroughfare of medieval York. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Crown of Thomas a Becket at Canterbury
image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Ivanhoe
image.creator: Jewitt, Thomas Orlando Sheldon
image.description: Title page of Ivanhoe, volume XVII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting the Corona of Canterbury Cathedral, Kent. This image depicts the 'Corona' or the east end of Canterbury Cathedral, named after the severed crown of St Thomas Becket (St. Thomas the Martyr), who was assassinated in the cathedral in 1170. The Corona was built to contain a shrine to St Thomas, which was subsequently destroyed on the orders of Henry VIII in 1540. St Thomas' name is used in many oaths in Walter Scott's Ivanhoe (1819). Prince John also despairs about the loyalty of his men: "An unhappy prince am I. My father, King Henry, had faithful servants---He had but to say that he was plagued with a factious priest, and the blood of Thomas-a-Becket, saint though he was, stained the steps of his own altar" (ch. 11). The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). The engraving by Jewitt is presumably after his own design.

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Monastery
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of The Monastery, volume XVIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting King James V of Scotland (1512-1542). Sir Walter Scott's The Monastery (1820) in the years following the death of James V, when Lowland Scotland was devastated by Henry VIII of England's 'Rough Wooing'. That is the term that Scott coined to describe Henry's military campaign (1544-1551) to bring about the marriage of the infant Mary Queen of Scots and his own son Edward Prince of Wales. This portrait is taken from a 16th-century carving made for the King's Presence Chamber in Stirling Castle (one of the 'Stirling Heads'). The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Monastery
image.creator: Holbein, Hans the younger
image.description: Title page of The Monastery, volume XIX of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Edward Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset (ca. 1500-1552). Somerset was Lord Protector of England from 1547 to 1549, ruling the country in the name of the boy king Edward VI. As Warden of the Scottish Marshes, he continued to prosecute the war of 'Rough Wooing', which was designed to bring about the marriage of Edward and the infant Mary Queen of Scots. The Scots suffered a particularly devastating defeat at his hands at the Battle of Pinkie Cleugh (1547). In Sir Walter Scott's The Monastery (1820), the father of Halbert and Edward Glendinning has been killed at the battle, and Somerset is depicted encamped at Roxburgh Castle demanding tribute from the Scots (ch. 2). The original wood engraving, probably by Charles Green, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Abbot
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of The Abbot, volume XX of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting John Knox (ca. 1514-1572). Scott never portrayed John Knox directly in his fiction, but his 1820 novels The Monastery and The Abbot portray the triumph of the Knox-inspired Reformation in Scotland. Scott's preacher Henry Warden is presented as second only in power and eloquence to Knox. In The Abbot even the Catholic Mary Queen of Scots salutes Knox's power, describing him as 'the ablest and most powerful of heresiarchs' (ch. 25). Scott also described Knox's role in the Reformation in the historical Tales of a Grandfather, First Series (1828), where Knox is introduced as 'a man of great courage, zeal, and talents' and as the 'bold and inflexible father of the Scottish Reformation'. For each of these works, Knox's own Historie of the Reformation of the Church of Scotland was an important source. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847), where it was used to illustrate The Monastery. It was engraved by John Orrin Smith and William James Linton after a drawing by William Dickes. Dickes's drawing was based on one of several earlier prints all ultimately deriving from a portrait by Adrian Van Son (ca. 1580).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Abbot
image.creator: Elstrack, Renold
image.description: Title page of The Abbot, volume XXI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley (1545-1567) as a child. Following the murder of Lord Darnley, second husband of Mary Queen of Scots (1567), and Mary's subsequent remarriage to the Earl of Bothwell, the Scottish Lords confronted the Queen and imprisoned her in Loch Leven Castle. Her escape from captivity is the subject of Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820). In ch. 22 of the novel she proclaims herself innocent of involvement in the murder of Darnley, but acknowledge that by marrying the chief suspect she has laid herself open to suspicion. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847) by a member of the Dalziel family of engravers, possibly George (1815-1902). It derives ultimately from a late 16th- or early 17th-century engraving by Renold Elstrack.

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Kenilworth
image.creator: Harvey, William
image.description: Title page of Kenilworth, volume XXIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Thomas Radcliffe, 3rd Earl of Sussex (ca. 1525-1583). Thomas Radcliffe was Earl of Sussex, not Essex as indicated here. Under Queen Elizabeth, he served as Lord Lieutenant of Ireland (1559-1564) and Lord Chamberlain (1572-1583). His court rivalry with Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester, forms the backdrop to Sir Walter Scott's Kenilworth (1821). Radcliffe wished Elizabeth to marry a non-English bridegroom and was thus hostile to Dudley's own ambitions to marry the Queen. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). It derives from a 16th-century painting by an unknown artist.

image.title1: Aisle of St. Magnus' Cathedral, Kirkwall
image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Pirate
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of The Pirate, volume XXIV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting St. Magnus Cathedral, Kirkwall, Orkney. In Sir Walter Scott's The Pirate (1821), St. Magnus Cathedral in Kirkwall, Orkney, is the scene of decisive encounters between Captain Cleveland and Minna Troil (ch. 37) and between Mordaunt Mertoun and Ulla Troil (ch. 41). Scott, who had visited Orkney in 1814, described the Cathedral as 'of the heaviest order of Gothic architecture, but grand, solemn, and stately, the work of a distant age, and of a powerful hand' (The Pirate, ch. 31). The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). There the engraving itself gives the artist's name as Dickes and the engraver as Mary A. Williams, but the list of illustrations gives the artist's name as Elizabeth Leveson-Gower, Duchess-Countess of Sutherland.

image.title1: Headland of Culswick, Pictish Fort: Norna's Dwelling
image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Pirate
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of The Pirate, volume XXV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Fitful Head, Shetland. In Sir Walter Scott's The Pirate (1821), the self-style prophetess Ulla Troil inhabits a pictish fort or broch on Fitful Head, Shetland. No such structure exists on Fitful Head, and Scott is generally thought to have modelled her imaginary dwelling on the nearby brochs of Mousa and Culswick (the latter portrayed here). Scott visited Shetland in 1814 when he joined a party of Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection around the coast of Scotland. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Statue of George Heriot: (In the Hospital at Edinburgh)
image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel
image.creator: Mylne, Robert I
image.description: Title page of The Fortunes of Nigel, volume XXVI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting a statue of George Heriot (1563-1624). George Heriot, Goldsmith and Jeweller to James VI, is portrayed as 'Jingling Geordie' in Sir Walter Scott's 1822 novel The Fortunes of Nigel. George Heriot's School, Edinburgh, formerly George Heriot's Hospital, was founded in 1628 as a result of a bequest from Heriot. The statue of Heriot in the school's Quadrangle was carved in 1693 by Robert Mylne (1633-1710) who based the likeness on a painting by Paul Van Somer. This engraving, obtained glyphographically be Edward Palmer, was originally made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel
image.creator: Miereveld, Michiel Jansz van (b.1567, d.1641)
image.description: Title page of The Fortunes of Nigel, volume XXVII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting the George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham (1592-1628). Buckingham appears as the omnipotent favourite of both King James VI and I and the Prince of Wales in Sir Walter Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel (1822). Scott describes him as 'more feared than beloved, and, if not absolutely of a tyrannical disposition [...] accounted haughty, violent, and vindictive' (ch. 6). The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). It derives, via earlier engravings, from a portrait by Michiel Jansz van Miereveld (1567-1641).

image.title1: Newgate: As Built by Sir Richard Whittington
image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Whymper, Ebenezzar
image.description: Title page of Peveril of the Peak, volume XXVIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Newgate Prison, London. In Sir Walter Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak (1823), the hero Julian Peveril is imprisoned in Newgate following an affray with the Duke of Buckingham's men. His father Sir Geoffrey Peveril had earlier been imprisoned in the same gaol on suspicion of involvement in the Popish Plot (1678). The original wood engraving, probably by Ebenezzar Whymper, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Diepenbeeck, Abraham Jansz. van
image.description: Title page of Peveril of the Peak, volume XXIX of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Margaret Cavendish, Duchess of Newcastle (1661-1717). In Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823), the Duchess of Newcastle is mentioned on several occasions as a friend of the Countess of Derby. She attracts the ridicule of the Earl of Derby and of King Charles II who describes her as 'an entire raree-show in her own person--a universal masquerade--indeed a sort of private Bedlam-hospital' (ch. 45). To this day, the Duchess divides opinion, some hailing her as a pioneering woman writer, others concurring with Pepys that she was 'mad, conceited and ridiculous'. Scott clearly inclined to the latter view. The original wood engraving, probably by John Thompson, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-47). It derives, probably via earlier engravings, from an original painting by Abraham Diepenbeeck.

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Dodgson, George Haydock
image.description: Title page of Peveril of the Peak, volume XXX of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Haddon Hall with lit beacon. Martindale Castle, ancient seat of the Peverils in Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823), is generally thought to be modelled on Haddon Hall, Derbyshire, a fortified medieval manor house belonging to the Manners family. The original wood engraving, probably by Charles Green, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Quentin Durward
image.creator: Mason, Walter George
image.description: Title page of Quentin Durward, volume XXXI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting P̩ronne, Somme, France. In Sir Walter Scott's Quentin Durward (1823), Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy makes his camp at P̩ronne. He is unexpectedly visited there by his enemy Louis XI who, by feigning friendliness, hopes to allay suspicions that he has backed a revolt against Charles's brother-in-law, the Bishop of Li̬ge. Charles sees through Louis's ploy and imprisons him. The King is finally, however, able to persuade Charles of his innocence and regain liberty. Scott himself passed through P̩ronne when travelling from Belgium to France in 1815. The original wood engraving, probably by Walter George Mason, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Quentin Durward
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of Quentin Durward, volume XXXII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting St Joan of Valois (1464-1505). Joan (or Jeanne), Duchess of Berry was the second daughter of Louis XI by his second wife Charlotte of Savoy. For dynastic purposes, Louis compelled her to marry his second cousin Louis duc d'Orl̩ans, later Louis XII. Divorced by Louis XII on his ascent to the throne, she went on to found the religious order of the Annonciades and was canonized by Pius XII. In Sir Walter Scott's Quentin Durward (1823), the duc d'Orl̩ans's passion for Isabelle de Croye threatens to thwart Louis IX's plans to marry him to her daughter. Scott describes Joan as 'pale, thin, and sickly in her complexion; her shape visibly bent to one side, and her gait [...] so unequal that she might be called lame'. In terms of appearance, eyes 'expressive of melancholy, softness, and resignation' were her only 'redeeming points'. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Saint Ronan's Well
image.creator: Paton, Noel
image.description: Title page of St. Ronan's Well, volume XXXIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting the inn at Howgate, near Penicuik, Midlothian. The inn at Howgate has sometime been proposed as a model for the Auld Town Inn kept by Meg Dods in Sir Walter Scott's Saint Ronan's Well (1823). The original wood engraving, probably after Noel Paton, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's St Ronan's Well
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of Saint Ronan's Well, volume XXXIV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, featuring Niel Gow (1727-1807). Niel (or Neil) Gow was the most celebrated Scottish fiddler of the 18th century. His son Nathaniel (1766-1831), a first-rate musician and composer in his own right, plays during the theatricals at Shaws-Castle in Sir Walter Scott's St Ronan's Well (1823). Touchwood comments: 'He is his father's own son [...]. It is many a long year since I listened to old Neil at Inver, and, to say truth, spent a night with him over pancakes and Athole brose; and I never expected to hear his match again in my lifetime' (ch. 20). The original wood engraving, probably by John Andrew, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Betrothed
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of The Betrothed, volume XXXVII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting the Bishop's Palace, Gloucester. In ch. 18 of Sir Walter Scott's The Betrothed (1825), Hugo de Lacy meets Baldwin, Archbishop of Canterbury, in the Bishop's Palace at Gloucester. Scott is guilty here of an anachronism. There was no Diocese of Gloucester in the twelfth century, the period in which the novel is set. The fourteenth-century building portrayed here only became the Bishop's Palace in 1542 when Henry VIII created the Diocese. Previously it had been the residence of the Abbot of the Benedictine Abbey of St. Peter. The original wood engraving, probably by J. J. Field, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Interior of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, Jerusalem
image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Talisman
image.creator: Barry, Charles the elder
image.description: Title page of The Talisman, volume XXXVIII of a set the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, Jerusalem. Sir Walter Scott's The Talisman (1825) is set during the Third Crusade (1189-1192), when a combined European force attempted to reconquer the Holy Land from Saladin and to restore access to the most important Christian shrine, the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem. The original wood engraving, probably by Thomas Armstrong, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Woodstock
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of Woodstock, volume XXXIX of a set the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting General George Monck (1608-1670). In ch. 38 of Sir Walter Scott's Woodstock (1826) news reaches the exiled Royal Court at Brussels that General Monck (or Monk) is marching South from Scotland, a move that would bring about the restoration of the Stewart dynasty. Having initially fought on the Royal side, Monck had become one of Cromwell's most trusted generals and his deputy in Scotland. On Cromwell's death, he pledged to support Cromwell's son and successor Richard. As the country descended into chaos, however, he acted to restore the monarchy. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-47). According to the contents page of the Abbotsford Edition, the illustration was engraved by 'Nugent' after 'Chapman'. However, the image is clearly signed 'W. Dickes' and was probably derived from one or more pre-existing engraved portraits.

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Woodstock
image.creator: Evans, Edmund
image.description: Title page of Woodstock, volume XL of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, featuring Windsor Castle, Berkshire. In Sir Walter Scott's Woodstock (1826), Cromwell is stationed at Windsor while awaiting the capture of the fugitive King Charles. In chapter 8 of the novel Roger Wildrake is granted an audience at Windsor with Cromwell, during which he delivers a letter from Colonel Markham Everard. The original wood engraving, possibly after Edmund Evans, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Highland Widow, etc.
image.creator: Douglas, William
image.description: Title page of The Highland Widow, etc, volume XLI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting the Canongate Cross, Edinburgh. Sir Walter Scott's Chronicles of the Canongate were published in two Series (1827 and 1828) and purport to be narrated by Chrystal Croftangry, a resident in the Canongate, Edinburgh, who writes up the tales from the recollections of his friends and neighbours, Mrs Bethune Baliol and Miss Kate Fairscribe. The original wood engraving, probably by Owen Jones after William Douglas, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Gowrie Tower, the Tay, and Bridge, Perth
image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Fair Maid of Perth
image.creator: Clerk, John II
image.description: Title page of The Fair Maid of Perth, volume XLII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting the Perth Bridge. Describing Perth in ch. I of The Fair Maid of Perth (1828), Sir Walter Scott regrets the demolition in 1809 of Gowrie House or Tower, the scene of the alleged 'Gowrie Conspiracy' against James VI in 1600. The bridge portrayed here was built in 1771 and is therefore not the one featured in the novel which was destroyed by a flood in 1621. The original wood engraving, possibly by Edward Evans, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's The Fair Maid of Perth
image.creator: Paton, Noel
image.description: Title page of The Fair Maid of Perth, volume XLIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Abernethy Round Tower, Perthshire. The Round Tower of Abernethy (near Perth) was built in the ninth century and is one of only two such towers in Scotland. Over 70 feet tall, it was built by monks from the nearby monastery and has served as a place of refuge, a belfry, and a burial chamber. Scott described the Tower in a letter to his son Walter on 14 November 1820 and in a review of Joseph Ritson's Annals of the Caledonians, Picts, and Scots for the Quarterly Review in July 1829. The original wood engraving, by William Dickes after Noel Paton, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Anne of Geierstein
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of Anne of Geierstein, volume XLV of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting a monument to William Tell. The legend of William Tell is constantly invoked throughout Sir Walter Scott's Anne of Geierstein (1829). The caption to this engraving is a little misleading. The monument to Tell is not the tower but the statue overlooking the fountain. It was created in 1786 by Benedikt Curiger and removed in 1859 to make way for a new monument. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Count Robert of Paris
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of Count Robert of Paris, volume XLVI of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C Black, depicting the Column of Theodosius, Istanbul. Sir Walter Scott's Count Robert of Paris (1831) is set in Constantinople during the reign of the Byzantine Emperor Alexius Comnenus (1081-1118). It begins with a brief history of the city which mentions the additions and improvements made by the Emperor Theodosius I (378-395). It was Theodosius who brought to Constantinople the Egyptian obelisk of Pharaoh Thutmosi III now known as the Column of Theodosius. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Castle Dangerous
image.creator: Paton, Noel
image.description: Title page of Castle Dangerous, volume XLVII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting St Bride's Church, Douglas, South Lanarkshire. In Sir Walter Scott's Castle Dangerous (1831), the disguised heroine, Lady Augusta de Berkely, takes up residence in the Abbey of St. Bride in the village of Douglas. Originally the parish church, the thirteenth-century Kirk of St Bride's became a mausoleum for the 'Black' Douglas family. The original wood engraving, possibly by Owen Jones after Noel Paton, was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved title page and frontispiece of Scott's Surgeon's Daughter
image.creator: Dickes, William
image.description: Title page of The Surgeon's Daughter, volume XLVIII of a set of the Waverley Novels published by A. and C. Black, depicting Hyder Ali (ca. 1720-1782). In Sir Walter Scott's The Surgeon's Daughter (1827), Haidar (or Hyder Ali), Nawab of Mysore, assures the safety of the heroine, Menie Gray, and punishes her duplicitous fiance Richard Middlemass. The original wood engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of the Vale of Gala Water by W. Forrest after C. Stanfield]
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts the Vale of Gala Water from the woods of Abbotsford, Scottish Borders. The Gala Water, a tributary of the River Tweed, runs through the heart of the 'Scott Country'. In his Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. (1837-1838), Scott's son-in-law J. G. Lockhart describes the return of the dying Scott to Abbotsford on 11 July 1832 after a lengthy stay on the Continent. Scott begins to revive from a state of torpor as his carriage descends the Vale of Gala, and he murmurs, 'Gala Water, surely -- Buckholm --Torwoodlee'. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847), where it appeared as an illustration to The Monastery.

image.title2: Engraving of Berwick-upon-Tweed by W. Miller after J.M.W. Turner
image.creator: Turner, Joseph Mallord William (b.1775, d.1851)
image.description: Depicts Berwick-upon-Tweed, Northumberland, with the ruins of Berwick Castle in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott's drama Halidon Hill (1822) describes an event which took place during the Battle of Halidon Hill (1333), when a Scottish army under Sir Archibald Douglas sought to lift the siege of Berwick-upon-Tweed but were heavily defeated by English forces. This engraving was first published in vol. XII of the The Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. (Edinburgh: Cadell, 1834).

image.title1: The Vale of Manor Water, Peebles-Shire
image.title2: Engraving of Manor Valley by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts Manor Valley, Scottish Borders, with bridge and ruined tower. In the Introduction to Magnum Opus edition of The Black Dwarf (1830), Walter Scott recounts the tale of David Ritchie, the inspiration for the eponymous character: 'Tired at length of being the object of shouts, laughter, and derision, David Ritchie resolved, like a deer hunted from the herd, to retreat to some wilderness... He settled himself, with this view, upon a patch of wild moorland at the bottom of a bank on the farm of Woodhouse, in the sequestered vale of the small river Manor, in Peeblesshire.' Scott himself visited Ritchie's cottage while staying with his friend Captain Adam Ferguson in Peeblesshire in 1797. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Craignethan Castle by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts Craignethan Castle, Lanarkshire. Craignethan Castle is generally held to be the inspiration for Tillietudlem Castle, seat of the Bellenden family in Walter Scott's Old Mortality (1816). Scott had visited the ruins of the 16th-century castle in 1799 in the company of Lord and Lady Douglas. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of a Highland Pass, near Gairloch, by W. Richardson after C. Stanfield]
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts a deep canyon and two Highlanders by a fallen tree. In ch. 49 of Sir Walter Scott's The Heart of Midlothian (1818), Lady Staunton (the former Effie Deans) becomes trapped while visiting a waterfall in the vicinity of Gairloch (Ross and Cromarty). The artist has chosen a spot matching the description: 'A single shoot carried a considerable stream over the face of a black rock, which contrasted strongly in colour with the white foam of the cascade, and, at the depth of about twenty feet, another rock intercepted the view of the bottom of the fall. The water, wheeling out far beneath, swept round the crag, which thus bounded their view, and tumbled down the rocky glen in a torrent of foam.' The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of the Trossachs by W. Richardson after A. Nasmyth]
image.creator: Nasmyth, Alexander (b.1758, d.1840)
image.description: Depicts a view of the Trossachs, Stirling. The Trossachs region of Scotland, now a National Park, was home to Rob Roy Macgregor and his clan. Sir Walter Scott celebrated its scenery in the novel Rob Roy (1817) and poem The Lady of the Lake (1810), spawning an enduring tourist industry. Scott visited the region with his wife in the summers of 1809, 1816, and 1817. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of Eyemouth and the coast of Berwickshire by W. Richardson after C. Stanfield]
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts boats in the harbour at Eyemouth, Berwickshire. In Sir Walter Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor (1819), Wolf's Crag tower is 'situated on the bleak shores between Saint Abb's Head and the village of Eyemouth' (ch. 2). In ch. 35 of the novel Ravenswood perishes in quicksand on the Links of Wolf's Hope, which are based on Eyemouth Links. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of Fast Castle by J. Horsburgh after J. Thomson]
image.creator: Thomson, John
image.description: Depicts the ruins of Fast Castle on a promontory and a stretch of Berwickshire coastline. Fast Castle, near St Abbs Head, Berwickshire, has been identified as an inspiration for Wolf's Crag, the home of the Master of Ravenswood in Sir Walter Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor (1819). In the Magnum Opus edition of the novel (1830), Scott claims that he cannot comment on the perceived resemblance between Wolf's Crag and Fast Castle as he has only seen the latter from the sea. He acknowledges, however, that the position of Fast Castle resembles that of Wolf's Crag. Scott owned a painting of Fast Castle by the Rev. John Thomson (Letters, VIII, 459), quite possibly the one engraved here. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of Inveraray by W. Forrest after W. L. Leitch]
image.creator: Leitch, William Leighton
image.description: Depicts the town of Inveraray (Argyll and Bute) and Loch Fyne. In ch. 12 of Sir Walter Scott's A Legend of Montrose (1819), Sir Duncan Campbell and Captain Dalgetty arrive in Inveraray (formerly Inverary), ancestral home of the Marquis of Argyle. The village is described as 'a rude assemblage of huts, with a very few stone mansions interspersed, stretching upwards from the banks of Loch Fine to the principal gate of the castle'. Extensively rebuilt in 1745, by Scott's age it had become 'a neat country town'. There are further references to Inverary as the seat of the Duke of Argyll in The Heart of Mid-Lothian (1818). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of York Minster by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts York Minster in the moonlight. At the conclusion of Sir Walter Scott's novel Ivanhoe (1819), Wilfred of Ivanhoe marries Rowena 'in the most august of temples, the noble Minster of York' (ch. 44). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Temple Church by J. H. Le Keux after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts the interior of the Temple Church, London. In ch. 35 of Sir Walter Scott's Ivanhoe (1819), the Grand Master of the Knights Templar declares: 'Not one object in England hath met mine eye which it could rest upon with pleasure, save the tombs of our brethren, beneath the massive roof of our Temple Church in yonder proud capital.' The Temple Church was built by the Knights Templar in the 12th century as their English headquarters. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Melrose Abbey by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts the town of Melrose, Scottish Borders, and the ruins of Melrose Abbey with a quarry in the foreground. Sir Walter Scott coordinated the restoration of Melrose Abbey in 1822. The Abbey features in many of Scott's works, most famously The Lay of the Last Minstrel (1805): 'If thou would'st view fair Melrose aright, | Go visit it by the pale moonlight [...] | Then view St. David's ruin'd pile; | And, home returning, soothly swear, | Was never scene so sad and fair!' (canto II, stanza I, lines 1-2, 16-18). The religious house of Kennaquhair in The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) is also based on the Abbey, and it is described in detail in Scott's 'Essay on Border Antiquities' (1814). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Barnbugle Castle and Firth of Forth: From Laurieston Castle.
image.title2: Engraving of the Barnbougle Castle and the Firth of Forth by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts the Firth of Forth from Lauriston Castle, Edinburgh, with cattle in the foreground. In Sir Walter Scott's The Abbot (1820), the hero Roland Graeme 'admired the Gothic towers of Barnbougle, rising from the seabeaten rock, and overlooking one of the most glorious landscapes in Scotland' (ch. 20). The thirteenth-century tower house is the seat of the Earls of Roseberry. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester by G. B. Shaw after W. Lodge
image.creator: Segar, William
image.description: Engraved portrait of Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester (1532 or 3-1588), in full court dress wearing the Order of the Garter. The murder of Amy Robsart, first wife of Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester, is the subject of Sir Walter Scott's Kenilworth (1821). Leicester was Elizabeth I's Master of the Horse and court favourite. He was suspected of arranging Amy Robsart's murder to free himself to marry the Queen. The original steel engraving, after a sixteenth-century portrait by Sir William Segar, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Warwick Castle by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts Warwick Castle in the moonlight, with the River Avon in the foreground. In Sir Walter Scott's Kenilworth (1821), Queen Elizabeth I stays at Warwick Castle while travelling to Kenilworth Castle. Scott describes it as 'that fairest monument of ancient and chivalrous splendour which yet remains uninjured by time' (ch. 25). Scott visited Warwick Castle in September 1815 when travelling home from France. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of Thurso Bay and Orkney Islands by R. Brandard after W. Collins]
image.creator: Collins, William
image.description: Depicts Thurso Bay, Caithness, with a view across the sea to Orkney. Sir Walter Scott's The Pirate (1821) was inspired by the legend of the Orkney pirate, John Gow, and is set partly in Orkney, partly in Shetland. Scott visited both groups of islands in 1814 when he joined a party of Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection around the coast of Scotland. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: View on the Coast of Zetland: The Morning after a Storm
image.title2: Engraving of Shetland (Zetland) by W. Miller after W. Collins
image.creator: Collins, William
image.description: Depicts wreckage off the Shetland coast. In Sir Walter Scott's The Pirate (1822), Captain Cleveland is shipwrecked on the coast of Shetland, where most of the novel is set. Scott visited Shetland in 1814 when he joined a party of Commissioners for the Northern Lighthouse Service on a voyage of inspection around the coast of Scotland. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Royal Palace, Whitehall: As Designed by Inigo Jones
image.title2: Engraving of the Royal Palace at Whitehall by J. Horsburgh after G.H. Dodgson
image.creator: Unknown
image.description: Depicts the Palace of Whitehall, London, and the River Thames. In Walter Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel (1822), the hero Nigel Olifaunt, Lord Glenvarloch travels to the court of King James VI and I at Whitehall, in order to reclaim a sum of money lent to the King by his father. The palace was then undergoing a major modernization at the hands of Inigo Jones. Nigel thus finds the King 'amidst the rubbish of old buildings, and the various confusion attending the erection of the new pile, which formed at present a labyrinth not easily traversed' (ch. 5). A fire in the Palace on 4 January 1698 destroyed all except Inigo Jones's Banqueting Hall. The original steel engraving, from a drawing in the British Museum, was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of James I by G. B. Shaw after the original at the Palace of Holyroodhouse
image.creator: Somer, Paulus van I
image.description: Engraved portrait of King James VI and I (1566-1625) in ermine fringed robes. In Walter Scott's The Fortunes of Nigel (1822), the hero Nigel Olifaunt, Lord Glenvarloch travels to the court of King James VI and I at Whitehall, in order to reclaim a sum of money lent to the King by his father. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847). It derives from a portrait painted in 1618 by Paulus van Somer.

image.title1: [Engraving of Haddon Hall by J. Horsburgh after W. L. Leitch]
image.creator: Leitch, William Leighton
image.description: Depicts Haddon Hall and surrounding countryside. Martindale Castle, ancient seat of the Peverils in Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823), is generally thought to be modelled on Haddon Hall, a fortified medieval manor house belonging to the Manners family. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Peveril Castle by W. Richardson after W. L. Leitch
image.creator: Leitch, William Leighton
image.description: Depicts Peveril Castle overlooking the village of Castleton, Derbyshire. Peveril Castle is the principal seat of Sir Geoffrey Peveril in Sir Walter Scott's novel, Peveril of the Peak (1823). The stronghold, formerly known as Peak Castle, was built around 1080 by William Peveril who is thought to be the illegitimate son of William the Conqueror. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Castle Rushen by W. Miller after W. L. Leitch
image.creator: Leitch, William Leighton
image.description: Depicts the harbour at Castleton, Isle of Man, with Castle Rushen in the background. At the beginning of Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823), the hero Julian Peveril is staying as a guest of the Countess of Derby in Castle Rushen (or Rushin). The Castle was built around 1200 and was the residence of the last Norse King of Man (d. 1266). Scott did not personally visit the Isle of Man, but received information from his younger brother Thomas who served as an officer in the Manx Fencibles from 1808 to 1810. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of P̩ronne by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts four soldiers outside the castle of P̩ronne, Somme, France. In Sir Walter Scott's Quentin Durward (1823), Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy makes his camp at P̩ronne. He is unexpectedly visited there by his enemy Louis XI who, by feigning friendliness, hopes to allay suspicions that he has backed a revolt against Charles's brother-in-law, the Bishop of Li̬ge. Charles sees through Louis's ploy and imprisons him. The King is finally, however, able to persuade Charles of his innocence and regain liberty. Scott himself passed through P̩ronne when travelling from Belgium to France in 1815. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Cologne by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts the waterfront of Cologne, Germany, with, to the right, a view of the Cathedral. In Sir Walter Scott's Quentin Durward (1823), the eponymous hero journeys to Li̬ge with Isabelle de Croye under the pretence of being pilgrims on their way to visit the Shrine of the Three Kings in Cologne Cathedral. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Peebles and the Tweed: From Neidpath Castle
image.title2: Engraving of Neidpath Castle by W. Miller after P. Paton
image.creator: Paton, Peter
image.description: Depicts the Peebles countryside and the River Tweed from the battlements of Neidpath Castle (Scottish Borders). Neidpath Castle, near Peebles, has been suggested as the model for Saint Ronan's Castle as described in chapter I of Saint Ronan's Well (1823). Neidpath is a 14th-century castle converted into a 17th-century tower house. At the turn of the 19th century, it was home to Scott's close friend Adam Ferguson. It also features in Scott's poem 'The Maid of Neidpath', which was published in William Whyte's A Collection of Scottish Airs (1806-07): 'Disease had been in Mary's bower | And slow decay from mourning, | Though now she sits on Neidpath's tower | To watch her Love's returning' (lines 5-8). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Dumfries, Scotland by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts the River Nith and the town of Dumfries. The first part of Sir Walter Scott's Redgauntlet (1824) consists of a series of letters between Darsie Latimer and Alan Fairford. Darsie's first letter is sent from Dumfries which he has made his base while rambling through the countryside of Dumfries and Galloway. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Llanberis Pass by W. Miller after R. K. Penson
image.creator: Penson, Richard Kyrke
image.description: Depicts a traveller making his way through the Llanberis Pass, Wales, with Dolbadern Castle in the background. Sir Walter Scott's The Betrothed (1824) is a tale of Anglo-Welsh Border conflict set in the Welsh Marches. In ch. 9 an Anglo-Norman force lifts the siege of the castle of Garde Douleureuse. The defeated Welsh army are seen fleeing through the pass protected by the Castle: 'The single pass by which they could cross to the other side was soon completely choked by fugitives, on whose rear raged the swords of the victorious Normans. Many threw themselves into the river, upon the precarious chance of gaining the farther side, and, except a few, who were uncommonly strong, skilful, and active, perished among the rocks and in the currents'. To illustrate this scene, R. K. Penson has chosen to portray Dolbadern Castle and the Llanberis Pass, although neither is geographically close to the Welsh Marches. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Convent of St. Saba, Wilderness of Engadi, Holy Land
image.title2: Engraving of the Convent of St Saba by J. Horsburgh after D. Roberts
image.creator: Roberts, David
image.description: Depicts the monastery of Mar Saba overlooking the Kidron Valley (West Bank). In chapter 6 of Sir Walter Scott's The Talisman (1825), King Richard of England is informed that his wife Queen Berengaria has set out on a pilgrimage to the 'Convent of Engadi', i.e. the Greek-Orthodox Monastery Mar Saba. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Worcester by W. Miller after T. Creswick
image.creator: Creswick, Thomas
image.description: Depicts the River Severn and city of Worcester. The plot of Sir Walter Scott's novel Woodstock (1826) revolves around the escape of King Charles II following his decisive defeat by Cromwell at the Battle of Worcester (3 September 1651). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of Windsor Castle by J. Horsburgh after T. Creswick]
image.creator: Creswick, Thomas
image.description: Depicts Windsor Castle, Berkshire, by moonlight. In Sir Walter Scott's Woodstock (1826), Cromwell is stationed at Windsor while awaiting the capture of the fugitive King Charles II. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of Kilchurn Castle and Loch Awe by W. Miller after H. McCulloch]
image.creator: McCulloch, Horatio
image.description: Depicts Loch Awe and Kilchurn Castle (Argyl and Bute, Scotland). In Sir Walter Scott's The Highland Widow (1827), the narrator Mrs. Bethune Baliol meets Elspat MacTavish, the widow of the title, while on a Highland tour. On the morning before their meeting, Mrs Baliol's party takes a boat-trip across Loch Awe, and their guide tells 'a hundred legends of the stern chiefs of Loch Awe, Duncan with the thrum bonnet, and the other lords of the now mouldering towers of Kilchurn'. The Castle, seat of the Lairds of Glenurquhay, was built around 1440. The original painting by Horatio McCulloch was made in 1844. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Ben Lawers, From the South Shore of Loch Tay
image.title2: Engraving of Ben Lawers by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts the south face of Ben Lawers as seen from Loch Tay, Perthshire. In ch. 27 of Sir Walter Scott's The Fair Maid of Perth (1828), the mountains seen from the north bank of Loch Tay are likened to a 'clan of Titans [...] commanded by their appropriate chieftains -- the frowning mountain of Ben Lawers, and the still more lofty eminence of Ben Mohr'. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: St. Omer and the Cathedral, Strasbourg
image.title2: Engraving of Strasbourg by W. Richardson after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts Strasbourg Cathedral, Alsace, France, with, in the foreground, the Protestant englise Saint-Thomas (incorrectly identified as St. Omer). In Sir Walter Scott's Anne of Geierstein (1829), two exiled Lancastrians, John de Vere, Earl of Oxford, and his son, Arthur, travel to Strasbourg on a mission to convert Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy, to the Lancastrian cause. In Strasbourg Cathedral, Arthur meets Margaret of Anjou, widow of the Lancastrian King Henry VI (ch. 24). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraving of Mount Pilatus by J. Cousen after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Presents a view of the Swiss Alps from Mount Pilatus. In Sir Walter Scott's Anne of Geierstein (1829), the exiled Lancastrians John de Vere, Earl of Oxford, and his son, Arthur, travel incognito through Switzerland on a mission to convert Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy, to the Lancastrian cause. As they stand beneath the 'dark and shadowy eminence' of Mount Pilatus, they are told the local legend that Pontius Pilate committed suicide by throwing himself into the lake at its summit and that his ghost still haunts the peak. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: The Walls of Constantinople and Distant View of the Sea of Marmara
image.title2: Engraving of the Walls of Constantinople by W. Forrest after T. Allom
image.creator: Allom, Thomas
image.description: Depicts the city walls of Istanbul, Turkey. Sir Walter Scott's Count Robert of Paris is set in Constantinople during the reign of the Byzantine Emperor Alexius Comnenus (1081-1118).The opening scene takes place outside the Golden Gate before 'the massive, and seemingly impregnable walls with which Constantine surrounded the city' and which 'were greatly improved and added to by Theodosius' (ch. 2). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of the Rumeli Fortress and the Bosporus by W. Richardson after T. Allom]
image.creator: Allom, Thomas
image.description: Depicts the Rumeli Hisar, Istanbul, Turkey and the River Bosporus. Sir Walter Scott's Count Robert of Paris is set in Constantinople during the reign of the Byzantine Emperor Alexius Comnenus (1081-1118). The fortress of Rumeli Hisar portrayed here was built in 1451 or 1452, some three-and-a-half centuries later than the setting of the novel. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of the Palace of Holyroodhouse by W. Miller after C. Stanfield]
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh, with the Salisbury Crags and the Firth of Forth in the background. In Sir Walter Scott's Waverley (1814), the Royal Palace of Holyroodhouse is occupied by Prince Charles Edward Stuart and is the scene of a ball (ch. 43). The Palace is also described in Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Highland Hills, From the Teith Below Callander
image.title2: Engraving of the Highland Hills, near Callander by W. Miller after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts a view from the River Teith, Perthshire. In ch. 38 of Sir Walter Scott's Waverley (1814), Edward Waverley is rescued by a party of Jacobite Highlanders and escorted through the Menteith district and over the River Teith to Doune Castle. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: [Engraving of boats on Lake Windermere by E. Goodall after C. Stanfield]
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts a ferry crossing Lake Windermere, Cumbria. This engraving illustrates a passage in ch. 16 of Sir Walter Scott's Guy Mannering (1815), where Julia Mannering is serenaded by Henry Bertram on an (unnamed) Westmorland lake. Scott met his wife Charlotte when holidaying in the Lake District in 1797. He made further visits to the region in 1805, 1813, and 1825. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Skiddaw and Saddleback: From Bolton Moor.
image.title2: Engraving of Skiddaw and Saddleback by R. Brandard after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts Bolton Moor, Cumbria, with Skiddaw and Saddleback mountains in the background. In ch. 22 of Guy Mannering (1815), Sir Walter Scott describes the hero Henry Bertram setting out on foot from Cumbria to Scotland: 'Let the reader conceive to himself a clear frosty November morning, the scene an open heath,--having for the background that huge chain of mountains in which Skiddaw and Saddleback are pre-eminent.' Scott met his wife Charlotte when holidaying in the Lake District in 1797. He made further visits to the region in 1805, 1813, and 1825. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: Dundee in the Time of the Antiquary
image.title2: Engraving of Dundee by E. Goodall after C. Stanfield
image.creator: Stanfield, Clarkson
image.description: Depicts the River Tay and the waterfront of Dundee. Sir Walter Scott himself acknowledged that Jonathan Oldbuck, the titular character of The Antiquary (1816), was based partly on a family friend George Constable who first introduced Scott to Shakespeare. Constable was a native of Dundee, and Oldbuck's house of Monkbarns is sometimes thought to be based on Constable's estate of Craigie Wallace. The original steel engraving was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title1: From the Original Picture in the Possession of Mr. Murray: Painted 1824
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by W. Finden after G. S. Newton
image.creator: Newton, Gilbert Stuart
image.description: Three-quarter portrait of Walter Scott at the age of fifty-three. Sir Walter Scott sat for Gilbert Stuart Newton in August 1824. The portrait was commissioned by the publisher John Murray and is held by his heirs. The engraving was first published by John Murray in 1833. It includes a facsimile of Scott's handwriting with the words: 'Very truly yours, Walter Scott. Abbotsford 3 Sept. 1824'.

image.title1: The Portrait Engraved by Woolnoth and the Emblematical Design by Hawksworth
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by T. Woolnoth after A. Geddes, with ornamental frieze by J. Hawkesworth
image.creator: Geddes, Andrew (b.1783, d.1844)
image.description: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott (aged forty-seven or forty-eight), surrounded by a Gothic border with vignettes taken from his poems. The original portrait by Andrew Geddes began life as a study for his The Discovery of the Regalia of Scotland (1821). The sitting took place some time between 4 February 1818, the date of the discovery of the Regalia, and the beginning of 1819 when Scott fell seriously ill. The portrait suggests that Scott's health is already deteriorating. Originally purchased by the collector Sir James Stuart, 7th Baronet of Allanbank, the picture now hangs in the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. Woolnoth's engraving is after a drawing by Geddes himself, or possibly after an earlier engraving by F.C. Lewis (1824). The ornamental frieze by Hawkesworth features scenes from Scott's poems, some based on illustrations by Richard Westall. Scott had not yet publicly acknowledged authorship of the Waverley Novels (he would do so in 1827).

image.title1: Sir Walter Scott, and His Favorite Maida: From an Original Sketch
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by R.J Hamerton
image.creator: Hamerton, Robert Jacob
image.description: Engraved portrait of a seated Walter Scott with his dog Maida. This engraved portrait by Robert Jacob Hamerton (fl. 1831-1858) was published by J. M. M'Cormack, London, in 1832. The 'original sketch' has not been identified. The face bears a close resemblance to that in Charles Robert Leslie's 1824 portrait of Scott, especially as engraved by M. I. Danforth in 1829.

image.title1: [Etched portrait of Walter Scott by William Nicholson]
image.creator: Nicholson, William
image.description: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott aged forty-six, with his dog Maida. William Nicholson made at least three watercolour portraits of Sir Walter Scott in 1816. One formed the basis for this etching executed in 1817 by Nicholson himself. The only significant difference between the watercolour and the etching is that Scott's dog Maida has been moved somewhat to the right, leaving more of Scott's waistcoat visible.

image.title1: [Walter Scott]: Etched by W. Mayor after a Sketch by Edwin Landseer
image.title2: Facsimile of etched portrait of Walter Scott by W. Mayor after E. Landseer
image.creator: Landseer, Edwin (b.1802, d.1873)
image.description: Facsimile of etched profile portrait of Walter Scott. The etching by W. Mayor was taken from a portrait now in the collection of the Dower House Gallery, Boughton House. According to Algernon Graves, the portrait was painted in 1831 (Catalogue of the Works of the Late Sir Edwin Landseer, no. 163). There is no record of Scott sitting for Landseer in that year, but Scott appears markedly older than in sketches made by Landseer in 1824. Francis Russell agrees that it is 'not unreasonable' to suggest that Landseer may have seen Scott in 1831, but argues that Landseer nonetheless referred to his earlier sketches of Scott (Portraits of Sir Walter Scott, no. 113). The etching by Mayor was published in 1832.

image.title1: [Facsimile of silhouette of Sir Walter Scott by A. Edouart]
image.creator: Edouart, Augustin Amant Constant Fid̬le
image.description: Profile full-length silhouette of Sir Walter Scott at the age of fifty-nine (with slight water damage). The original silhouette of Sir Walter Scott was cut by Augustin Edouart in Edinburgh in 1831. It is now held by the Scottish National Portrait Gallery.

image.title1: [Facsimile of silhouette of Walter Scott at his desk by A. Edouart]
image.creator: Edouart, Augustin Amant Constant Fid̬le
image.description: Newspaper clipping of silhouette of Sir Walter Scott, aged fifty-nine, writing at his desk. The original silhouette of Sir Walter Scott was cut by Augustin Edouart in Edinburgh in 1831. It is now held by the Scottish National Portrait Gallery.

image.title1: Sir Walter Scott: From a Sketch by Sir Edwin Landseer
image.title2: Pencil drawing of Sir Walter Scott after E. Landseer
image.creator: Landseer, Edwin (b.1802, d.1873)
image.description: Pencil sketch of three-quarter portrait of Sir Walter Scott, with, below, a further profile of Scott. The original sketch by Sir Edwin Landseer was probably made during his visit to Abbotsford in 1824. It is now held by the Victoria and Albert Museum. This pencil drawing was probably made by James Clarkson Corson, copied from a reprint of the original sketch in Richard Garnett and Edmund Gosse's English Literature (1903).

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by W.T. Fry after T. Phillips
image.creator: Phillips, Thomas
image.description: Engraved half-length portrait of Walter Scott, aged forty-four, with a plaid of Stuart tartan over his shoulders. The dating of the half-length portrait of Scott made by Thomas Phillips for the publisher John Murray remains uncertain. In his Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart. (2nd edn, 1839), J.G. Lockhart dates it to 1818, relying on information provided by Phillips himself. In his Portraits of Sir Walter Scott, however, Francis Russell argues that 1815 is more probable (no. 157). Scott did not, in fact, visit London in 1818 but spent ten weeks there in 1815, spending a good deal of time at John Murray's where he met Byron. The engraving by Fry was first published by Boys, 1 November 1820.

image.title1: Walter Scott, Esq.: Engraved For the New Monthly Magazine, by Hy. Meyer
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by H. Meyer after H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott at the age of thirty-six. The original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn was commissioned by Scott's publisher Archibald Constable in 1808. It is now part of the collection at Bowhill, seat of the Duke of Buccleuch. Meyer's engraving was published in the November 1818 issue of the New Monthly Magazine. It is based on an earlier engraving by Charles Picart (1811) made from a drawing by William Evans. Evans substituted the outdoor backdrop of Raeburn's portrait for an interior suggestive of the writer's study.

image.title1: Sir Walter Scott: From the Original in Possession of the Publishers
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by H. Robinson after J. W. Gordon
image.creator: Gordon, John Watson, Sir (b.1788, d.1864)
image.description: Engraved three-quarter portrait of Walter Scott, seated in a study. The original portrait by John Watson Gordon was probably painted to be engraved by Samuel Freeman for Robert Chambers's Lives of Eminent Scotsmen, vol. 4 (Glasgow: Blackie and Son, 1835). It derives from an earlier unfinished portrait by Gordon, painted in spring 1830 and now held by the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. The engraving by Robinson was first published by Blackie and Son in 1837. It adds a chair, bookshelves, curtains, and the Byron urn to the Gordon/Freeman original.

image.title2: Engraving of Walter Scott with family and friends by J. Smith after D. Willkie
image.creator: Wilkie, David
image.description: Depicts Walter Scott with family and friends in south-country peasant dress. Sir David Wilkie was commissioned to paint 'The Abbotsford Family' by Scott's friend Sir Adam Ferguson in 1817. The sittings took place at Abbotsford in October of that year. Portrayed from left are: Lady Scott; Ann Scott (Scott's younger daughter); Sophia Scott (Scott's older daughter, later Mrs. John Gibson Lockhart); Sir Walter Scott (seated); Thomas Scott (shepherd); Charles Scott (Scott's younger son); Sir Adam Ferguson; Walter Scott (Scott's oldest son). The dogs are Maida (left) and Ourisk (right). The painting is now held by the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. The engraving by John Smith was made for the Abbotsford Edition of the Waverley Novels (1842-1847).

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by E. Smith after D. Wilkie
image.creator: Wilkie, David
image.description: Engraved three-quarter portrait of Walter Scott (aged fifty-three) in fur-trimmed cloak. The portrait by David Wilkie originated in 1824 as a sketch for The Entrance of King George the Fourth at Holyrood, where Scott was to figure among the King's attendants. It was subsequently worked up as an independent painting for Sir William Knighton in 1828. It was engraved by Edward Smith for Robert Cadell, Edinburgh, and Moon, Graves, and Boys, London, in 1829. In 1830, it was published as the frontispiece to vol. I of The Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott by W.H. Lizars after W. Wilkie
image.creator: Wilkie, William
image.description: Engraved portrait of Walter Scott at the age of sixty. The original portrait by Captain William Wilkie was painted in 1831. The undated engraving by Lizars was published by George Tait, Haddington, and Alexander Hill, Edinburgh. George Tait died in 1844.

image.title1: Henry Mackenzie: From the Original in Possession of the Publishers
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Henry Mackenzie by S. Freeman after J. Watson Gordon
image.creator: Gordon, John Watson, Sir (b.1788, d.1864)
image.description: Engraved portrait of Scottish novelist Henry Mackenzie (1745-1831). Scott read Henry Mackenzie's novels in his youth and became his friend and colleague in adulthood.Mackenzie contributed to Walter Scott's Edinburgh Annual Register and both men were trustees of the Edinburgh Theatre. In 1823, Scott edited Mackenzie's fiction for Ballantyne's Novelists Library, and provided a biographical sketch of the author which was subsequently reprinted as one of his Lives of the Novelists. The original portrait by Watson Gordon was probably expressly painted to be engraved by Freeman for Chambers's Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen (1835). It may have derived from an earlier portrait by Watson Gordon painted during Mackenzie's lifetime.

image.title2: Engraved portrait by G. Parker after S.A. Hart of the heroine of Scott's novel The Talisman
image.creator: Hart, Solomon Alexander
image.description: Depicts Edith Plantagenet, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's novel The Talisman (1825), dressed as a Carmelite votaress with a chaplet of red and white roses. This portrait of Edith Plantagenet was inspired by a passage in ch. 4 of The Talisman in which Edith appears as a Carmelite novice: 'Six, who from their black scapularies, and black veils over their white garments, appeared to be professed nuns of the order of Mount Carmel; and as many whose veils, being white, argued them to be novices, or occasional inhabitants in the cloister, who were not as yet bound to it by vows. The former held in their hands large rosaries, while the younger and lighter figures who followed carried each a chaplet of red and white roses... one of the white-stoled maidens, as she glided by him, detached from the chaplet which she carried a rosebud, which dropped from her fingers, perhaps unconsciously, on the foot of Sir Kenneth.'

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Dugald Stewart by S. Freeman after H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Engraved half-length portrait of Scottish philosopher Dugald Stewart (1753-1828). Sir Walter Scott studied Moral Philosophy under Dugald Stewart at Edinburgh University in 1789-90. An exponent of the Scottish 'Common Sense' School of philosophy, Stewart greatly influenced Scott's views on history, human nature, and political ethics. At one stage good friends, the two men fell out following Scott's vehement support of Henry Dundas, Viscount Melville when he was impeached in 1806 for misappropriation of public money. The original portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn was painted ca. 1810.

image.title2: Engraved portrait by H.T. Ryall after W. Mulready of the heroine of Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Mulready, William
image.description: Engraved half-length portrait of Alice Bridgenorth, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak (1823). This portrait of Alice Bridgenorth was inspired by the following lines in ch. 13 of the novel: 'The sad-coloured gown--the pinched and plaited cap, which carefully obscured the profusion of long dark-brown hair--the small ruff, and the long sleeves, would have appeared to great disadvantage on a shape less graceful than Alice Bridgenorth's.'

image.title2: Engraved portrait by W.H. Egleston after J.W. Wright of the heroine of Scott's novel Castle Dangerous
image.creator: Wright, John William
image.description: Engraved half-length portrait of Lady Augusta de Berkely, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's Castle Dangerous (1831), disguised as a male pilgrim. The portrait illustrates the line: 'In a moment, I think, of madness, I resolved to set out in this masculine disguise' (ch. 11). Lady Augusta, an English heiress, has promised to marry Sir John de Walton if he can defend the strategically vital Castle Douglas against the forces of Robert the Bruce and Sir James Douglas (the 'Black Douglas') for a year and a day. Increasingly alarmed, though, by the danger he is running, she travels to Douglasdale in masculine disguise. The scallop shell was the universally recognized badge of a pilgrim.

image.title2: Engraved portrait by C.E. Wagstaff after J. Inskipp of the heroine of Scott's novel The Betrothed
image.creator: Inskipp, James
image.description: Engraved half-length portrait of Eveline Berenger, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's novel The Betrothed (1825). This portrait of Eveline Berenger, heroine of Sir Walter Scott's The Betrothed (1825), was inspired by the following line in ch. 8: 'The morning light was scarce fully spread abroad, when Eveline Berenger, in compliance with her confessor's advice, commenced her progress around the walls and battlements of the beleaguered castle.' Eveline's father, the Anglo-Norman Raymond Berenger, has refused her hand to the Welsh prince Gwenwyn, and the incensed Gwenwyn has laid siege to the Berengers' castle of Garde Douloureuse.

image.title2: Engraving of Lochmaben Castle by J.T. Willmore after J.M.W. Turner
image.creator: Turner, Joseph Mallord William (b.1775, d.1851)
image.description: Engraved title page for The Poetical Works of Walter Scott, vol. III, with vignette depicting the ruins of Lochmaben Castle, Dumfries and Galloway. Lochmaben Castle near Dumfries was the seat of the Bruce family in their capacity as Lords of Annandale and has been proposed by some historians as the birthplace of Robert the Bruce, hero of Sir Walter Scott's The Lord of the Isles (1815). Built in the 13th century, the castle lay in ruins by Scott's time. There are further references to Lochmaben Castle and the Bruces in Scott's The Monastery and The Abbot (both 1820) and in the traditional ballad 'The Lochmaben Harper' which Scott included in his Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802-1803).

image.title1: Alexander Adam, L.L.D.: From the Original Painting in the Royal High School Edinburgh
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Alexander Adam by S. Freeman after H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Engraved half-length portrait of Scottish educationalist Alexander Adam (1741-1809). Alexander Adam was Rector of the High School of Edinburgh where Sir Walter Scott was educated from 1779 to 1783. One of the most innovative educators of his age, he sought to instil in his pupils not only a grasp of grammar but a sensitivity to literary language. With Adam's encouragement, the young Scott translated Horace and Virgil into English verse and made his first attempts at original composition. The original portrait was painted by Raeburn ca. 1808.

image.title2: Engraving of Edinburgh Castle by Heath
image.creator: Heath, James
image.description: Depicts the north-west face of Edinburgh Castle. Edinburgh Castle is the most prominent landmark of Scott's hometown. It was here that on 4 February 1818 Scott helped discover the lost Regalia (or Crown Jewels) of Scotland. The Castle also figures in a number of Scott's novels, notably Waverley and The Heart of Midlothian, and is described in his Provincial Antiquities and Picturesque Scenery of Scotland (1826). The engraving is by James Heath, possibly after his own design.

image.title2: Engraving of a cave at Staffa by E. Goodall after J.W.M. Turner
image.creator: Turner, Joseph Mallord William (b.1775, d.1851)
image.description: Engraved title page for The Poetical Works of Walter Scott, vol. X, with image of Staffa, Inner Hebrides. Sir Walter Scott visited the Isle of Staffa in 1810 and declared it 'one of the most extraordinary places I ever beheld' which 'exceeded in my mind every description I had heard of it' (Letter to Joanna Baillie, July 19, 1810). He was particularly struck by Fingal's Cave: 'the appearance of the cavern composed entirely of basaltic pillars as high as the roof of a cathedral and running deep into the rock, eternally swept by a deep and swelling sea, and paved as it were with ruddy marble baffles all description'. He subsequently described Fingal's Cave in The Lord of the Isles (1815), canto IV, stanza X: 'that wondrous dome, | Where, as to shame the temples deck'd | By skill of earthly architect, | Nature herself, it seem'd, would raise | A Minster to her Maker's p raise!' (lines 13-17). The island and its caves are further celebrated in 'Lines Addressed to Ranald Macdonald, Esq. of Staffa' (1814).

image.title2: Engraved portrait by H. Meyer after J.S. Stump of a character from Scott's novel Kenilworth
image.creator: Stump, John Samuel
image.description: Engraved portrait depicting Janet Foster, lady-in-waiting to Amy Robsart in Sir Walter Scott's Kenilworth (1821). This portrait of Janet Foster is inspired by a passage in ch. 5 of the novel. Janet admires a string of pearls sent as a gift to Amy by her husband the Earl of Leicester: '"Surely, lady," said Janet, gazing with admiration at the neck-string of pearls, "the daughters of Tyre wore no fairer neck-jewels than these. And then the posy, 'For a neck that is fairer'--each pearl is worth a freehold.'

image.title2: Engraved portrait by H. Cook after H. Howard of a character from Scott's novel Peveril of the Peak
image.creator: Howard, Henry
image.description: Engraved portrait of Fenella, confidante of the Countess of Derby in Sir Walter Scott's Peveril of the Peak (1823). This portrait is inspired by a passage in ch. 5 of the novel. Fenella, who has assumed the role of a deaf mute, attempts to warn Julian Peveril against keeping a rendezvous with Alice Bridgenorth: 'She proceeded to put him to the question by a series of gestures, which we will endeavour to describe. She commenced by extending her hand slightly, accompanied with the sharp inquisitive look which served her as a note of interrogation... Fenella looked grave, shook her head, and pointed to the Countess's window, which was visible from the spot where they stood.'

image.title1: Francis Jeffrey: One of the Lords of Session
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Francis Jeffrey by G. Stodart after G. Hayter
image.creator: Hayter, George
image.description: Engraved profile portrait of the Scottish lawyer and critic Francis Jeffrey, Lord Jeffrey (1773-1850). Francis Jeffrey was one of the founders of the Edinburgh Review and responsible for asking his fellow advocate Walter Scott to contribute. The Review flourished with Jeffrey as editor, and he became a powerful and influential critic. Jeffrey reviewed a number of Scott's own works making few concessions to personal friendship. Scott was particularly hurt by his critique of Marmion (1808), feeling that it might have been couched 'in language rather more civil to a personal friend'.
