While entertaining the highest regard for Jeffrey's talents, Scott felt he lacked 'the taste for poetry which is essentially necessary to enjoy and of course to criticize it with justice', and specifically 'that enthusiastic feeling which like sun-shine upon a landscape lights up every beauty and palliates if it cannot hide ever defect' (letter to Joanna Baillie, 31 October 1808).

image.title2: Engraved portrait by W.H. Mote after E.T. Parris of a character from Scott's novel Anne of Geierstein
image.creator: Parris, Edmund Thomas
image.description: Engraved portrait of Hermione, a character in Scott's Anne of Geierstein (1829). This portrait of Hermione, a learned Persian woman who acts as tutor to the Baron of Arnheim in Anne of Geierstein, was inspired by the following passage in ch. 11 of the novel: 'The silver lamp was extinguished, or removed from its pedestal, where stood in place of it a most beautiful female figure in the Persian costume, in which the color of pink predominated. But she wore no turban or head-dress of any kind, saving a blue ribbon drawn through her auburn hair, and secured by a gold clasp, the outer side of which was ornamented by a superb opal [...]. The little lady's countenance was of a lively and expressive character, in which spirit and wit seemed to predominate; and the quick dark eye, with its beautifully formed eyebrow, seemed to presage the arch remark, to which the rosy and half smiling lip appeared ready to give utterance.'

image.title2: Engraved portrait by H. Robinson after S.J. Rochard of the heroine of Scott's novel Quentin Durward
image.creator: Rochard, Simon Jacques
image.description: Engraved profile portrait of Countess Isabelle de Croye, heroine of Scott's Quentin Durward (1823). This portrait of Isabelle de Croye is inspired by the eponymous hero's first glimpse of her: 'He speedily made the discovery that a quantity of long black tresses, which, in the maiden fashion of his own country, were unadorned by any ornament, except a single chaplet lightly woven out of ivy leaves, formed a veil around a countenance which, in its regular features, dark eyes, and pensive expression, resembled that of Melpomene, though there was a faint glow on the cheek, and an intelligence on the lips and in the eye, which made it seem that gaiety was not foreign to a countenance so expressive, although it might not be its most habitual expression.' (ch. 4)

image.title1: Sir John Leslie: Professor of Natural Philosophy in the University of Edinburgh
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir John Leslie by J. Johnstone after B.W. Crombie
image.creator: Crombie, Benjamin William
image.description: Engraved profile portrait of Scottish mathematician, scientist, and prolific inventor Sir John Leslie (1766-1832). In 1808 Sir Walter Scott engaged Sir John Leslie, Professor of Mathematics at Edinburgh University, to contribute scientific articles to the Edinburgh Annual Register. Writing to George Ellis, Scott described Leslie as 'a great philosopher, and as abominable an animal as I ever saw', adding that 'he writes, however, with great eloquence, and is an enthusiast in mathematical, chemical, and mineralogical pursuits' (13 December 1808). The original portrait by Benjamin W. Crosbie was probably made for his Modern Athenians (1831), a collection of caricature etchings of prominent Edinburgh citizens.

image.title1: Major Gen. David Stewart, of Garth
image.title2: Engraved portrait of Major General David Stewart by J.B. Shaw after J.W. Gordon
image.creator: Gordon, John Watson, Sir (b.1788, d.1864)
image.description: Engraved half-length portrait of Major-General David Stewart (1772-1829) in military uniform. David Stewart of Garth worked with Sir Walter Scott on the committee which organized the visit of King George IV to Edinburgh in August 1822. A hero of the Napoleonic Wars, Stewart is now best-known as the author of Sketches of the Character, Manners and Present State of the Highlanders of Scotland (1822). In 1828 he was appointed Governor of St Lucia. In a letter to J. G. Lockhart of 14 July 1828, Scott expresses his pleasure in the appointment, praising Stewart as a 'highlander of the old stamp'.

image.title2: Engraved portrait of Sir David Wilkie by W. Holl after A. Geddes
image.creator: Geddes, Andrew (b.1783, d.1844)
image.description: Engraved half-length portrait of Scottish painter Sir David Wilkie (1785-1841). Sir David Wilkie painted Scott on three occasions: in the group compositions 'The Abbotsford Family' (1817) and 'The Entrance of King George IV at Holyrood' (1829) and in an individual portrait (1824). He also left a sketch of 'Sir Walter Scott Coursing' (1817 or 1824). Besides painting a number of pictures inspired by the Waverley Novels, Wilkie contributed illustrations to the Magnum Opus edition of the Waverley Novels. Scott was a great admirer of Wilkie's work. In chapter 10 of The Antiquary (1816), he describes Steenie Mucklebackit's mourning family as presenting 'a scene which our Wilkie alone could have painted, with that exquisite feeling of nature that characterises his enchanting productions'. The original portrait of Wilkie by Andrew Geddes was painted in 1821.

image.title2: Engraved title page for Redgauntlet by J. Horsburgh after W. Kidd
image.creator: Kidd, William
image.description: Engraved title page for Redgauntlet, vol. XXXVI of the Magnum Opus edition of the Waverley Novels. The portrait depicts Peter Peebles, the novel's obsessive litigant, standing before Parliament House, seat of Scotland's Court of Session. As a newly qualified advocate, the novel's hero Alan Fairford takes up Peebles's case. The inscription reads: 'The identical Peter wears a huge great coat, threadbare and patched. His hair, half grey, half black, escaped in elflocks around a huge wig made of tow, above which he plants an immense cocked hat.' This is an abbreviated description of Peter Peebles taken from Letter XIII: Alan Fairford to Darsie Latimer.

image.title2: Engraved title page for The Talisman by S. Sangster after J.W. Gordon
image.creator: Gordon, John Watson, Sir (b.1788, d.1864)
image.description: Engraved title page for The Talisman, vol. XXXVIII in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration portrays the meeting between the novel's hero, Sir Kenneth and Saladin. The inscription reads: 'Christian and Saracen, sat down together on the turf, and produced each the small allowance of store which they carried for their own refreshment.' (ch. 2)

image.title2: Engraved title page for Anne of Geierstein by J. Rolls after J.W. Wright
image.creator: Wright, John William
image.description: Engraved title page for Anne of Geierstein, vol. XLV in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the heroine's attendant Annette announcing to her the arrival of Arthur de Vere at Castle Arnheim. The inscription reads: 'Annette sped up a narrow turnpike stair to a closet or dressing-room, where her young mistress was seated, and exclaimed with open mouth -- Anne of Gei -- I mean my Lady Baroness, they are come, they are come !' (ch. 21)

image.title2: Engraved title page for The Pirate by Freebairn after A. Cooper
image.creator: Cooper, Abraham
image.description: Engraved title page for The Pirate, vol. XXV in the Magnum Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the heroine Minna Troil riding to Ull Troil's tower. The inscription reads: 'She could not help looking back to see how Minna should pass the point of peril, which she herself had just rounded: Minna, with an eager look dropped the bridle, and stretched forward her arms, and even her body, over the precipice in the attitude of a wild swan, when balancing itself.' (ch. 27)

image.title2: Engraved title page for The Abbot by W.H. Watt after E. Landseer
image.creator: Landseer, Edwin (b.1802, d.1873)
image.description: Engraved title page for The Abbot, vol. XX in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the rescue of the hero Roland Graeme by Lady Avenel's stag-hound Wolf. The inscription reads: 'Wolf marked the object of her anxiety, he swam straight to the spot where his assistance was so much wanted, and, seizing the childs under dress in his mouth, he not only kept him afloat, but towed him towards the causeway.' (ch. 1)

image.title2: Engraved title page for Old Mortality by C. Fox after J. Burnet
image.creator: Burnet, John (b.1784, d.1868)
image.description: Engraved title page for Old Mortality, vol. IX in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the arrival of Henry Morton at Cuddie Headrigg's cottage upon his return from exile. The child is Cuddie' daughter. The inscription reads: 'The child set down its water-pitcher, hardly understanding what was said to her, put her fair flaxen hair apart on her brows, and opened her round blue eyes with the wondering "what's yere wull?"' (ch. 37)

image.title2: Engraved title page for A Legend of Montrose by F. Bacon after W. Boxall
image.creator: Boxall, William
image.description: Engraved title page for A Legend of Montrose, vol. XV in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the Earl of Menteith and Allan M'Aulay rescuing the heroine Annot Lyle from the Children of the Mist. The inscription reads: 'One little maiden alone, who smiled upon Allan's drawn dirk, escaped his vengeance upon my earnest entreaty. She was brought to the castle and here bred up under the name of Annot Lyle.' (ch. 5)

image.title2: Engraved title page for Peveril of the Peak by F. Bacon after J. Webster
image.creator: Webster, J.
image.description: Engraved title page for Peveril of the Peak, vol. XXVIII in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the young Julian Peveril preparing to protect Alice Bridgenorth from an intruder (who will shortly be revealed as the Countess of Derby). The inscription reads: 'Yet naturally bold and high-spirited, the little champion placed himself beside his defenceless sister, continuing to brandish his weapon in her defence, as boldly as he had himself been an Abencerrage of Grenada.' (ch. 5) 'Sister' is used here in the sense of 'comrade' or 'companion'.

image.title2: Engraved title page for The Fortunes of Nigel by A. Fox after W. Boxall
image.creator: Boxall, William
image.description: Engraved title page for The Fortunes of Nigel, vol. XXVI in the Magnum Opus Edition of the Waverley Novels. The illustration depicts the visit of Vincent Jenkins, or 'Vin Jin' to Dame Ursley Suddlechop. Vin Jin, apprentice to George Heriot, has contracted gambling debts in an effort to gain a fortune sufficient to win Margaret Ramsay for a bride. He has come to upbraid Dame Ursley for offering him bad advice and to demand her aid in extricating himself from his predicament. The inscription reads: '[as] Jin Vin, threw himself into the great leathern chair, in which Dame Ursley was wont to solace herself of an evening, he declared "himself the most miserable dog within the sound of Bow-bell."' (ch. 21)

image.title2: Engraved portrait of John Home by J. Rogers after H. Raeburn
image.creator: Raeburn, Henry, Sir (b.1756, d.1823)
image.description: Engraved half-length portrait of Scottish dramatist John Home (1722-1808). The Scottish dramatist John Home befriended the infant Sir Walter Scott and his aunt Jenny when they were taking the waters in Bath in 1775-1776. Scott subsequently became a frequent visitor to Home's villa at Kilduff outside Edinburgh. Scott reviewed Henry Mackenzie's edition of Home's Works (1822) in the Quarterly Review for June 1827, providing a detailed account of Home's life. The original portrait by Raeburn was painted ca. 1795-1800.
